State Law reference- Municipal powers as to cemeteries and burials, Code of Virginia, §§ 15.2-972, 15.2-1111, 15.2-1121; offenses relating to cemeteries, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-125 et seq.; advertising near public cemetery, Code of Virginia, § 33.1-369(1); lot in burial ground exempt from levy and distress, Code of Virginia, §§ 34-26, 34-28; cemetery operators, perpetual care trust funds and preneed burial contracts, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-2310 et seq.; cemeteries generally, Code of Virginia, § 57-22 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 30-1. - Unlawful entry on cemetery property. 
    If any person, without the consent of the owner, proprietor or custodian, shall go or enter in the nighttime, upon the premises, property, driveways or walks of any cemetery, either public or private, for any purpose other than to visit the burial lot or grave of some member of his family, he shall be guilty of a class 4 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1981, § 21-50) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-125. 
Secs. 30-2-30-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - BLANDFORD CEMETERY 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 30-31. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Cemetery means the Blandford Cemetery, owned and operated by the city. 
    Director and cemetery director mean the director of the Blandford Cemetery, unless otherwise indicated. 
(Code 1981, § 8-1) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 30-32. - Violations of article. 
    Unless otherwise specifically provided, any person who shall violate any provision of this article shall be guilty of a class 3 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1981, § 8-2) 
Sec. 30-33. - Operating rules and regulations. 
(a)  The city manager shall prepare rules and regulations governing the operation of the cemetery. When such rules and regulations have been submitted to and approved by the city council, they shall become the official rules and regulations governing the operation of the cemetery. 
(b)  The city council may, at any time, adopt new rules and regulations governing the operation of the cemetery and may amend, alter or repeal any rule or regulation previously prepared and approved pursuant to subsection (a) of this section. 
(c)  Copies of rules and regulations adopted or approved under this section shall be available at the office of the clerk of the city council and at the office of the cemetery director. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to violate any rule or regulation adopted or approved pursuant to this section. 
(Code 1981, § 8-6) 
Sec. 30-34. - Keeping of areas for burial. 
    The burial ground in the cemetery shall be kept as a place of burial for persons. 
(Code 1981, § 8-7) 
Sec. 30-35. - Division into lots or plots. 
    The cemetery shall be laid off into lots or plots in such manner as the city council may, from time to time, direct. 
(Code 1981, § 8-8) 
Sec. 30-36. - Designation and plan of single-grave portion. 
    The director shall designate a portion of the cemetery which shall be known as the single-grave portion and shall have a plan of such portion made. 
(Code 1981, § 8-9) 
Sec. 30-37. - Information to be furnished by applicant for burial permit. 
    A person applying for a burial permit for burial in the cemetery shall furnish the name of the owner of the lot or plot and the location of the lot or plot. 
(Code 1981, § 8-13) 
Sec. 30-38. - Evidence of burial privilege prerequisite to burial. 
    No burial shall be allowed in the cemetery until satisfactory evidence of the lawful privilege to bury a body has been established. 
(Code 1981, § 8-14) 
Sec. 30-39. - Digging and closing of graves generally. 
    All graves in the cemetery shall be dug and closed by employees of the city under the supervision of the director. 
(Code 1981, § 8-15) 
Sec. 30-40. - Depth of graves. 
    No graves in the cemetery shall be less than five feet deep, except graves for children, which shall be not less than four feet deep. 
(Code 1981, § 8-16) 
Sec. 30-41. - Height of grave mounds. 
    No grave in the cemetery shall have a mound above the grade level after a reasonable time for settling of the dirt has elapsed. 
(Code 1981, § 8-17) 
Sec. 30-42. - Mounds, cradles or other structures in single-grave portion. 
    No mounds, cradles or other structures, other than permanent markers, will be allowed on or around graves in the single-grave portion of the cemetery and any such permanent markers so erected shall not exceed 32 inches in width. 
(Code 1981, § 8-18) 
Sec. 30-43. - Charges for lots or plots, perpetual care or digging graves, interments and other services or work; ordinances not affected. 
(a)  The charges for digging graves, interments, disinterments and other services rendered or work done in the cemetery, or in connection therewith, shall be such as are prescribed, from time to time, by the city council. Such charges shall be paid to the collector of city taxes within 30 days after the service is rendered or the work done. 
(b)  Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect any ordinance prescribing the charges referred to in subsection (a) of this section, the prices of lots or plots or the charges for perpetual care of a lot or plot, and all such ordinances are hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length in this Code. 
(Code 1981, §§ 8-10, 8-19, 8-40; Ord. No. 17-30, 7-11-2017) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to charge for services rendered in connection with cemetery, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1121. 
Sec. 30-44. - Prerequisites to disinterments or reinterments, during certain period of year. 
    No disinterments or reinterments shall be made in the cemetery between May 15 and October 15 of any year, without the consent of the city manager and the approval of the health director. 
(Code 1981, § 8-20) 
Sec. 30-45. - Record of interments, disinterments and reinterments. 
(a)  The director shall register all interments in the cemetery in a book to be kept for the purpose and so arranged as to present, in a convenient tabular form, the name of the deceased, the date of the burial and the location in which the interment is made. The director shall keep this book in the cemetery office, properly indexed and subject at all times to the inspection of the public. 
(b)  The director shall record all disinterments and reinterments at the cemetery in a similar manner to that required for interments by subsection (a) of this section. 
(Code 1981, § 8-21) 
Sec. 30-46. - Work permits generally. 
    No person shall do any work in the cemetery, such as curbing of a lot or setting monuments, headstones, footstones or markers, without having first obtained a permit therefor from the director. No such work shall commence until at least 48 hours have passed after the issuance of the permit required in this article. Such waiting period may be waived by the city manager in exceptional circumstances which require immediate attention. 
(Code 1981, § 8-22) 
Sec. 30-47. - Permit to plant or remove trees or shrubs. 
    No person shall plant any shade tree or large shrub in any lot in the cemetery or remove any tree or large shrub from such a lot, without first obtaining a permit therefor from the director. 
(Code 1981, § 8-23) 
Sec. 30-48. - Permit for trimming trees. 
    No person shall trim, prune or remove any branches from any tree in the cemetery, whether on his lot or plot or not, without having first obtained a permit therefor from the director. 
(Code 1981, § 8-24) 
Sec. 30-49. - Fences prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to erect in or upon any square or section in the cemetery any fence of any kind or character whatsoever. 
(Code 1981, § 8-25) 
Sec. 30-50. - Removal of nuisances. 
(a)  If anything deemed offensive, improper or injurious or which violates any rules shall be deposited or placed on any lot or plot in the cemetery, the director shall remove it without notice. 
(b)  The director may remove from the cemetery any tree, vine, brush or shrub that is unsightly, dangerous or infected with fungi or other pests. 
(Code 1981, § 8-26) 
Cross reference- Nuisances, § 50-61 et seq. 
Secs. 30-51-30-65. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - DIRECTOR 

Sec. 30-66. - Appointment, term and general duties of director. 
(a)  The city manager shall appoint a director of the Blanford Cemetery, whose term of office shall be at the pleasure of the city manager. The director shall devote his whole attention to the preservation, adornment and keeping in order of the cemetery grounds and perform such other duties as are required by this article and as are prescribed by the city manager. The director shall be present at all interments in the cemetery and shall conduct them in the manner prescribed by the city manager. 
(b)  The director shall recommend to the city manager for appointment such employees as he may deem necessary for the operation and maintenance of the cemetery. 
(Code 1981, § 8-3) 
Sec. 30-67. - Obedience to directions of director. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to fail or refuse to obey the lawful directions of the director. 
(Code 1981, § 8-5) 
Sec. 30-68. - Obstructing or hindering director. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to obstruct or hinder the director in the discharge of his duties. 
(Code 1981, § 8-4) 
Secs. 30-69-30-85. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - SALE OF LOTS OR PLOTS 

Sec. 30-86. - Prices. 
    The city shall sell lots or plots in the cemetery at such prices as are prescribed, from time to time, by the city council. 
(Code 1981, § 8-10) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to charge for cemetery lots and burial spaces, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1121. 
Sec. 30-87. - Procedure. 
    Any person desiring to purchase a burial lot or plot, or any part thereof, in the cemetery, shall apply, after due selection, to the director. The director shall issue an invoice, in quintuplet, that states the name and address of the purchaser and the lot or plot to be purchased. One copy of the invoice shall be retained in the cemetery office. The purchaser shall, within two days thereafter, pay the price of such lot or plot to the collector of city taxes, who shall issue a receipt to the purchaser and also, within two days thereafter, shall issue receipts to the cemetery director and to the director of finance. The collector of city taxes shall retain one copy for his office records. A copy of the receipt shall be certified by the director to the clerk of the circuit court, who shall record and properly index the copy in a book to be kept in his office for that purpose, and for public inspection. 
(Code 1981, § 8-11; Ord. No. 17-30, 7-11-2017) 
State Law reference- Records and papers of circuit court open to inspection, Code of Virginia, § 17.1-208. 
Sec. 30-88. - Limitation on sales to same person; transfer from one owner to another; repurchase by city. 
    Not more than one cemetery lot shall be sold to any one person, nor shall any lot or plot be transferred from one owner to another. The city shall repurchase any unoccupied and unused lot at the price originally paid by the purchaser or at 50 percent of the current resident selling price. Any unoccupied lot, from which bodies have been disinterred, shall, subject to the approval of the city manager, be repurchased by the city at 50 percent of the original purchase price. 
(Code 1981, § 8-12) 
Secs. 30-89-30-105. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - PERPETUAL CARE[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Authority of city as to perpetual care of cemetery lots and burial spaces, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1121. 

Subdivision I. - In General 

Sec. 30-106. - Rights of owner after care assumed by city. 
    Nothing in this article shall be construed to affect the right of any person to construct, in conformance with the official cemetery rules and regulations, a curbing of stone or to erect upon his lot or plot in the cemetery any mausoleum, vault, monument, tombstone or marker, after the city has assumed the care thereof under this article, nor the right of access thereto, nor to place flowers on the graves thereon, nor to plant shrubs thereon; provided, however, that if the ground is disturbed in erecting any such structure, the person doing the work shall restore the ground to the same condition as before. 
(Code 1981, § 8-39) 
Sec. 30-107. - Charges to be determined by city council. 
    The charges for perpetual care of a lot or plot or the interior area of a mausoleum in the cemetery shall be determined by the city council. Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect any ordinance establishing such charges and all such ordinances are hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length in this Code. 
(Code 1981, § 8-40) 
Sec. 30-108. - Charges to be paid to the collector of city taxes; receipts for payments. 
    All charges for perpetual care under this article shall be paid to the collector of city taxes, who shall receipt for such charges and give duplicates of such receipts, certified by the director, to the director, the director of finance and the collector of city taxes. The collector of city taxes shall retain one copy of such receipt for his office records. 
(Code 1981, § 8-41; Ord. No. 17-30, 7-11-2017) 
Sec. 30-109. - Disposition of charges paid. 
(a)  All sums which are paid into the city treasury for the purposes of perpetual care of a lot or plot or the interior area of a mausoleum in the cemetery shall be placed to the credit of the board of sinking fund commissioners and shall be invested by them. 
(b)  Annually, or at such times the board of sinking fund commissioners may elect, the income from perpetual care charges shall be credited to the general fund of the city to support cemetery operations. The amount of income from perpetual care shall constitute the city's minimum allowable level of financial support to cemetery operations. 
(Code 1981, § 8-42) 
Secs. 30-110-30-125. - Reserved. 
Subdivision II. - Lots and Plots 

Sec. 30-126. - Notice when care desired. 
    The owner or any other authorized applicant desiring to place his lot or plot in the cemetery under perpetual care shall first give notice in writing to the director. 
(Code 1981, § 8-51) 
Sec. 30-127. - Examination of lot or plot and structures thereon. 
    Upon receipt of a notice provided for in section 30-126, the director shall examine the lot or plot in question and the curbing, mausoleum, vaults, monuments and other stones thereon and any fences around such lot or plot. 
(Code 1981, § 8-52) 
Sec. 30-128. - Acceptance or refusal. 
(a)  If, upon examination under section 30-127, the director finds the subjects of the examination to be in acceptable condition, he shall certify such fact to the applicant and to the collector of city taxes. The payment procedures outlined in section 30-108 shall then be followed. 
(b)  If, upon examination under section 30-127, the director finds the subjects of the examination not in acceptable condition, he shall promptly notify the applicant of his refusal to accept the lot or plot until it is conditioned to apply with cemetery regulations governing perpetual care. When the lot or plot is put in acceptable condition, the director shall certify that fact to the applicant and to the collector of city taxes. The payment procedures outlined in section 30-108 shall then be followed. 
(Code 1981, § 8-53; Ord. No. 17-30, 7-11-2017) 
Sec. 30-129. - Duty of city upon acceptance; limitations on city's responsibilities. 
    When a lot or plot in the cemetery is accepted by the city for perpetual care under this article, it shall be the duty of the city to keep such lot or plot in good order, free from undergrowth and to keep the grass cut and the monuments or stones upright, so long as such monuments or stones continue intact. The city will not be responsible for keeping alive any flowers, ivy, moss, shrubs or grass on a lot or plot. Grass will be planted only on new graves. Furthermore, the city will not be responsible for damage to stones or curbing or for results of vandalism. 
(Code 1981, § 8-54) 
Sec. 30-130. - Metal plate indicating perpetual care. 
    On each burial lot or plot in the cemetery placed under perpetual care pursuant to this article, a metal plate indicating the fact shall be attached in some substantial way, by and at the cost of the city. 
(Code 1981, § 8-55) 
Sec. 30-131. - Hedges prohibited. 
    No hedge will be permitted around a lot or plot in the cemetery under perpetual care pursuant to this article. 
(Code 1981, § 8-56) 
Sec. 30-132. - Mound graves prohibited. 
    No mound graves shall be allowed on any lot or plot in the cemetery under perpetual care pursuant to this article. 
(Code 1981, § 8-57) 
Secs. 30-133-30-150. - Reserved. 
Subdivision III. - Interior Areas of Mausoleums 

Sec. 30-151. - Notice when care desired. 
    The owner of a lot in the cemetery, or any other authorized applicant, on whose lot there is a mausoleum and who desires to place the interior area of such mausoleum under perpetual care, shall after first having had his lot accepted by the city for perpetual care under this article, give notice in writing to the director. 
(Code 1981, § 8-69) 
Sec. 30-152. - Examination of mausoleum. 
    Upon receipt of a notice provided for in section 30-151, the director shall examine the mausoleum in question. 
(Code 1981, § 8-70) 
Sec. 30-153. - Acceptance or refusal. 
(a)  If, upon examination under section 30-152, the director finds the mausoleum in question to be in acceptable condition, he shall certify such fact to the collector of city taxes and to the applicant. The payment procedures outlined in section 30-108 shall then be followed. 
(b)  If, upon examination under section 30-152, the director finds the mausoleum in question not to be in acceptable condition, the director shall promptly notify the applicant of his refusal to accept the mausoleum for perpetual care in its present condition. 
(Code 1981, § 8-71; Ord. No. 17-30, 7-11-2017) 
Sec. 30-154. - Duty of city upon acceptance; delivery of key; repairs. 
    When the interior of the mausoleum is accepted by the city for perpetual care under this article, it shall be the duty of the city to keep such area clean. The owner or authorized applicant shall deliver to the director a key to the mausoleum. Nothing contained in this section shall be construed as requiring the city to make repairs to any mausoleum. 
(Code 1981, § 8-72) 
Chapter 34 - CHARITABLE AND RELIGIOUS SOLICITATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 26. 
State Law reference- Solicitation of contributions, Code of Virginia, § 57-48 et seq.; local ordinances, Code of Virginia, § 57-63. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 34-1. - Definitions. 
    Whenever used in this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively given them in this section, unless a different meaning clearly appears from the context: 
    Charitable means and shall include the words philanthropic, social services or welfare, either actual or purported. 
    Contribution means any gift, bequest, devise or other grant of any money, credit, financial assistance or property of any kind or value, including the promise to contribute, except payments by the membership of an organization for membership fees, dues, fines, or assessments, or for services rendered to individual members, and except money, credit, financial assistance or property received from any governmental authority. The term "contribution" shall not include any donation of blood or any gift made pursuant to Code of Virginia, § 32.1-289 et seq. 
    Person means any individual, organization, trust, foundation, association, partnership, corporation, society, or other group or combination acting as a unit. 
    Promoter means any person who promotes, manages, supervises, organizes or attempts to promote, manage, supervise or organize a campaign of solicitation. 
    Religious and religion shall not mean and include the word "charitable," but shall be given their commonly accepted definitions. 
    Solicit and solicitation mean the request or appeal, directly or indirectly, for any contribution on the plea or representation that such contribution will be used for a charitable purpose, including, without limitation, the following methods of requesting such contribution: 
(1)  Any oral or written request; 
(2)  Any announcement to the press, over the radio or television, or by telephone or telegraph concerning an appeal or campaign to which the public is requested to make a contribution for any charitable purpose connected therewith; 
(3)  The distribution, circulation, posting or publishing of any handbill, written advertisement or other publication which directly or by implication seeks to obtain public support; or 
(4)  The sale of, offer or attempt to sell, any advertisement, advertising space, subscription, ticket, or any service or tangible item in connection with which any appeal is made for any charitable purpose or where the name of any charitable or civic organization is used or referred to in any such appeal as an inducement or reason for making any such sale, or when or where in connection with any such sale, any statement is made that the whole or any part of the proceeds from any such sale will be donated to any charitable purpose. 
Solicitation shall be deemed to occur when the request is made, at the place the request is received, whether or not the person making the request actually receives any contribution. 
(Code 1981, § 29-1) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 57-48. 
Sec. 34-2. - Violations of chapter. 
    Any person who willfully and knowingly violates or causes to be violated any provision of this chapter, or who willfully and knowingly gives false or incorrect information to the city in filing statements or reports required by this chapter, whether such report or statement is verified or not, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished for the first offense by a fine of not less than $100.00 and not more than $1,000.00 or by confinement in jail for not more than six months, or both, and for the second and any subsequent offense by a fine of not less than $500.00 and not more than $2,500.00 or by confinement in jail for not more than one year, or both. 
(Code 1981, § 29-2) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 57-59. 
Sec. 34-3. - Exemptions. 
    Any provision of this chapter from which any person is exempted by law shall not apply to such person. 
Sec. 34-4. - Misrepresentations, deception or fraud in soliciting or in applications or reports under chapter. 
    No person shall, directly or indirectly, solicit contributions for any purpose by misrepresentation of his name, occupation, financial condition, social condition or residence, and no person shall make or perpetrate any other misstatement, deception or fraud in connection with any solicitation of any contribution for any purpose in the city, or in any application or report filed under this chapter. 
(Code 1981, § 29-3) 
Sec. 34-5. - Investigation of solicitors' affairs. 
(a)  The chief of police is authorized to investigate the affairs of any person soliciting for charitable or religious purposes within the city, whether or not such person has or is required to have a permit or certificate under this chapter, and make public his written findings in order that the public may be fully informed as to the affairs of any of such person. Such person shall make available to the chief of police, or to any representative designated by the chief of police in writing for such specific purpose, all books, records or other information reasonably necessary to enable the chief of police to fully and fairly inform the public of all facts necessary to a full understanding by the public of the work and methods of operation of such person. 
(b)  Five days before the public release of any findings under this section, the chief of police shall serve a copy of such findings upon the person investigated and, at the time of the release of his findings, he shall release a copy of any written statement such person may file with him in explanation, denial or confirmation of such findings. 
(Code 1981, § 29-4) 
Secs. 34-6-34-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CHARITABLE SOLICITATIONS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 34-31. - Records to be kept. 
    No person shall solicit any contributions for any charitable purpose without maintaining a system of accounting whereby all donations and all disbursements are entered upon the books or records of such person's treasurer or other financial officer. 
(Code 1981, § 29-16) 
Sec. 34-32. - Reports. 
    It shall be the duty of all persons issued permits under this article to furnish to the chief of police, within 60 days after the solicitation has been completed, a detailed report and financial statement showing the amount raised by the solicitation, the amount expended in collecting such funds, including a detailed report of the wages, fees, commissions and expenses paid to any person in connection with such solicitation, and the disposition of the balance of the funds collected by the solicitation. This report shall be available for public inspection at the office of the chief of police. The permit holder shall make available to the chief of police, or to any person designated in writing by the chief of police, as his representative for such purpose, all books, records and papers whereby the accuracy of such report may be checked. 
(Code 1981, § 29-17) 
Secs. 34-33-34-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 34-51. - Required; exceptions. 
(a)  No person shall solicit contributions for any charitable purpose within the city without a permit from the chief of police authorizing such solicitation; provided, that the provisions of this section shall not apply to any established organization or other entity organized and operated wholly or partially for religious or charitable purposes and not operated for the pecuniary profit of any person, if the solicitations by such established organization or other entity are conducted only among the members thereof by other members or officers thereof, voluntarily and without remuneration for making such solicitations, or if the solicitations are in the form of collections or contributions at the regular assemblies or services of such established organization or other entity. 
(b)  When a permit has been issued under this division to other than an individual, then the individual agents and solicitors for the permit holder shall not be required to obtain individual permits. 
(Code 1981, § 29-29) 
Sec. 34-52. - Application generally. 
(a)  An application for a permit required by this division shall be made to the chief of police upon forms prescribed by him. Such application shall be sworn to or affirmed and filed with the chief of police at least 15 days prior to the time at which the permit applied for shall become effective. Such application shall contain the following information or, in lieu thereof, a statement satisfactory to the chief of police of the reasons why such information or any item thereof is not furnished: 
(1)  A financial statement for the last preceding fiscal year of any funds collected for charitable purposes by the applicant, such statement giving the amount of money so raised, together with the cost of raising it, and final distribution thereof. 
(2)  A full statement of the general character and extent of the charitable work being done or to be done by the applicant, and showing how much thereof is being done or is to be done within the city. 
(3)  A statement that the actual cost of the solicitation will not exceed 25 percent of the total amount to be raised, or if the cost of solicitation is expected to exceed 25 percent, a statement of what the maximum cost is expected to be, together with a statement of any special facts tending to show that there are peculiar reasons which make a cost higher than 25 percent reasonable in the particular case. 
(4)  A statement to the effect that, if a permit is granted, it will not be used or represented in any way as an endorsement by the city or by any department or officer thereof. 
(5)  A statement to the effect that, if a permit is granted, no person under the age of 16 years will be permitted to solicit money. 
(b)  If, while any application filed pursuant to this section is pending, or during the term of any permit granted thereon, there is any change in fact, policy or method that would alter the information given in the application, the applicant shall notify the chief of police, in writing, thereof within 24 hours after such change. 
(Code 1981, § 29-30(a)(1)-(5), (b)) 
Sec. 34-53. - Investigation of applicant and application; inspection of applicant's records. 
    The chief of police shall examine all applications filed under this division and shall make, or cause to be made, such further investigation of the application and the applicant as he shall deem necessary in order for him to perform his duties under this division. Upon request by the chief of police, the applicant shall make available for inspection by the chief of police, or any person designated in writing by the chief of police as his representative for such purpose, all of the applicant's books, records and papers at any reasonable time before the application is granted. 
(Code 1981, § 29-31) 
Sec. 34-54. - Fee. 
    No application for a permit required under this division shall be accepted or considered by the chief of police unless the person applying for the permit pays to the city a fee of $10.00 to aid in defraying the cost involved in considering the application for the permit and taking action with respect thereto, which fee shall not be refunded. 
(Code 1981, § 29-32) 
Sec. 34-55. - Issuance or denial. 
(a)  The chief of police shall issue a permit applied for under this division whenever he shall find the following facts to exist: 
(1)  The fee required by section 34-54 has been paid. 
(2)  All of the statements made in the application are true. 
(3)  The applicant, or if the applicant is not an individual person, that its managing officers and managing agents, is or are of good character and reputation for honesty and integrity. 
(4)  The control and supervision of the solicitation will be under responsible and reliable persons. 
(5)  The applicant has not engaged in any fraudulent transaction or enterprise. 
(6)  The solicitation will not be a fraud on the public. 
(7)  The solicitation is prompted solely by a desire to finance the charitable cause described in the application, and will not be conducted primarily for private profit. 
(8)  The cost of raising the funds will be reasonable. Any such cost in excess of 25 percent of the amount collected shall be considered to be unreasonable, unless special facts are presented showing to the satisfaction of the chief of police that peculiar reasons make a cost higher then 25 percent reasonable in the particular case. 
(9)  The kind, character and method of the proposed solicitation, the time when it will take place and its duration are such that the solicitation will be in the interest of and not inimical to the safety, convenience or welfare of the inhabitants of the city. 
(b)  The chief of police shall file in his office for public inspection a written statement of his findings of fact and his decisions upon each application. If the application is denied, the chief of police shall notify the applicant, by registered mail at the address given in the application, stating the reasons therefor. 
(Code 1981, § 29-33) 
Sec. 34-56. - Contents. 
    A permit issued under this division shall bear the name and address of the person to whom it is issued, the number of the permit, the date issued, the dates within which the permit holder may solicit and a statement that the permit does not constitute an endorsement by the city, or by any of its departments, officers or employees, of the purpose or of the person conducting the solicitation. All such permits shall be signed by the chief of police. 
(Code 1981, § 29-34) 
Sec. 34-57. - Term; renewal. 
    At the discretion of the chief of police, a permit issued under this division shall grant the right to solicit on one or more single, nonconsecutive days in any calendar year or the right to solicit for any number of consecutive days not to exceed one year from the date of the permit. Upon the expiration of any permit of the kind last mentioned, and if requested in writing to do so, the chief of police may renew the permit, if he is satisfied that the requirements of this article are still being met and that no violation of this article has been committed. The chief of police may, in his discretion, require a new application, and his action upon such new application shall be governed by the same standards as to granting or withholding the permit as in the case of an original application. No new permit or renewal of an original permit shall be issued for more than one year. 
(Code 1981, § 29-35) 
Sec. 34-58. - Transfer. 
    Any permit issued under this division shall be nontransferable. 
(Code 1981, § 29-36) 
Sec. 34-59. - Suspension or revocation. 
(a)  Whenever it shall be shown, or whenever the chief of police has reason to believe, that any person to whom a permit has been issued under this division has violated any of the provisions of this article, or that any promoter, agent or solicitor of a permit holder has misrepresented the purpose of the solicitation, the chief of police shall immediately suspend the permit and give the permit holder written notice, in person or by registered, special delivery mail, of the suspension and of a hearing to be held within two days of such suspension to determine whether or not the permit should be revoked. The notice shall contain a statement of the facts upon which the chief of police has acted in suspending the permit. 
(b)  At the hearing referred to in subsection (a) of this section, the permit holder and any other interested person shall have the right to present evidence as to the facts upon which the chief of police based the suspension of the permit and any other facts which may aid the chief of police in determining whether this article has been violated or whether the purpose of the solicitation has been misrepresented. If, after such hearing, the chief of police finds that this article has been violated or the purpose of the solicitation has been misrepresented, he shall, within two days after the hearing, file in his office for public inspection and send to the permit holder by registered mail, or serve upon him in any manner provided by general law for the service of notices, a written statement of the facts upon which he bases such a finding and shall immediately revoke the permit. If, after such hearing, the chief of police finds that this article has not been violated and the purpose of the solicitation has not been misrepresented, he shall, within two days after the hearing, give to the permit holder a written statement cancelling the suspension of the permit and stating that no violation or misrepresentation was found to have been committed. 
(Code 1981, § 29-37) 
Secs. 34-60-34-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - RELIGIOUS SOLICITATIONS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 34-81-34-95. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CERTIFICATE OF REGISTRATION 

Sec. 34-96. - Required; exceptions. 
(a)  No person shall solicit contributions for any religious purpose within the city without a certificate of registration from the chief of police authorizing such solicitation; provided, that the provisions of this section shall not apply to any established organization or other entity organized and operated exclusively for religious purposes and not operated for the pecuniary benefit of any person, if the solicitations by such established organization or other entity are conducted only among the members thereof by other members or officers thereof, voluntarily and without remuneration for making such solicitations, or the solicitations are in the form of collections or contributions at the regular assemblies or services of such established organization or other entity. 
(b)  When a certificate has been issued under this division to other than an individual, then the individual agents and solicitors for the certificate holder shall not be required to obtain individual certificates. 
(Code 1981, § 29-61) 
Sec. 34-97. - Application. 
(a)  An application for a certificate required by this division shall be made to the chief of police upon forms prescribed by him. Such application shall be sworn to or affirmed and shall contain the following information or, in lieu thereof, a statement satisfactory to the chief of police of the reasons why such information or any item thereof is not furnished: 
(1)  A financial statement for the last preceding fiscal year of any funds collected for religious purposes by the applicant, such statement giving the amount of money so raised, together with the cost of raising it and the final distribution thereof. 
(2)  A full statement of the general character and extent of the religious work being done or to be done by the applicant and also the character and extent of such work being done or to be done within the city. 
(3)  A statement to the effect that, if a certificate is granted, it will not be used or represented in any way as an endorsement by the city or by any department or officer thereof. 
(4)  A statement to the effect that, if a certificate is granted, no person under the age of 16 years will be permitted to solicit money. 
(5)  Such other information as may be submitted to the chief of police in order for him to determine the kind and character of the proposed solicitation. 
(b)  If, while any application filed under this section is pending, or during the term of any certificate granted thereon, there is any change in fact, policy or method that would alter the information given in the application, the applicant shall notify the chief of police, in writing, thereof within 24 hours after such change. 
(Code 1981, § 29-62) 
Sec. 34-98. - Fee. 
    No application for a certificate under this division shall be accepted or considered by the chief of police, unless the person applying for the certificate pays to the city a fee of $4.00 to aid in defraying the cost involved in considering the application for the certificate and taking action with respect thereto, which fee shall not be refunded. 
(Code 1981, § 29-63) 
Sec. 34-99. - Issuance. 
    Upon receipt of an application for a certificate under this division and payment of the prescribed fee, the chief of police shall forthwith issue such certificate to the applicant. 
(Code 1981, § 29-64) 
Sec. 34-100. - Contents. 
    A certificate of registration issued under this division shall bear the name and address of the person by whom the solicitation is to be made, the number of the certificate, the date issued and a statement that the certificate does not constitute an endorsement by the city, or by any of its departments or officers, of the purpose of the solicitation or of the person conducting the solicitation. 
(Code 1981, § 29-65) 
Sec. 34-101. - Term; renewal. 
    A certificate issued under this division shall remain in force and effect for a period of one year after the issuance thereof and shall be renewed upon the expiration of such period upon the filing of a request in writing, but the chief of police may require a new application. 
(Code 1981, § 29-66) 
Chapter 35 - SOLICITATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Restrictions on aggressive solicitation, ch. 36. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 35-1. - Purpose. 
    The purposes of the solicitation restrictions imposed under this article are to: 
(a)  Reduce the detrimental effect that threatening and intimidating conduct has on a safe environment in the city; and 
(b)  Restrict solicitation in certain places where citizens feel vulnerable to criminal activity, without prohibiting constitutionally protected activity; 
(c)  Restrict solicitation after dark, when citizens feel vulnerable to criminal activity, without prohibiting constitutionally protected activity; 
(d)  Reduce the detrimental effect that solicitation has on tourism and retail business. 
(Ord. No. 13-37, § 1, 5-21-2013) 
Sec. 35-2. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Beg, panhandle or solicit means any request made in person for donations, contributions, employment, business, sales or exchanges of any kind either by words, bodily gestures, signs or other means, from another person. 
    Public place means any street, sidewalk, bridge, alley, alleyway, plaza, park, public grounds, public driveway, public parking lot, public transportation facility, or inside a motor vehicle in or on any such place. 
    Traveled portion of a roadway means any portion of a roadway that is normally used by a moving motor vehicle or that is not a lawful parking area. 
(Ord. No. 13-37, § 1, 5-21-2013) 
Sec. 35-3. - Offense. 
(a)  No person shall solicit, ask, or beg in the following public places: 
(1)  Within 50 feet in any direction of any entrance or exit of any bank during the hours of operation of such bank; 
(2)  Within 50 feet in any direction of any automated teller machine; 
(3)  Within 20 feet in any direction of any outdoor or sidewalk café or restaurant during the hours of operation of such outdoor or sidewalk café or restaurant; and 
(4)  Within 20 feet in any direction of any package store or food store that sells alcohol during the hours of operation of such package store or food store; 
(5)  On the traveled portion of any street, roadway or road; 
(6)  The intersection while walking on, standing on or going into any street or highway used for motor vehicle travel, or any area appurtenant thereto (including medians, sidewalks, shoulder areas, turning lanes, ramps and exit ramps) within 50 feet (in any direction) of any of the following intersections, ramps, and exit ramps: 
a.  Exit 52 ramp from I-95 to East Washington Street; 
b.  Graham Road at I-95 off Ramp; 
c.  The intersection of Graham Road and Crater Road; 
d.  The intersection of Wagner Road and Crater Road; 
e.  The intersection of Sycamore Street and Bank Street; 
f.  The intersection of Crater Circle and Crater Road; 
g.  The intersection of Wythe Street and Sycamore Street; 
h.  The intersection of Washington and Sycamore Street; and 
i.  The intersection of Washington and Union Street. 
(7)  Within any public vehicle, facility or place. 
(b)  No person shall solicit, ask, or beg in a public place after sunset or before sunrise. However, passive solicitation is permitted at any time except within the areas listed in this section or as otherwise prohibited by law; provided such activity does not create a public safety issue. 
(Ord. No. 13-37, § 1, 5-21-2013; Ord. No. 14-82, 9-2-2014) 
State Law reference- Localities may prohibit or regulate distribution of handbills, etc., solicitation of contributions, and sale of merchandise or services on highways within their boundaries or on public roadways and medians, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-931. 
Sec. 35-4. - Permitted conduct. 
    Acts authorized as an exercise of a person's constitutional right to picket, protest, or speak and acts authorized by a permit issued by the city shall not constitute unlawful activity under this article. 
(Ord. No. 13-37, § 1, 5-21-2013) 
Sec. 35-5. - Penalty. 
    Any person, upon conviction of an offense charged under this article, shall be guilty of a class 4 misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 13-37, § 1, 5-21-2013) 
Chapter 36 - RESTRICTIONS ON AGGRESSIVE SOLICITATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Solicitation, ch. 35. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 36-1. - Purpose. 
    The purposes of the aggressive solicitation restrictions imposed under this article are to: 
(a)  Reduce the detrimental effect that threatening and intimidating conduct has on a safe environment in the city; 
(b)  Restrict certain aggressive acts of solicitors without prohibiting constitutionally protected activity; and 
(c)  Maintain the peace and order of the city and preserve and protect the rights of all citizens to be free of intimidation. 
(Ord. No. 13-37, § 3, 5-21-2013) 
Sec. 36-2. - Offense. 
    No person shall solicit, ask, or beg in an aggressive manner in any public place. 
(Ord. No. 13-37, § 3, 5-21-2013) 
Sec. 36-3. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Aggressive manner means intentionally or recklessly: 
(a)  Touching or causing physical contact with another person without that person's consent in the course of soliciting, asking, or begging; 
(b)  Blocking the safe or free passage of a pedestrian or vehicle by any means, including unreasonable causing a pedestrian or vehicle operator to take evasive action to avoid physical contact in the course of soliciting, asking, or begging; or 
(c)  Using violent, obscene, or threatening gestures or language toward a person solicited, if such conduct is intended to or is likely to cause a reasonable person to fear bodily harm to oneself, or the commission of a criminal act upon the person or upon property in the person's immediate possession or otherwise be intimidated into giving money or other thing of value or buying merchandise. 
    Public place means any street, sidewalk, bridge, alley, alleyway, plaza, park, public grounds, public driveway, public parking lot, public transportation facility, or inside a motor vehicle in or on any such place. 
    Solicit, ask or beg means using the spoken, written, or printed work or bodily gestures, signs or other means with the purpose of obtaining an immediate donation of money or other thing of value or soliciting the sale of goods or services regardless of the solicitor's purpose or intended use of the money or other thing of value. 
(Ord. No. 13-37, § 3, 5-21-2013) 
Sec. 36-4. - Permitted conduct. 
    Acts authorized as an exercise of a person's constitutional right to picket, protest, or speak and acts authorized by a permit issued by the city shall not constitute unlawful activity under this article; nor does aggressive solicitation include solicitation without engaging in the acts specifically prohibited in this article. 
(Ord. No. 13-37, § 3, 5-21-2013) 
Sec. 36-5. - Penalty. 
    Any person, upon conviction of an offense charged under this article, shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 13-37, § 3, 5-21-2013)

ARTICLE III. - URBAN ENTERPRISE ZONE 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 38-61. - Statement of purpose. 
    In accordance with Code of Virginia, § 59.1-270 et seq., and the resultant declaration of the governor of the commonwealth designating a portion of the city as an urban enterprise zone, it is the purpose of this article to stimulate business and industrial growth within the area designated as the Petersburg Urban Enterprise Zone by means of tax incentives, fee exemptions, governmental programs and other initiatives established to promote such growth. 
(Code 1981, § 36.1-2) 
Sec. 38-62. - Boundaries established. 
    The boundaries of the Petersburg Urban Enterprise Zone are as follows: 
    Beginning at the intersection of the northern city limits of the City of Petersburg and Interstate 95; thence southwardly along the centerline of I-95 to the south bank of the original channel of the Appomattox River; thence along the said south bank in an easterly direction to Poor Creek; thence along Poor Creek to East Bank Street; thence eastwardly along the centerline of East Bank Street to a point which is the intersection of East Bank Street with the northern projection of Patrick Street; thence southwardly along the said northern projection of Patrick Street and along the centerline of Patrick Street to Nottoway Street; thence westwardly along Nottoway Street to Accomack Street; thence southwardly along Accomack Street to Wythe Street; thence westwardly along Wythe Street to I-95; thence southwardly along the centerline of I-95 to its intersection with the eastward projection of the centerline of Surry Lane; thence westwardly along the projected and actual centerline of Surry Lane to South Sycamore Street; thence southwardly along the centerline of South Sycamore Street to Shore Street; thence westwardly along the centerline of Shore Street to Halifax Street; thence northwardly along the centerline of Halifax Street to Independence Street; thence westwardly along the centerline of Independence Street to South Jones Street; thence northwardly along the centerline of South Jones Street to Lee Avenue; thence westwardly along the centerline of Lee Avenue to South Street; thence northwardly along the centerline of South Street to West High Street; thence westwardly along the centerline of West High Street to its intersection with the abandoned right-of-way of the Seaboard Coast Line Railway; thence northwardly along the centerline of said right-of-way to the Appomattox River, said river being the northern city limits of the City of Petersburg, Virginia; thence along the northern city limits to the point of beginning. 
(Code 1981, § 36.1-3) 
Sec. 38-63. - Rules and regulations. 
    Rules and regulations prescribing procedures effectuating the purpose of this chapter shall be promulgated by the city manager and approved by the city council. 
(Code 1981, § 36.1-8) 
Secs. 38-64-38-80. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - EXEMPTIONS 

Sec. 38-81. - Business taxes. 
    Notwithstanding the provisions of chapter 26 of this Code, businesses, trades, professions, occupations and callings located or locating within the Petersburg Urban Enterprise Zone that are designated as qualified business firms by the state department of housing and community development in accordance with Code of Virginia, § 59.1-279, are exempt from the payment of local license taxes. Such exemptions shall extend for a maximum of five calendar years and shall be coextensive with the years for which state tax credits are received in accordance with Code of Virginia, § 59.1-280. 
(Code 1981, § 36.1-4) 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 26; taxation, ch. 106. 
Sec. 38-82. - Building permit fees, zoning filing fees, and land disturbing permit fees. 
    Any business firm located or locating within the Petersburg Urban Enterprise Zone designated as a qualified business firm by the state department of housing and community development in accordance with Code of Virginia, § 59.1-279, is exempted from all building permit fees, zoning filing fees, and land disturbing permit fees, not withstanding the provisions of chapter 22, chapter 50, article IV, and the zoning ordinance, respectively. 
(Code 1981, § 36.1-5) 
Editor's note- The zoning ordinance is on file in the office of the clerk of the council. 
Sec. 38-83. - Water and sewer fees. 
    Any business firm located or locating within the Petersburg Urban Enterprise Zone designated as a qualified business firm by the state department of housing and community development in accordance with Code of Virginia, § 59.1-279, is exempted from all sewer and water connection fees, notwithstanding the provisions of section 114-68 and section 114-204, respectively. 
(Code 1981, § 36.1-6) 
Sec. 38-84. - Retail sales tax. 
    Notwithstanding the provisions of chapter 106, article IV of this Code, any business firm located or locating within the Petersburg Urban Enterprise Zone designated as a qualified business firm by the state department of housing and community development in accordance with Code of Virginia, § 59.1-279, is exempted from the payment of the local one percent sales tax for all items purchased for the conduct of its business. Such exemption shall extend for a period not to exceed five years and shall be coextensive with the years for which the state sales tax is exempted in accordance with Code of Virginia, § 59.1-282. 
(Code 1981, § 36.1-7) 
Secs. 38-85-38-89. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - I-95 TECHNOLOGY ZONE 

Sec. 38-90. - Purpose. 
    The city council finds that certain classes of high technology business activities have special economic significance to the city due to the nature of the technology and their potential for high growth in employment and capital investment. The city council further finds that the most appropriate method of encouraging location of new businesses and the expansion of certain existing classes of technology businesses is to create a technology zone with particular boundaries as designated herein and located on the east side of Interstate 95, and as authorized by the 1950 Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3850, as amended. The city council has determined that the establishment of this technology zone will improve economic conditions, hasten redevelopment, and benefit the welfare of its citizens. 
(Ord. No. 03-52, 7-15-2003) 
Sec. 38-91. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the following meanings, unless clearly indicated to the contrary: 
    Base assessed value. The term "base assessed value" shall be defined as the assessed value of machinery and tools within a local enterprise zone as shown upon the records of the commissioner of the revenue on January 1 of the year preceding the effective date of the ordinance establishing the local technology zone development taxation. 
    Current assessed value. The term "current assessed value" shall be defined as the annual assessed value of machinery and tools in a local technology zone as shown upon the records of the commissioner of the revenue. 
    Definite place of business. The term "definite place of business" shall be defined as an office or a location at which occurs a regular and continuous course of dealing over a period of 30 consecutive days or more. A definite place of business for a person engaged in business may include a location leased or otherwise obtained from another person and real property leased to another. A definite place of business may include several facilities operated by the same person, as long as each facility will be located within the boundaries of a qualified technology zone. 
    New equipment. The term "new equipment" is defined as items of equipment subject to machinery and tools taxes that are brought on to the definite place of business within a five-year period, commencing on the first tax day following the date on which each item of property is first brought on to the site. 
    Qualified technology. The term "qualified technology" shall mean the research and development, manufacturing and/or production of any of the following: 
(1)  Pharmaceutical ingredients or advanced intermediaries; or 
(2)  Synthetic and organic chemical compounds for use in biotechnology or the production of pharmaceuticals. 
    Qualified technology business. The term "qualified technology business" shall be defined as a new or existing business that has a "definite place of business" as defined in paragraph (c) of this section, within a "qualified technology zone" as defined in paragraph (g) of this section, and which is primarily engaged in a qualified technology, as defined in paragraph (e) of this section. 
    Qualified technology zone. The term "qualified technology zone" shall mean the I-95 Technology Zone as described in section 38-98 of this article. 
(Ord. No. 03-52, 7-15-2003) 
Sec. 38-92. - Authorization. 
    There is hereby established a Technology Zone Taxation Program in the City of Petersburg. 
(Ord. No. 03-52, 7-15-2003) 
Sec. 38-93. - Technology zone incentives. 
    Qualified technology businesses shall receive the following: 
(1)  Capital investment grants: There is hereby established a grant provided to qualified technology businesses. The grant will be allocated by the industrial development authority of the city and will be based on the new or qualifying existing equipment within the technology zone. Each annual installment of the capital investment grant will be calculated based on the machinery and tools taxes paid by a qualified technology business on such new equipment in that calendar year. The grant, as further defined and limited by this article, will be equal to 100 percent of the machinery and tools taxes paid in years one through five attributable to such new or qualifying existing equipment and allocated to the local enterprise zone development fund. 
(2)  The capital investment grant shall be paid annually in each year that the qualified technology business has such new equipment. In furtherance of the foregoing, the five-year grant period shall apply separately to each and every item of such new equipment, such that a qualified technology business may receive the grant on a rolling basis for each year in which it has such new equipment. Accordingly, a qualified technology business shall be permitted to receive a capital investment grant for multiple years. 
(3)  The first year for which such incentives are calculated shall be the calendar year of the first machinery and tools tax filing for the calendar year in which a business firm is first certified as a qualified technology business. 
(4)  Taxes paid on leased items shall be eligible for the capital investment grant incentives only when the grant recipient directly pays to the City of Petersburg applicable machinery and tools taxes for those items. 
(Ord. No. 03-52, 7-15-2003; Ord. No. 14-101, 10-21-2014) 
Sec 38-94. - Procedure. 
(a)  A business firm seeking to obtain the benefits provided under the technology zone program must make an initial filing to the city manager on applications provided by the commissioner of the revenue for certification as a qualified technology business. The city manager shall certify to the commissioner of the revenue those businesses that qualify. By January 31 of each calendar year, the commissioner of the revenue shall send applications to each previously certified business. 
(b)  Applications from qualified businesses for the capital investment grant shall contain information on machinery and tools taxes paid on new equipment. All applications shall be submitted on an annual basis to the commissioner of the revenue at the same time of the filing of the machinery and tools tax returns for that year in order to receive the grant. Applications will be processed within 60 days of the submission. Qualified technology businesses shall retain eligibility for technology zone incentives in subsequent calendar years. 
(c)  The commissioner of the revenue shall record in the appropriate books both the base assessed value and the current assessed value of machinery and tools in the local technology zone. 
(d)  Machinery and tools taxes attributable to the lower of the current assessed value or base assessed value of machinery and tools located in the local technology zone shall be allocated by the treasurer as they would be in the absence of this article. 
(e)  All of the increase in machinery and tools taxes paid attributable to the difference between (i) the current assessed value and (ii) the base assessed value shall be allocated by the treasurer and paid into a special fund entitled the "Local Enterprise Zone Development Fund." Such amounts paid into the fund shall be limited so as not to include any revenues resulting from machinery and tools taxes paid on other than new equipment as defined by this article. Such allocation shall be accomplished within 30 days after receipt of machinery and tools taxes from the qualified business. 
(f)  Grants shall be allocated, by the Petersburg Industrial Development Authority, to qualified businesses in accordance with this article from grants made to the authority by the city from the Technology Zone Development Fund. Such grants shall be allocated to the qualified business within 30 days after receipt of the funds from the city. 
(Ord. No. 03-52, 7-15-2003) 
Sec. 38-95. - Compliance. 
(a)  Once qualified as a qualified technology business, a business shall be entitled to file for a capital investment grant in each subsequent year unless it no longer engages in a qualified technology at a definite place of business in the qualified technology zone. 
(b)  If a business ceases to be a qualified technology business during a calendar tax year in which the grant program applies, any payments made to the qualified technology business shall be prorated for the months the business was a qualified technology business. 
(Ord. No. 03-52, 7-15-2003) 
Sec. 38-96. - Confidentiality. 
    To the extent permitted under the Virginia Freedom of Information Act, confidential business records shall be safeguarded from disclosure. The technology zone administrator may establish verification procedures with the commissioner of the revenue for the city, which will ensure that all required taxes have been paid, but that all privacy concerns and rights are protected. 
(Ord. No. 03-52, 7-15-2003) 
Sec. 38-97. - Effective date. 
    This article shall be effective on October 21, 2014, and shall expire no later than January 1, 2020. Notwithstanding the foregoing, five-year grant periods, commenced for new equipment acquired prior to the termination of the technology zone, shall continue for the remainder of the five-year periods, and the technology zone shall extend for that purpose subject to the terms outlined herein. 
(Ord. No. 03-52, 7-15-2003; Ord. No. 14-101, 10-21-2014) 
Sec. 38-98. - I-95 Technology Zone. 
    The I-95 Technology Zone shall consist of all that tract of land located in the City of Petersburg, Virginia, containing 197.033 acres located on the east side of Interstate 95 and on the north side of Wagner Road, further identified as Tax Map Parcel 063-01-001, reference to said Tax Map Parcel which is made by this section and incorporated herein. 
(Ord. No. 03-52, 7-15-2003) 
Secs. 38-99-38-104. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - ARTS AND CULTURAL DISTRICT 

Sec. 38-105. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, the words and phrases set out in this section shall have the following meanings: 
    Appeals committee means a group consisting of five individuals, appointed by council, established to review decisions made by the district administrator, hear appeals from those decisions, and provide guidance as to the overall administration of the district. 
    District means the Petersburg Arts and Cultural District established pursuant to this article. 
    Qualified arts organization means a business or not-for-profit organization physically located within the district which, has as its primary mission to expose, educate and enlighten the public with cultural and creative activities in the areas of the visual arts, performing arts, and literary arts. Examples may include, but are not limited to, theatres, art galleries, museums, and dance studios. 
    Resident means any individual or entity occupying a business structure or personal residence located within the district. 
(Ord. No. 08-26, § 1, 3-4-2008) 
Sec. 38-106. - Purpose. 
    The city finds that the continued development and success of its arts and cultural venues require incentives, and determines that the most appropriate method of offering incentives for the area described in section 38-108 is to create an arts and cultural district in that area, as authorized by Code of Virginia § 15.2-1129.1. The city believes that the establishment of an arts and cultural district will improve the economic conditions of this geographic area which could, in turn, benefit the welfare of the citizens of Petersburg. 
(Ord. No. 08-26, § 1, 3-4-2008) 
Sec. 38-107. - Administration. 
(a)  The district administrator shall be the city manager or his designee. The administrator shall establish the procedures for administration of this article, including, but not limited to: (i) the processes by which entities are designated as qualified arts organizations; (ii) the processes by which issues regarding the establishment and amendment of district boundaries are resolved; and (iii) the processes by which qualified arts organizations may obtain the benefits established pursuant to this article. 
(b)  Council may appoint up to five people to an appeals committee that may perform various tasks relating to the fair and effective administration of the district, including, but not limited to: (i) reviewing decisions made by the administrator; (ii) hearing appeals of those decisions; and (iii) providing guidance to the administrator, at his request or at the request of district residents, as to the overall administration of the district. At least one member shall be a representative of the Southside Virginia Council of the Arts, one shall be a representative of the Petersburg Chamber of Commerce, one shall be a representative of the Olde Towne Merchants Association, one shall be a representative of the Halifax Triangle area, and one shall be a representative of Downtown Petersburg, Inc. 
(Ord. No. 08-26, § 1, 3-4-2008) 
Sec. 38-108. - Boundaries. 
    The district shall be located in the northeastern portion of the city, defined by the following borders: 
Beginning at the intersection of East Wythe and South Adams Streets, the boundary proceeds northwardly along the center line of South Adams Street, and thence along the centerline of North Adams Street to its intersection with the center line of Henry Street, thence eastwardly along the center line of Henry Street to the southward extension of the east property line of 203 Henry Street, thence northwardly along the east property lines of properties abutting Third Street to the center line of Bollingbrook Street, thence eastwardly along the center line of Bollingbrook Street to its intersection with the center line of Phoenix Street, thence northwardly along the center line of Phoenix Street to its intersection with the center line of Joseph Jenkins Roberts Street, thence northwestwardly along the center line of Joseph Jenkins Roberts Street to a point directly underneath the southern side of the Pocahontas Island ramp, thence westwardly to the center line of the railroad spur line serving Pocahontas Island, thence westwardly along the center line of the railroad spur line to its intersection with the center line of the Norfolk Southern main railroad track, thence westwardly along the center line of the Norfolk Southern main railroad track to its intersection with the northward extension of the west property line of property addressed as 520 McNeil's Alley, thence southwardly along this west property line and the west property line of property addressed as 201 Grove Avenue to the centerline of Grove Avenue, thence southwardly to and along the west property line of property addressed as 424 North Market Street, thence southwardly along the west property lines of properties abutting N. Market Street to the intersection of the center line of West Wythe Street, in the process crossing Low Street, High Street, Hinton Street, West Washington Street, thence eastwardly along the center line of West Wythe Street to the intersection of the northward extension of the east property line of property addressed as 111 South Market Street, thence southwardly along the east property lines of properties fronting South Market Street to the intersection of the north property line of property addressed as 153 Halifax Street, thence westwardly along the north property line of 153 Halifax Street extended to its intersection with the center line of South Market Street, thence southwardly along the center line of South Market Street to its intersection with the center line of Halifax Street, thence eastwardly along the south property lines of properties fronting South Avenue to the center line of Harrison Street, thence eastwardly along the center line of College Place to the intersection of the southward extension of the east property line of property addressed as 33 College Place, thence northwardly along the east property line of property addressed as 33 College Place, thence northwardly along the east property lines of properties fronting Harrison Street to the intersection with the north boundary of property addressed as 105 Harrison Street, thence eastwardly along the southern boundary of property addressed as 28 West Wythe Street, thence northwardly along the east property line of property addressed as 28 West Wythe Street to the intersection of this property line, as extended, with the center line of West Wythe Street, thence eastwardly along the center line of West Wythe and East Wythe Streets to the point of beginning. 
    All parcels located within the boundaries described above are included in the district. 
(Ord. No. 08-26, § 1, 3-4-2008) 
Sec. 38-109. - Exemption from admissions tax; other incentives. 
    Qualified arts organizations shall be exempt, for a period of no more than 10 years, from the admissions tax imposed by chapter 106, article V, sections 106-201 et seq. of the Petersburg City Code. Council may establish other incentives at the request of any person or the appeals committee, including provisions to increase regulatory flexibility and other incentives designed to help create and support arts and cultural venues in the district. 
(Ord. No. 08-26, § 1, 3-4-2008) 
Chapter 42 - COURTS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Appointment of police officers for issuance of civil warrants for collection of city taxes and other claims of the city, § 3-19. 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; law enforcement, ch. 70; offenses and miscellaneous provisions, ch. 74; traffic and vehicles, ch. 110. 
State Law reference- Criminal and traffic jurisdiction of general district courts, Code of Virginia, § 16.1-123.1. 

Sec. 42-1. - Assessment for law library. 
(a)  The city does hereby assess, as part of the costs incident to each civil action filed in any court located within the city, the sum of $2.00. Such assessments shall be collected by the clerk of the court in which the action is filed and remitted to the collector of city taxes, and held by such treasurer, subject to the disbursements by the city council for the acquisition of law books, law periodicals and computer legal research services and equipment for the establishment, use and maintenance of a law library, which shall be open for the use of the public at hours convenient to the public, and such disbursements may include compensation to be paid to the librarians and other necessary staff for the maintenance of such library and acquisition of suitable quarters for such library. The compensation of such librarians and the necessary staff and the cost of suitable quarters for such library shall be fixed by the city council and paid out of the fund created by the imposition of such assessment of cost. 
(b)  The assessment provided for in this section shall be in addition to all other costs prescribed by law, but shall not apply to any action in which the commonwealth or any political subdivision thereof or the federal government is a party and in which the costs are assessed against the commonwealth, such political subdivision or the federal government. The city council is authorized to accept contributions to the fund from any bar association. 
(Code 1981, § 1-16; Ord. No. 17-30, 7-11-2017) 
State Law reference- Authority for above section, Code of Virginia, § 42.1-70. 
Sec. 42-2. - Assessment for courthouse construction, renovation or maintenance. 
(a)  Imposed; amount. Pursuant to the provisions of Code of Virginia, § 17.1-281, and subject to the conditions and limitations thereof, there is hereby imposed an assessment as part of the costs in each civil action, and as a part of the fees taxed as costs against each defendant in each criminal and traffic case, in the district and circuit courts of the city, the sum of $2.00. The assessment provided for in this section shall be in addition to any other fees prescribed by law. The assessment provided for in this section shall be collected by the clerk of the court in which the action is filed, and remitted to the collector of city taxes and held by the treasurer subject to disbursements by the city council for construction, renovation, or maintenance of any city courthouse or jail and court-related facilities and to defray increases in the cost of heating, cooling, electricity, and ordinary maintenance of such facilities. 
(b)  Additional sum imposed; amount. Pursuant to the provisions of Code of Virginia, § 17.1-281(C), and subject to the conditions and limitations thereof, there is hereby imposed an assessment as part of the costs in each civil action where the amount in controversy exceeds $500.00, and as a part of the fees taxed as costs against each defendant in each criminal and traffic case, in the district courts of the city, the additional sum of $3.00. The assessment provided for in this section shall be in addition to any other fees prescribed by law. The assessment provided for in this section shall be collected by the clerk of the court in which the action is filed, remitted to the collector of city taxes, and held by the treasurer subject to disbursements by the city council solely for the construction, reconstruction, renovation of, or adaptive re-use of a structure for a courthouse. 
(Code 1981, §§ 34-224, 34-225; Ord. No. 12-64, 9-18-2012; Ord. No. 12-87, 12-18-2012; Ord. No. 17-30, 7-11-2017) 
Sec. 42-3. - Assessment for courthouse security. 
(a)  Imposed; amount. Pursuant to the provisions of Code of Virginia, § 53.1-120D, and subject to the conditions and limitations thereof, there is hereby imposed an assessment as part of the costs in each criminal or traffic case in the Petersburg District or Circuit Court in which the defendant is convicted of a violation of any statute or ordinance the sum of $10.00. This assessment shall be in addition to any other fees prescribed by law. 
(b)  Collection; disbursement. The assessment shall be collected by the clerk of the court in which the case is heard, remitted to the collector of city taxes and held by the treasurer subject to appropriation by the city council to the sheriff's office for the funding of courthouse security personnel, and, if requested by the sheriff, equipment and other personal property used in connection with courthouse security. 
(Ord. No. 02-30, 6-4-2002; Ord. No. 07-60, 7-3-2007; Ord. No. 17-30, 7-11-2017) 
Sec. 42-4. - Processing fee may be imposed on certain individuals. 
(a)  Imposed; amount. Pursuant to the provisions of Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1613.1, and subject to the conditions and limitations thereof, there is hereby imposed a processing fee of $25.00 on any individual admitted to the city jail, the jail farm, or the regional jail following conviction. This fee shall be in addition to any other fees prescribed by law. 
(b)  Collection; disbursement. The fee shall be ordered as a part of court costs collected by the court clerk, deposited into the account of the collector of city taxes and shall be used by the sheriff's office to defray the costs of processing arrested persons into the city jail, the jail farm, or the regional jail. 
(Ord. No. 02-31, 6-4-2002; Ord. No. 17-30, 7-11-2017) 
Sec. 42-5. - Assessment for electronic summons system. 
    Pursuant to the provisions of the Code of Virginia, § 17.1-279.1, the city council shall assess an additional sum not in excess of $5.00 as part of the costs in each criminal or traffic case in any court in the city in which the defendant is charged with a violation of any statute or ordinance. The police department will use the additional funds toward its electronic summons system. 
(Ord. No. 17-37, 9-5-2017)

ARTICLE V. - ELECTION DATE FOR CITY COUNCIL MEMBERS AND SCHOOL BOARD MEMBERS 

Sec. 46-100. - Election of council and school board members. 
(a)  Pursuant to and in accordance with Code of Virginia (1950), § 24.2-222.1, as amended, and notwithstanding the provisions of Code of Virginia (1950), § 24.2-222, as amended, and notwithstanding Section 2-2.1 of the Charter of the City of Petersburg, in the year 2008, the members of the city council and members of the school board from wards two, four, and six shall be elected on the November general election date for terms to commence January 1, 2009. Thereafter, elections shall be held in such wards every fourth year on the November general election date. In the year 2010, the members of the city council and members of the school board from wards one, three, five, and seven shall be elected on the November general election date for terms to commence January 1, 2011. Thereafter, elections shall be held in such wards every fourth year on the November general election date. 
(b)  Pursuant to and in accordance with Code of Virginia (1950), § 24.2-507, as amended, and notwithstanding the provisions of Section 2-3.1 of the Charter of the City of Petersburg, declarations of candidacy and the petitions therefor shall be filed according to the following schedule: 
(1)  For a November general election date, the deadline shall be at 7:00 p.m. on the second Tuesday in June; 
(2)  For a special election held at the same time as a November general election, either (i) at least seventy-four days before the election, or (ii) if the special election is being held at the second November election after the vacancy occurred, by 7:00 p.m. on the first Tuesday in March. 
(3)  For a special election held at a time other than a general election, (i) at least thirty days before the election, or (ii) within five days of any writ of election or order calling a special election to be held less than 35 days after the issuance of the writ or order. 
(Ord. No. 07-15, 2-20-2007)
