(c)  The person in charge of any such building, place, conveyance, meeting, operation or activity may eject therefrom any person who violates any provision of this section, with the aid, if necessary, of any persons who may be called upon for such purpose. 
(d)  A person violating any provision of this section shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1981, § 21-14) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-415. 
Sec. 74-364. - Abusive language. 
    If any person shall, in the presence or hearing of another, curse or abuse such other person, or use any violent abusive language to such person concerning himself or any of his relations, or otherwise use such language, under circumstances reasonably calculated to provoke a breach of the peace, he shall be guilty of a class 3 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1981, § 21-11) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-416. 
Sec. 74-365. - Slander and libel. 
    Any person who shall falsely utter and speak, or falsely write and publish, of and concerning any female of chaste character, any words derogatory of such female's character for virtue and chastity, or imputing to such female acts not virtuous and chaste, or who shall falsely utter and speak, or falsely write and publish, of and concerning another person, any words which from their usual construction and common acceptation are construed as insults and tend to violence and breach of the peace or shall use grossly insulting language to any female of good character or reputation, shall be guilty of a class 3 misdemeanor. The defendant shall be entitled to prove upon trial in mitigation of the punishment, the provocation which induced the libelous or slanderous words, or any other fact or circumstance tending to disprove malice, or lessen the criminality of the offense. 
(Code 1981, § 21-12) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-417. 
Secs. 74-366-74-380. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - TELEPHONES; RADIOS 

Sec. 74-381. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Emergency call means a call to report a fire or summon police, or for medical aid or emergency medical services vehicle service, in a situation where human life or property is in jeopardy and the prompt summoning of aid is essential. 
    Telephone party line means a subscribers' line circuit consisting of two or more main telephone stations connected therewith, each station with a distinctive ring or telephone number. 
(Code 1981, § 35-1) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-426. 
Sec. 74-382. - Duty of telephone company to furnish information relative to violations of division. 
    It shall be the duty, on pain of contempt of court, of each telephone company to furnish immediately, in response to a subpoena issued by the circuit court, such information as it, its officers and employees may possess which, in the opinion of the court, may aid in the apprehension of persons suspected of violating the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1981, § 35-2) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-431. 
Sec. 74-383. - Requesting relinquishment of party line on false pretext. 
    Any person who requests another to relinquish a telephone party line on the pretext that he must place an emergency call, knowing such pretext to be false, shall be guilty of a class 4 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1981, § 35-4) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-425. 
Sec. 74-384. - Certain solicitation calls prohibited; penalties. 
(a)  Any person who uses recorded solicitation calls for initial sales contacts shall be guilty of a class 4 misdemeanor. 
(b)  Any person who uses recorded solicitation calls which do not disengage or terminate when the party called attempts to terminate the call by any method which is in accordance with normal operating procedures of his receiver shall be guilty of a class 3 misdemeanor. 
(c)  Nothing contained in this division shall be construed to permit any fine or penalty against any employee or agent who has been caused, directed or authorized by his employer to violate the provisions of this section. In such cases, the employer shall be subject to the sanctions prescribed in this section. 
(Code 1981, § 35-5) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-425.1. 
Sec. 74-385. - Use of profane, threatening, etc., language over telephone. 
    If any person shall use obscene, vulgar, profane, lewd, lascivious, or indecent language, or make any suggestion or proposal of an obscene nature, or threaten any illegal or immoral act with the intent to coerce, intimidate, or harass any person, over any telephone or citizens band radio in this city, he shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1981, § 35-6) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-427. 
Sec. 74-386. - Giving certain false information to another by telephone. 
    If any person maliciously advises or informs another, over any telephone in this city, of the death of, accident to, injury to, illness of or disappearance of some third party, knowing the information to be false, he shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1981, § 35-7) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-428. 
Sec. 74-387. - Causing telephone to ring with intent to annoy. 
(a)  Any person who, with or without intent to communicate but with intent to annoy any other person, causes any telephone or digital pager, not his own, to ring or to otherwise signal, and any person who permits or condones the use of any telephone under his control for such purpose shall be guilty of a class 3 misdemeanor. 
(b)  Any person who, with or without intent to converse, but with intent to annoy, harass, hinder or delay emergency personnel in the performance of their duties as such, causes a telephone to ring, which is owned or leased for the purpose of receiving emergency calls by a public or private entity providing fire, police or emergency medical service, and any person who knowingly permits the use of a telephone under his control for such purpose, shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1981, § 35-8) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-429. 
Secs. 74-388-74-410. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - OFFENSES AGAINST THE ADMINISTRATION OF JUSTICE[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 

Sec. 74-411. - Officer receiving bribe to omit or delay service of process. 
    If any officer authorized to serve legal process receives any money or other thing of value for omitting or delaying to perform any duty pertaining to his office, he shall be guilty of a class 2 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1981, § 21-7) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-440. 
Sec. 74-412. - Obstructing justice. 
    If any person, by threats or force, knowingly attempts to intimidate or impede a judge, magistrate, justice, juror, attorney for the commonwealth, witness, or any law enforcement officer, lawfully engaged in his duties as such, or to obstruct or impede the administration of justice in any court, he shall be deemed to be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1981, § 21-6) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-460. 
Sec. 74-413. - Concealing or compounding offenses. 
    If any person knowing of the commission of an offense takes any money or reward, or an engagement therefor, upon an agreement or understanding, expressed or implied to compound or conceal such offense, or not to prosecute therefor, or not to give evidence thereof, he shall, if such offense be a felony, be guilty of a class 2 misdemeanor, and if such offense is not a felony, unless it is punishable merely by forfeiture to him, he shall be guilty of a class 4 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1981, § 21-2) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-462. 
Secs. 74-414-74-440. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - DRUG AND PROSTITUTION-FREE ZONES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 74-441. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Adjudicated juvenile means a juvenile found by a court to be a delinquent child, a child in need of services, or a child in need of supervision pursuant to Code of Virginia, § 16.1-278 et seq. 
    City courts, sentencing court and courts mean the city circuit court, city general district court, and the city juvenile and domestic relations district court. 
    Public area means any street, sidewalk, bridge, alley, alleyway, plaza, park, driveway, parking lot, public transportation facility, or a doorway or entranceway to any building which abuts any such area, or inside a personal motor vehicle in or on any such place. 
(Ord. No. 97-106, §§ 20.1-1(1), (3), (8), 20.1-6(1), (3), (7), 7-1-1997) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Secs. 74-442-74-460. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - DRUG-FREE ZONES 

Sec. 74-461. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Bona fide resident means a person who has presented sufficient evidence to the court that such person owns, leases, or otherwise lawfully occupies a primary residence, or dwelling unit within a drug-free zone. 
    Controlled substance crime means any violation of Code of Virginia, §§ 18.2-247-18.2-264.01. 
    Convicted drug user, possessor, or seller means any person who has pleaded guilty to or been convicted in any court of competent jurisdiction, of a violation of those offenses set forth in Code of Virginia, §§ 18.2-247-18.2-264.01. 
    Court-ordered restriction means a court imposed condition that is placed on an adjudicated juvenile or a convicted drug user, possessor, or seller and restricts their activity in a drug-free zone for a specified period of time. 
    Drug-free zone means those public areas that have been designated and posted by the chief of police as locations that are the site of repeated and documented illicit drug activity. 
(Ord. No. 97-106, § 20.1-1(2), (4)-(7), 7-1-1997) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 74-462. - Designation of drug-free zones. 
(a)  The chief of police may designate certain public areas within the city as drug-free zones for a period not to exceed 12 consecutive months. Such designations shall be in writing and supported by data and any other relevant information that assist the chief of police in making his determination, including but not limited to the following factors: 
(1)  Those areas where the number of arrests for illegal drug activity for the 12-month period preceding the designation is significantly higher than other similarly sized areas of the city; 
(2)  Those areas where the number of homicides related to the possession or distribution of illegal drugs for the 12-month period preceding the designation is significantly higher than that for other similarly sized areas of the city; 
(3)  Those areas where there is objective evidence or verifiable information that shows that illegal drugs are being sold and distributed on a public space on public property within the area; 
(4)  Those areas where the chief of police can verify with other reliable information that the health or safety of the residents who live therein is endangered by the purchase, sale, or use of illegal drugs; or 
(5)  Those areas commonly referred to by law enforcement personnel as high drug areas or open air drug markets. 
(b)  The chief of police shall notify the general public, by publication, the city council, the city courts, and all police officers of the boundaries of all drug-free zones. In addition, any area which has been designated shall be conspicuously posted with signs identifying it as a drug-free zone. 
(Ord. No. 97-106, § 20.1-2, 7-1-1997) 
Sec. 74-463. - Restrictions in drug-free zone; exceptions. 
(a)  Upon the recommendation to a court by the attorney for the commonwealth, or upon a court's own motion, a court within the city may utilize the boundaries of drug-free zones as the basis for imposing restrictions upon an adjudicated juvenile or a convicted drug user, possessor, or seller. Any person who is restricted from entry into any drug-free zones shall be given, as part of his sentence, a written description of the boundaries of such drug-free zones. 
(b)  A sentencing court may grant exceptions or vary the restrictions imposed on an adjudicated juvenile or a convicted drug user, possessor, or seller based upon relevant circumstances including but not limited to the following factors: 
(1)  A person is a bona fide resident of a drug-free zone prior to exclusion by the court; 
(2)  A person is a bona fide owner, principal, or employee of a place of employment in one of the drug-free zones; 
(3)  A person must conduct business with a governmental office or a medical facility located in a drug-free zone; 
(4)  A person desires to attend a house of worship located in a drug-free zone; or 
(5)  A person is required or desires to attend a school located in a drug-free zone. 
Any exceptions granted by the court shall be in writing and in the possession of the restricted person while such person is in a drug-free zone. 
(Ord. No. 97-106, § 20.1-3, 7-1-1997) 
Sec. 74-464. - Unlawful entry into a drug-free zone. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person who has been ordered by a court to refrain from entry into a drug-free zone, or whose activities within a drug-free zone have been otherwise restricted by a court, to thereafter enter or be upon those public areas within the drug-free zone in violation of the court's order, unless the court has authorized an exception to such person as provided by section 74-463. Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 97-106, § 20.1-4, 7-1-1997) 
Secs. 74-465-74-480. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PROSTITUTION-FREE ZONES 

Sec. 74-481. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Bona fide resident means a person who has presented sufficient evidence to the court that such person owns, leases, or otherwise lawfully occupies a primary residence, or dwelling unit within a prostitution-free zone. 
    Court ordered restriction means a court imposed condition that is placed on an adjudicated juvenile or a person who has pleaded to or been convicted of a prostitution offense, which restricts activity of such juvenile or person in a prostitution-free zone for a mandatory period. 
    Person convicted of prostitution means any person who has pleaded guilty to or been convicted of a violation of section 74-234 or Code of Virginia, § 18.2-346. 
    Prostitution-free zones means those public areas that have been designated and posted by the chief of police as locations that are the site of repeated and documented illicit prostitution activity. 
(Ord. No. 97-106, § 20.1-6(2), (4)-(6), 7-1-1997) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 74-482. - Designation of prostitution-free zones. 
(a)  The chief of police may designate certain public areas within the city as prostitution-free zones for a period not to exceed 12 consecutive months. Such designations shall be in writing and supported by data and any other relevant information that assist the chief of police in making his determination, including but not limited to the following factors: 
(1)  Those areas where the number of arrests for prostitution for the 12-month period preceding the designation is significantly higher than other similarly sized areas of the city; 
(2)  Those areas where there is objective evidence or verifiable information that shows that solicitation for prostitution is occurring on public areas within the area; or 
(3)  Those areas where the chief of police can verify with other reliable information that the health and welfare of residents who live therein are disrupted by solicitation for prostitution. 
(b)  The chief of police shall notify the general public, by publication, the city council, the city courts, and all police officers of the boundaries of all prostitution-free zones. In addition, the area which has been designated shall be conspicuously posted with signs identifying it as a prostitution-free zone. 
(Ord. No. 97-106, § 20.1-7, 7-1-1997) 
Sec. 74-483. - Restrictions in prostitution-free zones; exceptions. 
(a)  Upon the recommendation to a court by the attorney for the commonwealth, or upon a court's own motion, a court within the city may utilize the boundaries of prostitution-free zones as the basis for imposing restrictions upon an adjudicated juvenile or a convicted person. Any person who is restricted from entry into any prostitution-free zones shall be given, as part of his sentence, a written description of the boundaries of such prostitution-free zones. 
(b)  A sentencing court may grant exceptions or vary the restrictions imposed on an adjudicated juvenile or a convicted person based upon relevant circumstances including but not limited to the following factors: 
(1)  A person is a bona fide resident of the prostitution-free zone prior to exclusion by the court; 
(2)  A person is a bona fide owner, principal or employee of a place of employment located in one of the designated prostitution-free zones; 
(3)  A person must conduct business with a governmental office or medical facility in a prostitution-free zone; 
(4)  A person desires to attend a house of worship in the designated prostitution-free zone; or 
(5)  A person is required or desires to attend a school located in a prostitution-free zone. 
(Ord. No. 97-106, § 20.1-8, 7-1-1997) 
Sec. 74-484. - Unlawful entry on public property in a prostitution-free zone. 
    It shall be unlawful for a person who has been ordered by a court to refrain from entry into a prostitution-free zone to enter or be upon those public areas in a prostitution free zone in violation of the court's order, unless the court has authorized an exception as provided in section 74-483. Violations of this article shall be a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 97-106, § 20.1-9, 7-1-1997) 
Chapter 78 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Environment, ch. 50; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 98; waterways, ch. 122. 
State Law reference- Parks, recreation facilities, playgrounds, etc., Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1806 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 78-1. - Violations of chapter. 
    Unless otherwise specifically provided, a violation of any provision of this chapter shall constitute a class 4 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1981, § 22-1) 
Sec. 78-2. - General powers and duties of city manager with respect to parks. 
    The city manager shall have full control of the public parks of the city and the buildings and appurtenances thereto belonging. The city manager shall appoint the keepers thereof and employ such labor as he may deem necessary, but no improvements or repairs shall be made or done at any of the parks without the approval of the city council. 
(Code 1981, § 22-2) 
Sec. 78-3. - Appointment, term and general powers and duties of director of recreation. 
(a)  The city manager shall appoint a director of recreation, whose term of office shall be at the pleasure of the city manager. 
(b)  The director of recreation shall have general charge of all playgrounds maintained by the city and shall have authority to enforce such rules and regulations as will ensure the best results, and shall also have general charge of such recreational activities as may from time to time be authorized by the city council. The director of recreation shall recommend for appointment to the city manager such assistants and employees as may be authorized from time to time to effectively carry out the work of his department. 
(Code 1981, § 22-4) 
Secs. 78-4-78-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - RECREATION ADVISORY BOARD[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Boards and commissions, § 2-241 et seq. 

Sec. 78-31. - Definition. 
    As used in this article, the word "board" shall mean the recreation advisory board created by section 78-32. 
(Code 1981, § 22-27) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 78-32. - Created; composition; appointment of members. 
    There is hereby created a board to be known as the Petersburg Recreation Advisory Board, which board shall consist of seven members. The members shall be appointed by the city council, whereby each councilmember shall nominate one member to serve on the board. In addition to the members so appointed, the director of recreation shall be, ex officio, a member of the board. 
(Code 1981, § 22-28) 
Sec. 78-33. - Terms of members; filling of vacancies. 
    Each member of the recreation advisory board shall serve a term concurrent with the term of office of the member of city council who nominated the member of the board. Any vacancy on the recreation advisory board shall be filled by the city council in the same manner set out in section 78-32. 
(Code 1981, § 22-29) 
Sec. 78-34. - Members to serve without compensation. 
    All members of the recreation advisory board shall serve without compensation. 
(Code 1981, § 22-30) 
Sec. 78-35. - Election of chairman. 
    The chairman of the recreation advisory board shall be designated by majority vote of the recreation advisory board. 
(Code 1981, § 22-31) 
Sec. 78-36. - To act in advisory capacity; recommendations. 
    The recreation advisory board shall act in an advisory capacity with the city manager in all matters pertaining to public recreation in the city. The city manager shall report to the city council the recommendations of the recreation advisory board, when such recommendations relate to matters requiring action by the city council. 
(Code 1981, § 22-32) 
Secs. 78-37-78-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CONDUCT IN PARKS 

Sec. 78-61. - Driving motor vehicle on park walkway. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to drive any motor vehicle on any walkway in a city park. 
(Code 1981, § 22-8) 
Cross reference- Traffic and vehicles, ch. 110. 
Sec. 78-62. - Walking on grass; lying down or sleeping on grass or park benches. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to walk on any of the grass plots in city parks or lie down or sleep on such plots or on park seats or benches. The prohibition against walking on such grass plots shall not apply to children under the age of 12 years, or the nurses in attendance upon them. 
(Code 1981, § 22-9) 
Sec. 78-63. - Noise. 
    No person shall engage in loud singing or make any disorderly noise in any city park. 
(Code 1981, § 22-10) 
Cross reference- Noise, § 50-31 et seq. 
Sec. 78-64. - Pollution of springs or lakes. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to pollute any spring or lake in any city park. 
(Code 1981, § 22-11) 
Secs. 78-65-78-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - SPECIFIC PARKS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 78-91-78-105. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LEE MEMORIAL PARK 

Sec. 78-106. - Establishment of Lee Memorial Park; preservation. 
(a)  There shall be established in the property of the city heretofore known as the watershed or the Willcox Dam reservoir tract a park, to comprise all that portion of such tract included in the territory annexed to the city as provided in ordinance of annexation approved September 12, 1921, with the exception, however, of such property as has been sold or shall hereafter be sold by the city. 
(b)  The park established by this section shall be dedicated to the use of the people of the city as a park and to the memory of General Robert E. Lee, as a testimonial to his defense of the city in the siege of 1864-65, and to his greatness as a soldier and his nobility as a man. The park shall be known as Lee Memorial Park. 
(c)  In making improvements in Lee Memorial Park, special care shall be taken to preserve the forts, entrenchments and other fortifications erected under the direction of General Lee, as a memorial to him and to the soldiers who served under him. 
(Code 1981, § 22-5) 
Secs. 78-107-78-125. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - WEST END PARK 

Sec. 78-126. - Designation. 
    The grounds known as West End Park are hereby set apart and shall be kept as a public park. 
(Code 1981, § 22-7) 
Secs. 78-127-78-145. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - POPLAR LAWN 

Sec. 78-146. - Designation. 
    The grounds known as Poplar Lawn are hereby set apart and shall be kept as a public park. 
(Code 1981, § 22-6) 
Sec. 78-147. - Use prohibited between certain hours; exceptions. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to be in Poplar Lawn at any time between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 5:00 a.m.; provided, however, nothing in this section shall be construed as applying to persons walking along, but not loitering, on the concrete walkway along or near the northern boundary of Poplar Lawn; and provided further, this section shall not apply with respect to functions or ceremonies held in Poplar Lawn which have been duly authorized by proper authority of the city. 
(Code 1981, § 22-14) 
Sec. 78-148. - Riding bicycles. 
    No person shall ride a bicycle in Poplar Lawn; provided, however, that children under 15 years of age may ride bicycles along the old bicycle circle in Poplar Lawn. 
(Code 1981, § 22-15) 
Sec. 78-149. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - MUNICIPAL GOLF COURSE 

Sec. 78-150. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this article, the following words shall have the meaning ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Adult means any person 18 years of age or older. 
    In-season means the period from April 1 through to October 31 within a single 12-month period. 
    Junior means any person aged 17 years or younger. 
    Off-season means the period from November 1 to March 31 within a single 12-month period. 
    Outing means an event in which group of individuals who wish to play golf together reserve a tee time and meet the requirements for group play established by the golf professional. 
    Resident means any person having a personal residence located within the city limits of the City of Petersburg. 
    Senior means any person aged 60 years or older. 
    Student means any person aged 22 years of age or younger, who can present a valid identification card issued by an institution of higher learning authorized to grant academic degrees. 
    Twilight means the period of time beginning after 2:00 pm on weekdays, and after 4:00 pm on weekends, and continuing until the course closes for the day, except that in the off season, twilight shall mean the period of time beginning at 1:00 pm and continuing until course closure for the day. 
    Weekday means Monday through Thursday. 
    Weekend means Friday through Sunday and holidays. 
(Ord. No. 08-30, § 1, 4-1-2008) 
Sec. 78-151. - Administration. 
(a)  The city shall operate and maintain a municipal golf course which shall be available for use by city residents and nonresidents alike. The course shall be known as the Dogwood Trace Golf Course. 
(b)  The city manager or his designee shall be responsible for ensuring that the course is properly maintained and that it is operated in a professional and efficient manner. The city may procure the services of a management professional to oversee the maintenance and operation of the course and the collection of fees. The golf professional shall establish such policies and procedures to govern course operation and maintenance, including the collection of fees, as he deems appropriate. 
(Ord. No. 08-30, § 1, 4-1-2008) 
Sec. 78-152. - Financial structure. 
    The municipal golf course is established within the city budget as an enterprise fund and as such, is responsible for generating the revenues required to support appropriate operation and maintenance costs. Nothing in this section shall prevent council from making such appropriations as they deem necessary to supplement the operation or maintenance of the course. 
(Ord. No. 08-30, § 1, 4-1-2008) 
Sec. 78-153. - Fees. 
(a)  Any person desiring to play golf shall first apply and pay the appropriate fee or fees as follows: 
Resident:  Weekday $20.00  Weekend $30.00 Nonresident:  Weekday $25.00  Weekend $35.00 Seniors:  Weekday $20.00 Juniors: $10.00 Students: $15.00 Twilight: $15.00 Nine holes (weekdays only):  Adults $15.00  Juniors $8.00 Annual passes:  Resident $1,100  Resident senior $1,000  Nonresident $1,300 Nonresident senior $1,200 Junior $400.00 Outings: In-season $35  Off-season $30.00 Cart fees: 18 holes $14.00 9 holes $10.00  
(b)  The following provisions shall govern the calculation of applicable fees: 
(1)  Carts shall be required for play beginning on weekends before 12:00 noon. 
(2)  Outings are available on weekdays only, and the established fee shall include the use of a cart. 
(3)  Annual passes govern admission to the course for the period from April 1 through March 31 of the following year except that persons holding annual passes may not use those for admission where they are accessing the course as participants in an outing. 
(4)  Cart fees do not include tax. 
(5)  Juniors must play with adults before 1:00 p.m. 
(c)  The city manager or his designee may approve the reduction or waiver of the fees established in this section (i) for special occasions, activities or events, or (ii) otherwise to promote the competitive positioning of the course. 
(Ord. No. 08-30, 4-1-2008) 
Chapter 82 - PLANNING[1] 
Footnotes:

ARTICLE II. - PLANNING COMMISSION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Boards and commissions, § 2-241 et seq. 

Sec. 82-31. - Created. 
    Under the authority of the applicable provisions of state law, there is hereby created a city planning commission. 
(Code 1981, § 2-156) 
State Law reference- Duty of city to create planning commission, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2210. 
Sec. 82-32. - Composition; appointment, qualifications, terms and removal of members. 
(a)  The number of voting members of the planning commission shall be nine. They shall be appointed by the city council, with one member being appointed from each ward, and two members at-large, for staggered terms of four years. All voting members shall be residents of the city qualified by knowledge and experience to make decisions on questions of community growth and development. At least one-half of the members so appointed shall be owners of real property. 
(b)  Two additional members, who are members of the administrative branch of the city, may be appointed to the planning commission by the city council, to serve ex officio without vote. These members shall perform such administrative duties as the commission may prescribe. The term of these members shall be coextensive with the terms of office to which they have been appointed, unless the city council, at its first regular meeting of the year, appoints another to serve as its representative. 
(c)  Members of the planning commission may be removed for malfeasance in office. 
(d)  The terms of the voting members shall expire on September 30. 
(Code 1981, § 2-157; Ord. No. 95-96, § 2-157, 9-5-1995; Ord. No. 02-70, 10-1-2002) 
State Law reference- Composition, etc., of planning commission, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2212. 
Sec. 82-33. - Powers and duties generally. 
    The planning commission shall have and exercise all such powers and shall discharge all such duties and functions as are set out in applicable provisions of the state law. 
(Code 1981, § 2-158) 
State Law reference- Local planning commissions, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2210 et seq. 
Chapter 86 - SECONDHAND GOODS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 26. 
State Law reference- Pawnbrokers, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4000 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 86-1. - Violations of chapter. 
(a)  Unless otherwise specifically provided, a violation of any provision of this chapter shall constitute a class 3 misdemeanor. 
(b)  Any violation of section 86-2 or section 86-3 shall be a misdemeanor. For the first offense, the penalty shall be a fine of not less than $50.00 nor more than $100.00, and for any second or subsequent offense, the penalty shall be a fine of not less than $100.00 nor more than $500.00 and confinement in jail for a period not exceeding 12 months. 
(Code 1981, §§ 21-65(f), 23-1) 
Sec. 86-2. - Daily reports by junk dealers and dealers in secondhand personal property. 
    Every junk dealer and dealers in secondhand personal property, including persons regularly engaged in the business of collecting secondhand materials for resale to junk dealers, shall every day except Sunday before the hour of noon deliver to the chief of police on blank forms to be prescribed and furnished by the chief of police a legible and accurate description of every secondhand article received by him during the business day next preceding, the permit number under which the goods were received by the dealer, the license number of any automobile or vehicle in which the goods or things were delivered, together with a description of the person selling or delivering such goods, including the color, sex, approximate height and age and any distinguishing features of such person, or a photograph of such person, together with a reference to the volume and number of the page where the original entry required by Code of Virginia, § 59.1-120 is made. 
(Code 1981, § 23-2) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 59.1-121. 
Sec. 86-3. - Sale of secondhand building fixtures. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided in this section or in Code of Virginia, §§ 59.1-117-59.1-136, no person shall, within the city, offer for sale or sell any secondhand heating or plumbing fixtures or supplies, electrical fixtures or wiring, or gas fixtures or appliances, water faucets, pipes, locks, bathtubs or other secondhand fixtures of whatever kind or description pertaining to a building, without first obtaining a permit for the sale of such material from the chief of police. 
(b)  The provisions of this section shall be construed so as to permit the chief of police to issue to persons who are regularly engaged in the business of collecting secondhand materials for resale a semiannual or annual permit covering all sales to be made by such persons. 
(c)  The chief of police may refuse to issue a permit, and may revoke any permit issued, to any person who has previously been or is convicted of stealing or receiving stolen goods. 
(d)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to the sale of any secondhand materials mentioned in subsection (a) of this section when such materials are taken from premises occupied by the owner and when they are sold by such owner on the premises. The provisions of this section shall not apply to the sale of such articles when purchased from a public utilities corporation at its place of business or a governmental agency. 
(e)  No charge shall be made for the issuance of any permit required by this section. 
(Code 1981, § 21-65(a)-(e)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, §§ 59.1-117, 59.1-118, 59.1-123. 
Secs. 86-4-86-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PAWNBROKERS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 86-31. - Limitation on number of pawnshops. 
    Not more than five pawnshops may be operated at any one time within the territorial limits of the city. 
(Code 1981, § 23-3) 
State Law reference- Authority for above section, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4002. 
Sec. 86-32. - Closing hours for pawnshops. 
    Each person licensed to conduct the business of a pawnbroker or a pawnshop shall close his place of business, and keep it closed, between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m. of the succeeding day on each day from Sunday through Saturday, inclusive. 
(Code 1981, § 23-4) 
State Law reference- Working or transacting business on Sunday, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-341. 
Sec. 86-33. - Daily reports. 
    Every pawnbroker shall prepare a daily report of all goods, articles or things pawned or pledged with him that day and shall file such report by noon of the following day with the chief of police or other law enforcement officer of the city designated by the attorney for the commonwealth to receive it. The report shall include the pledgor's name, residence, and driver's license number or other form of identification, and a description of the goods, articles or other things pledged and shall be in writing and clearly legible to any person inspecting it. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4010. 
Sec. 86-34. - Penalties. 
    Except as otherwise provided in section 82-51, any licensed pawnbroker who violates any of the provisions of this article shall be guilty of a class 4 misdemeanor. In addition, the court may revoke or suspend the pawnbroker's license for second and subsequent offenses. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4014. 
Secs. 86-35-86-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 86-51. - Procedure for issuance. 
(a)  A license for the conduct of business as a pawnbroker shall be authorized by the circuit court of the city. Any person desiring to obtain such a license shall present his written application therefor to the chief of police of the city, signed by himself, at least 30 days prior to the date on which he desires the license to become effective. The application shall state, if made by an individual, the full name of the applicant, and if by a firm, the full name of each member of the firm, and if by a corporation, the full names of the officers or agents who are to conduct the business in the city. The applicant shall also furnish his date of birth and a sworn statement or affirmation disclosing any criminal convictions or any pending criminal charges, whether within or without the commonwealth. 
(b)  If an application under this section is found to be in proper form, the chief of police shall endorse thereon the words "Referred to the circuit court of the City of Petersburg, or to the judge thereof in vacation." The applicant shall forthwith present such application to the circuit court of the city or the judge thereof in vacation, accompanied by a receipt from the collector of city taxes for a certified check, payable to the collector of city taxes, for the amount of the license tax assessed against pawnbrokers under the provisions of chapter 26 of this Code and other ordinances of the city. Such check shall be held by the collector of city taxes until the court or judge shall have passed upon the application. 
(c)  The court or judge shall hear such evidence as may be introduced for or against the applicant for a license, and determine whether such applicant is or is not eligible to be granted such a license and whether the place where the business is proposed to be conducted is or is not a proper and suitable place, and whether the issuance of such license is advisable or expedient, and whether the license may be legally granted under the ordinances of the city and the laws of the city. If the court or judge is of the opinion that the license may be granted, the court or judge, as the case may be, shall require the applicant to execute a bond, in the penalty and conditioned as prescribed in section 86-52, and upon the proper execution thereof, shall certify to the collector of city taxes that the applicant will be entitled to a license to conduct such business when the license tax has been paid. The clerk of the court shall thereupon certify to the collector of city taxes that the license has been granted and the check shall be at once paid into the city treasury. The collector of city taxes shall issue a license to the applicant to conduct such business in the place named in the application, in such form as may be approved by the city attorney. 
(d)  Upon the refusal to grant any license by the court or judge, that fact shall be certified by the clerk of the court to the collector, who shall thereupon return the check held by him to the applicant. 
(e)  Any person who violates the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1981, § 23-17) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4001. 
Sec. 86-52. - Applicant's bond. 
    No license to conduct the business of a pawnbroker shall be issued to any applicant therefor unless such applicant has given a bond, in the minimum amount of $50,000.00 to secure the payment of any judgement recovered under the provisions of Code of Virginia, § 54.1-4003(B), payable to the city, with surety satisfactory to the city attorney, and also conditioned that, if granted a license, he will make a daily report to the chief of police on a form to be prescribed by the chief of police and give all the information called for by the form, and that he will make use of any such call system as may be installed and maintained by the city or under its authority, in such manner and in strict accord with such rules and regulations as may be prescribed by the chief of police, and conditioned also that the holder of such license will observe and faithfully comply with all ordinances of the city relating to the conduct of such business. For any default in any of the conditions of the bond, it shall ipso facto, and without offset, be forfeited and payable to the city and the licensee shall immediately forfeit the license, which shall then and thereafter be null and void. 
(Code 1981, § 23-19)

Sec. 90-66. - Powers and duties.

(2)  To monitor the formulation and implementation of social welfare programs in the city. 
(3)  To meet with the director of social services at least four times a year for the purpose of making recommendations on policy matters concerning the department of public welfare. 
(4)  To make an annual report to the city council, concurrent with the budget presentation of the department, concerning the administration of the public welfare program. 
(5)  To submit to the city council, from time to time, other reports that the board deems appropriate. 
(Code 1981, § 28-20)

Chapter 94 - SOLID WASTE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Littering at city market, § 2-550; buildings and building regulations, ch. 22; environment, ch. 50; health and sanitation, ch. 62; utilities, ch. 114. 
State Law reference- Virginia Waste Management Act, Code of Virginia, § 10.1-1400 et seq.; removal of trash, garbage, etc., weeds and other foreign growth, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-901; garbage and refuse disposal, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-927; regulation of garbage and refuse pickup and disposal services, contracts, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-930; contracts for garbage and refuse pickup and disposal services, waste recovery facilities, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-932; delivery of garbage, trash and refuse to certain facilities, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-933; mailing summons for violation of trash ordinance, Code of Virginia, § 19.2-76.2. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 94-1. - Removal from premises on order of health director. 
(a)  The health director shall cause an inspection of the premises of all citizens of the city to be made when he may deem it necessary and require that all garbage, trash, filth, ashes, tin cans and all other articles that may endanger the health or safety of the citizens of the city be removed. 
(b)  Any person who fails to comply with a lawful order given pursuant to this section shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1981, § 30-1) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to require removal of garbage, trash, etc., Code of Virginia, § 15.2-901; abatement or removal of nuisances, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1115. 
Sec. 94-2. - Littering generally. 
(a)  No person shall dump, throw or otherwise deposit any trash, garbage, refuse or other unsightly matter on any street, highway, right-of-way or property adjacent to such street, highway or right-of-way, or on any other property, public or private, within the city, without the written consent of the owner of such property or his agent. 
(b)  When any person is arrested for a violation of this section and the matter alleged to have been deposited in violation of this section has been ejected from a motor vehicle, the arresting officer may comply with the provisions of section 110-35 of this Code in making such arrest. 
(c)  When a violation of the provisions of this section has been observed by any person, and the matter deposited in violation of this section has been ejected from a motor vehicle, the owner or operator of such motor vehicle shall be presumed to be the person ejecting such matter; provided, however, that such presumption shall be rebuttable by competent evidence. 
(d)  Any person violating this section shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1981, § 30-2) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions and authority of city council to adopt above section, Code of Virginia, § 33.1-346. 
Sec. 94-3. - Deposit of stone, brick or like objects on streets, vacant lots, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful and a class 1 misdemeanor for any person to throw or deposit, in or on any street, sidewalk, gutter, open space, vacant lot or space between houses, unless permitted by law or by the provisions of this Code or other ordinance of the city, any stone, brick or other like objects. 
(Code 1981, § 30-3) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 98. 
Sec. 94-4. - Unlawful use of street rubbish receptacles placed by city. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to use street rubbish cans or receptacles placed on the streets by duly authorized agents or employees of the city for any purpose whatsoever, except for the deposit of material of the kind ordinarily cast away by pedestrians or passersby, such as fruit peelings and refuse from unconsumed fruit, newspapers, letters, wrapping paper and like paper, refuse and trash. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit in the street rubbish cans or receptacles referred to in subsection (a) of this section any refuse, paper, trash or other matter which has been removed from, or which has accumulated, in any store, office, restaurant, hotel or other building, room, establishment or place. 
(c)  A violation of this section shall constitute a class 4 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1981, § 30-4) 
Secs. 94-5-94-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - COLLECTION BY CITY[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- General authority of city relative to collection and disposal of solid waste, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-927 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 94-31. - Violations of article. 
    Unless otherwise specifically provided, a violation of any provision of this article shall constitute a class 4 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1981, § 30-16) 
Sec. 94-32. - Director of public works or designee to have charge of collection. 
    Subject to the supervision and control of the director of public works or designee, the superintendent shall have charge of the collection and disposal of garbage, trash, refuse and ashes. 
(Code 1981, § 30-17; Ord. No. 12-66, 10-2-2012; Ord. No. 13-06, 1-22-2013) 
Sec. 94-33. - Frequency and days of collection. 
    The collection of garbage and other refuse, shall be weekly which shall be determined by the director of public works with the approval of the city manager. Hours of collection are Monday-Friday 7:00 a.m.-7:00 p.m. and Saturday 7:00 a.m.-12:00 noon. Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a class 3 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1981, § 30-18; Ord. No. 12-66, 10-2-2012; Ord. No. 13-06, 1-22-2013) 
Sec. 94-34. - Reserved. 
Sec. 94-35. - Placement for collection. 
(a)  Every occupant of a lot within the city shall place his garbage, trash and ashes for removal in the provided refuse and recycling receptacles. All receptacles must be placed out for collection by 7:00 a.m. on of the scheduled collection day but not earlier than 6:00 p.m. of the day preceding, except for any special times as deemed necessary by the director of public works. Refuse and recycling receptacles shall be placed for collection at a location designated by the director of public works. It shall be unlawful for any person to place hot or live ashes out for collection. 
(b)  All sweepings from stores, including waste paper and paper boxes, shall be placed, at the times named in subsection (a) of this section, in neat receptacles, with tops, on the outer edge of the sidewalk. In cases in which a store adjoins an alley connected with public streets, such receptacles may be placed in such alley at such times. 
(Code 1981, § 30-20; Ord. No. 13-44, 5-21-2013) 
Sec. 94-36. - Removal of receptacle after collection. 
    All refuse and recycling receptacles placed in accord with section 94-35 shall be removed no later than 7:00 a.m. on the day following collection from city property and rights-of-way to include, but not be limited to, sidewalks, alleys and median strips between sidewalks and roadways and returned by the occupant to a location not visible from the street or public right-of-way, except during the times prescribed for placement for collection and as soon as practicable after being emptied by collection personnel. However, nothing shall preclude the placement of such receptacles in any area other than the front of any residence or business. The public utility account holder of any property to which a refuse and recycling receptacles have been assigned shall be responsible for removing the refuse and recycling receptacles from city property and public rights-of-way. This provision applies to all residentially-zoned properties. 
(Code 1981, § 30-21; Ord. No. 11-59, 6-7-2011; Ord. No. 13-44, 5-21-2013) 
Sec. 94-37. - Certain waste matter not to be collected. 
    Waste matter from abattoirs, vegetable and fruit dealers, commission houses and hucksters' stalls and any other foodstuffs condemned by the health director or his representative shall not be collected by the city but shall be hauled to an approved landfill by the persons responsible for waste matter. 
(Code 1981, § 30-22) 
Sec. 94-38. - Penalties. 
    The public utility account holder of any property to which a refuse receptacle and recycling receptacle has been assigned shall be responsible for removing each receptacle from city property by 7:00 a.m. on the day following collection. Any account holder who allows a refuse receptacle or recycling receptacle to remain on city property after 7:00 a.m. on the day following collection shall receive a notice from the department of public works advising of the violation and allowing the account holder an opportunity to remove each such receptacle. If each refuse receptacle or recycling receptacle is not timely removed from city property, the department of public works shall cause the account holder to be assessed a civil penalty in the amount of $50.00 for each and every calendar day that each and every receptacle remains on city property beginning with the date of the most recent past scheduled pick up time from the department of public works. Such civil penalty shall be included on the account holder's monthly utility statement and shall be subject to collection in the same manner as other utility charges including delinquent charges for utilities. 
(Ord. No. 13-44, 5-21-2013) 
Secs. 94-39-94-55. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - FEES 

Sec. 94-56. - Fees established. 
    For providing or making available solid waste collection and disposal services to citizens, residences and commercial establishments located within the corporate limits of the city, there shall be a fee of $20.00 per month, or any part of a month. Such fee shall be for each single-family dwelling unit, for each unit in multi-family dwelling facilities, for each business unit, including retail, wholesale and commercial units. Only two carts, one trash cart and one recycling cart, are to be issued per each single family dwelling, multi-family or each business unit, each and for all other facilities where such collection and disposal services are provided or made available. Only one additional trash cart and recycling cart shall be provided for $58.00 each per each single family dwelling and multi-family and shall be a fee of $2.25 per month, or any part of a month. The director of public works shall have the authority to determine if additional carts are needed for any business unit. The fee for such carts provided shall be $58.00 per cart each and $2.25 per month, or any part of a month for each such business unit. 
(Code 1981, § 30-40; Ord. No. 97-60, § 30-40, 5-20-1997; Ord. No. 01-30, 5-15-2001; Ord. No. 12-66, 10-2-2012; Ord. No. 13-06, 1-22-2013; Ord. No. 16-38, 9-6-2016) 
Sec. 94-57. - Persons responsible for fees; schedule and place of payments; penalties and interest; priority of crediting payments. 
    All payment of fees for the collection and disposal of solid waste shall be the responsibility of the owner of the premises unless the premises are occupied by a person other than the owner and such person is the recipient of the service and is responsible for the payment of water and sewage charges; in which event, such person shall be responsible for the payment of the solid waste collection and disposal fee. This fee shall be paid on the same schedule as are the water and sewage charges, due and payable in the office of the collector of city taxes in the manner prescribed for water and sewage charges as established by this Code and, if not so paid, shall carry the same penalties and interest as prescribed therein. If the moneys received in payment of the water and sewage charges and the solid waste collection and disposal fees are not sufficient to pay the outstanding balance in full, including any penalties or interest, the solid waste collection and disposal fee and any penalties or interest attributed thereto shall be considered to be paid first out of the moneys collected. 
(Code 1981, § 30-41; Ord. No. 17-30, 7-11-2017) 
Sec. 94-58. - Exceptions, exclusions from fees. 
(a)  Any owner or person responsible for the payment of the solid waste collection and disposal fee, if such owner or person so elects, may have the solid waste collected and disposed of by a person duly licensed to perform such services, such to be accomplished in accordance with all applicable laws, ordinances and regulations controlling such collection and disposal. Such owner or person shall notify the director of public works of this election, and the director of public works shall have the authority to verify from time to time compliance with this section. Such owner or person shall be relieved of the obligation to pay the fees as are established by this article. 
(b)  The city shall not charge a fee for the collection of the following residential brush and yard waste: 
  Prunings, grass clippings, weeds, leaves, brush, and general yard and garden wastes must be bagged and securely tied together or bundled. 
  Yard waste and bundled brush will be collected up to ten cubic yards. Limbs shall be six feet or less in length and 60 pounds per contract. Brush must be tied in bundles less than four feet in length and weighing less than 75 pounds. 
  Bagged leaves will be collected year round. The limit per collection is up to 30 bags, each weighing no more than 50 pounds. 
  Limited amounts of bulky trash (like furniture, water heaters and appliances) will also be collected at the curb on your regular collection day. The amount should not exceed the capacity of a one-half ton pickup truck. 
(c)  Industrial waste, large-volume waste and similar refuse, construction debris disposal or garbage which the city does not collect and dispose of shall be excluded from the fees established by this article and it shall be the responsibility of the person generating such matter to properly collect and dispose of such matter. 
(Code 1981, § 30-42; Ord. No. 12-66, 10-2-2012; Ord. No. 13-06, 1-22-2013) 
Sec. 94-59. - Bulk waste fee. 
(a)  The city will remove items of residential waste, such as furniture or similar large items including but not limited to items too large to fit inside a trash cart/can and for unbundled brush debris, construction debris and excessive appliances with the regulations herein set forth, which have been placed on the edge of the street according to the following fee schedule. 
  Bulk and yard waste not exempted under section 94-58 collection fee for up to two cubic yards (approximately four feet × four feet × four feet) will be a minimum of $75.00; for every cubic yard (approximately three feet × three feet × three feet) over the initial two cubic yards, there will be an additional $35.00 charge. 
  Appliance collection fee will be $25.00 per appliance. 
  Furniture collection fee will be $20.00 per piece of furniture. 
(b)  This service is provided on an on-call basis and residents need to call and schedule a pick-up and prior to placing the material at the street right-of-way. 
(c)  Industrial waste, large-volume waste and similar refuse, construction debris disposal or garbage which the city does not collect and dispose of shall not be placed on the curb and it shall be the responsibility of the person generating such matter to properly collect and dispose of such matter. 
(d)  Violations of this section shall be subject to a civil penalty of $50.00 for the first violation, or violations arising from the same set of operative facts. The civil penalty for subsequent violations not arising from the same set of operative facts within 12 months of the first violation shall be $200.00. Each business day during which the same violation is found to have existed shall constitute a separate offense. In no event shall a series of specified violations arising from the same set of operative facts result in civil penalties that exceed a total of $3,000.00 in a 12-month period. Such violations shall be a class 3 misdemeanor in the event three civil penalties have previously been imposed on the same defendant for the same or similar violation, not arising from the same set of operative facts, within a 24-month period. Classifying such subsequent violations as criminal offenses shall preclude the imposition of civil penalties for the same violation. 
(Ord. No. 12-66, 10-2-2012; Ord. No. 13-06, 1-22-2013) 
Secs. 94-60-94-80. - Reserved. 
Chapter 98 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Toll bridges, ch. 5. 
Cross reference- Any ordinance authorizing, providing for or otherwise relating to any specific public improvement or making any assessment saved from repeal, § 1-7(7); health department inspection of streets and premises, § 2-215; distribution of advertising matter on or in street, sidewalk or public parking lot, § 6-4; deposit of advertising matter on street, sidewalk or public parking lot, § 6-5; painting or marking advertisements, signs, etc., on streets and sidewalks, § 6-6; operation of pool rooms or billiard rooms at other than street level, § 14-33; obstruction of view of pool rooms or billiard rooms from street, § 14-34; buildings and building regulations, ch. 22; cemeteries, ch. 30; community development, ch. 38; environment, ch. 50; floods, ch. 58; parks and recreation, ch. 78; planning, ch. 82; deposit of stone, brick or like objects on streets, vacant lots, etc., § 94-3; powers and duties regarding off-street parking facilities, § 110-67; designation of one-way streets and alleys, § 110-72; designation of through streets, § 110-73; operation of go-carts on streets, § 110-219; washing, polishing or greasing vehicle on street or sidewalk, § 110-262; pedestrians, § 110-401 et seq.; interurban buses taking on or discharging passengers on streets, § 118-285. 
State Law reference- Local streets and alleys, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2000 et seq.; state highway plat book, Code of Virginia, § 17.1-238; state highway system, Code of Virginia, § 33.1-25 et seq.; local authority over highways, Code of Virginia, § 33.1-224 et seq.; pipelines and other works in streets, alleys, etc., Code of Virginia, § 56-257 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 98-1. - Certain ordinances relating to streets and alleys not affected by Code. 
    Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect any ordinance opening, relocating, closing, altering or naming any street or alley, or fixing the grade thereof, and all such ordinances are hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length in this Code. 
(Code 1981, § 32-1) 
Sec. 98-2. - General powers and duties of director of public works with respect to streets and sidewalks. 
(a)  The director of public works shall exercise a general supervision over the streets, sidewalks, bridges and culverts in the public streets, or belonging to the city, and all matters connected therewith, under the direction of the city manager. 
(b)  The director of public works shall superintend the public streets, sidewalks, bridges and culverts in the public streets, or belonging to the city, see that such streets, sidewalks, bridges and culverts are kept in good order, remove obstructions therefrom, clean, construct and make such repairs and improvements therein as may be possible and recommend to the city manager such others as may be necessary, but which cannot be done by his personnel. Subject to the direction of the city manager, he shall have control and superintendence of city vehicles and employees employed on city streets. The director of public works shall also measure and make estimates for work ordered by the city manager or city council and, as far as possible, prevent violations of this chapter. 
(Code 1981, § 32-2) 
Sec. 98-3. - Appointment and general powers and duties of director of public works or director's designee. 
    The city manager shall appoint the director of public works or the director's designee, who shall, subject to the approval of the director of public works, have charge of the streets and sidewalks of the city. The director of public works or the director's designee shall have the powers of a police officer to the extent that it shall be necessary in performing his duties. 
(Code 1981, § 32-3; Ord. No. 12-66, 10-2-2012; Ord. No. 13-06, 1-22-2013) 
Sec. 98-4. - Minimum standards for entrances to state highways adopted. 
    There is hereby adopted, by reference, the latest publication of Minimum Standards of Entrances to State Highways, traffic and safety division of the state department of transportation, and such publication is hereby incorporated as fully as if set forth in this section verbatim and is to be in full force and effect in the city. 
(Code 1981, § 32-4) 
Sec. 98-5. - Repair of defective private works located in streets. 
    If any part of the works of any aqueduct, gas, telegraph, railroad or other company, or of any individual, located in any street shall, by reason of decay or other cause, do injury to such street, or endanger persons or property on the street or occasion inconvenience in the use thereof to a greater extent than would be the case if such works were kept in good repair, it shall be the duty of such company or person, on notice from the city manager or director of public works to such person, or any officer of such company having charge of such works, to repair or improve the works, so as to remedy the defect. If such person or company shall fail to repair or improve such works within a reasonable time after such notice, such works shall be deemed an obstruction, within the meaning of subsection 98-10(b) and such failure shall constitute a class 3 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1981, § 32-5) 
Sec. 98-6. - Adjustment of street works or structures when street graded. 
    Whenever the city shall determine to grade any street, the grade line of which has been or may hereafter be fixed by the city council, all persons lawfully having works or structures on the surface of the street shall, without delay, adjust and place such works and structures in a good and workmanlike manner, so as to conform to the grade line thus established. All persons lawfully having underground structures or works in such streets shall lower the underground structures or works where a cut will be made in grading the streets, so that such structures or works shall not be less than two feet below the surface. The director of public works shall promptly give notice in writing to all persons having such surface or underground structures or works of the action of the city and that they are required at once to adjust and place the surface or underground structures or works as required by this section. If any person shall fail to do so within 30 days after service of such notice, he shall be guilty of a class 2 misdemeanor and the director of public works, under the direction of the city manager, shall, when ordered by the city council, cause the work to be done and charge the cost thereof to the person so in default, to be collected as any other debt due the city and, in case of water service pipes connected with the city water mains, the water shall not be turned on again until such cost is paid. 
(Code 1981, § 32-6) 
Sec. 98-7. - Testing, repair, etc., of gas or water lines when street to be paved. 
(a)  Whenever the city shall determine to pave any street with any material, except cobble or rubble stones, before the paving shall be begun, all persons having gas mains, gas service pipes or water mains in the street where the paving is to be done shall examine and test them thoroughly, renew or repair them wherever needed, and put them in good order and condition, and at least two feet below the surface. All persons having water service pipes in the street where the paving is to be done shall renew the water service pipes by putting in new pipes, which shall conform to the requirements of this Code with reference to plumbing, at least two feet below the surface, all the way from the water main to the inner side of the curbline, or to the water meter, if one is in place on the service pipe, and shall fit the pipe with the new valves, cutoffs and the like, of the weight, thickness, diameter and style prescribed by the director of public works. 
(b)  The director of public works shall promptly give notice, in writing, of the action of the city, to all persons having structures or works referred to in subsection (a) of this section, that they are required to thoroughly examine, test, repair, renew, adjust and place such structures or works as required by this section. If any person shall fail to do so within 30 days after service of such notice, he shall be guilty of a class 2 misdemeanor; and the director of public works, under the direction of the city manager, shall, when ordered by the city council, cause the work to be done and charge the cost thereof to the person so in default, to be collected as any other debt due the city. In the case of a water service pipe connected with the city water main, the water shall not be turned on again until such cost is paid. 
(c)  If there is any lot abutting on a street where paving is to be done, into which city water has not been introduced, the director of public works, under the direction of the city manager, shall lay and construct a water service pipe, of the character and in the manner provided for in this section, from the city water main to some convenient point at the inner side of the curbline opposite such lot, and connect the water service pipe with the city water main. 
(d)  The director of public works shall preserve in his office a record of the cost and location of water supply pipes renewed, where one existed, or constructed, where none existed, as required by this section. Before city water shall be introduced into any such lot through such pipes, the owner thereof shall pay to the collector of city taxes the cost of renewing or constructing such water service pipe, as the case may be. When such payment has been made to the collector of city taxes and the permission of the director of public works obtained, such owner may introduce city water into his lot. 
(Code 1981, § 32-7; Ord. No. 17-30, 7-11-2017) 
Sec. 98-8. - Stopcocks on water, steam or gas supply pipes from street mains. 
(a)  All persons supplying water, steam or gas to customers from mains on the streets of the city, through supply pipes introduced into their property, shall fit such supply pipes with suitable and proper stopcocks, under the sidewalks next to the curb or outer edge of such curb. 
(b)  A violation of any provision of this section shall constitute a class 2 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1981, § 32-8) 
Sec. 98-9. - Removal of encroachments. 
    In every case of an encroachment upon a sidewalk or street by a building, fence or other thing, the city manager shall require the owner thereof to remove the building, fence or other thing. For failure to make such removal within the time ordered, such owner shall be guilty of a class 4 misdemeanor and the city manager may cause such encroachment to be removed at the risk and cost of such owner. 
(Code 1981, § 32-9) 
Sec. 98-10. - Obstructions generally. 
(a)  Any person who shall cause any unlawful obstruction in any public street, sidewalk, gutter or bridge, or in any culvert or drain, public or private, shall, unless otherwise specifically provided, be guilty of a class 3 misdemeanor. Each day that any person shall fail or refuse to comply with the provisions of this section, after 24 hours from the time of being notified by the director of public works or designee to do so, shall constitute a separate offense. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the director of public works to cause all obstructions to be removed from the public streets, sidewalks and bridges and from culverts and drains, public or private, either by the person causing such obstruction or otherwise, as the exigency of the case may require. If any person causing an obstruction shall fail to remove the obstruction after being notified to do so by the director of public works or designee, it shall be the duty of the director of public works to have the removal done at the expense of the city. In every such case, and also in every case where an obstruction is removed by the director of public works, or by order of the director of public works or designee, the city shall be reimbursed for its expenses for removal and any fees associated with current landfill rates, billable to the owner of the property which sum shall be collected as fines are collected. 
(Code 1981, § 32-10; Ord. No. 12-66, 10-2-2012; Ord. No. 13-06, 1-22-2013) 
Sec. 98-11. - Damage or obstruction to street or sidewalk resulting from defective walls, etc., or demolition of walls, etc. 
    If any sidewalk or street shall be damaged or obstructed by reason of the wall or other part of any lot or building on the street being out of repair or being demolished, such damage or obstruction shall be subject to all the provisions of subsection 98-10(b). 
(Code 1981, § 32-12) 
Sec. 98-12. - Overhead utility facilities prohibited on portion of Sycamore Street. 
(a)  No overhead utility facilities, including electric, telephone, telegraph, CATV and fire alarm facilities, shall be installed or maintained on Sycamore Street, between Wythe and Bank Streets. Temporary overhead facilities may be permitted by special permission of the city in such designated area of Sycamore Street in cases of emergency. All such facilities shall be constructed in accordance with standard utility practices. 
(b)  A violation of this section shall constitute a class 3 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1981, § 32-15) 
Sec. 98-13. - Signs or flags over streets and sidewalks. 
(a)  No sign shall be hung, kept in place, maintained or erected over any street or sidewalk within the city, nor shall any flag or sign in the nature of a flag be hung or remain across any street within the city, without the permission of the city manager. The city manager may grant such permission when the street or sidewalk will be kept open to normal public travel, free from obstruction, interference, or fire hazards, reduced visibility or light, or other danger. 
(b)  No sign shall be hung, kept in place, maintained or erected over any street or sidewalk within the city, unless the owner or tenant of the building or structure to which such sign is or may be attached shall have secured and deposited with the city manager a policy of insurance against public liability and property damage, issued by some solvent insurance company licensed and duly authorized to execute such policies within the state, or a proper certificate of such insurance company showing that such owner or tenant has obtained such policy, insuring the city against liability for bodily injuries, including death, in an amount of at least $300,000.00 for injury to any one person or $500,000.00 for injuries arising out of any one accident, and against liability for property damage in an amount of at least $25,000.00 for any one accident, where such liability arises out of the erection, maintenance or presence of any such sign or on account of any damages or injuries caused thereby. Such policy of insurance shall contain a clause obligating the company issuing the policy to give ten days' written notice to the city manager before cancellation thereof. In lieu of such policy of insurance the owner or tenant of such building or other structure shall be permitted to enter into a bond, with surety satisfactory to the city manager and in a form approved by the city attorney, payable to the city with conditions therein similar to the conditions provided in this subsection with respect to such policies of insurance. 
(c)  Every sign or flag in the nature of a sign that is hung, erected or maintained in violation of this section shall be deemed an obstruction within the meaning of subsection 98-10(b). 
(d)  A violation of any provision of this section shall constitute a class 2 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1981, § 32-16) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to regulate signs etc., over public rights-of-way, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2010. 
Sec. 98-14. - Packing or unpacking goods on street or sidewalk. 
(a)  No person shall deposit on any street or sidewalk of the city any boxes, barrels, hogsheads or packages in which goods are received, for the purpose of packing or unpacking such goods on such street or sidewalk, unless they shall have been broken in transit or are too large to be put through the cellar doors of the sidewalk or passageway of the stores, in which case, the person so unpacking on the sidewalk or street shall consume as little time as possible in so doing, and shall, as soon as the goods are unpacked, remove all trash, dirt and boxes incident to such unpacking. 
(b)  A violation of any provision of this section shall constitute a class 2 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1981, § 32-19) 
Cross reference- Traffic and vehicles, ch. 110. 
Sec. 98-15. - Stands, trucks, etc., on streets for display or sale of merchandise, purchase, etc. 
(a)  No person shall erect, place, park, station, hold, keep or maintain any stand or other structure, whether on wheels or not, or any kind of container, or any truck, automobile, cart, wagon or other vehicle of any kind whatsoever, at any place on the streets of the city, for the display or sale of goods, wares, merchandise or produce. Persons duly licensed as hucksters or peddlers and persons exempt from obtaining a peddler's license under the provisions of Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3717, while engaged in selling or soliciting from door to door, shall be permitted to park their vehicles in a lawful manner upon the streets for such length of time as may be reasonably necessary to permit them to sell to, or solicit, persons residing in the immediate vicinity of the place at which any such vehicle may be parked. 
(b)  A violation of any provision of this section shall constitute a class 2 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1981, § 32-21) 
Sec. 98-16. - Dispensing gasoline on street or sidewalk. 
    It shall be unlawful and a class 2 misdemeanor for any person to permit a gasoline dispensing device to occupy any street, sidewalk or other public way, or to dispense gasoline to a vehicle standing in a street. 
(Code 1981, § 32-22) 
Sec. 98-17. - Gutters and snowbreaks for buildings along streets. 
(a)  Every building, the eaves of which drop water on the sidewalk of any street or alley, or within 18 inches thereof, shall be furnished with gutters and conductors, on the side next to such street or alley, to carry off rain water, and also with suitable eaves, or upright boards, along the edge of the roof to prevent snow from sliding from the roof and falling upon the streets, alleys or sidewalks. Where the sidewalk is paved, the spout of such conductor shall be discharged in the street gutter through a terracotta, iron or other suitable drain under the sidewalk, covered either with pavement of the same character and quality as that of the sidewalk, or with an iron cover roughened so as to prevent slipping. If the sidewalk is not paved, a covered or open drain sufficient to carry the rain water shall be laid from the spout across the sidewalk to the street gutter, and in case of an open drain, such drain and ground under the spout of such conductor shall be covered with stone or brick, so as to prevent injury to the sidewalk. 
(b)  A violation of this section shall constitute a class 4 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1981, § 32-28) 
Sec. 98-18. - Barriers on retaining walls for embankments abutting street or sidewalk. 
    Whenever earth embankments abut on any street or sidewalk, it shall be the duty of the owner of the property in question to erect suitable barriers or retaining walls to prevent loose mud or earth from falling on such street or sidewalk. Any violation of this section shall constitute a class 4 misdemeanor, and if any person fails to conform hereto within a reasonable time after being notified to do so by the city manager or director of public works, each day of failure shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(Code 1981, § 32-29) 
Sec. 98-19. - Enclosure of dangerous places below grade of adjoining street. 
    All dangerous places below the grade of the adjoining street shall be enclosed with proper fences or walls, and should the owner fail to conform to the provisions of this section, within a reasonable time after being notified to do so by the city manager or the director of public works, he shall be guilty of a class 2 misdemeanor and each day of such failure shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(Code 1981, § 32-30) 
Sec. 98-20. - Emptying slop or wastewater in streets.
