    It shall be unlawful and a class 4 misdemeanor for any person to empty or cause to be emptied, into the streets or street gutters or drains, any slop or wastewater of any kind. 
(Code 1981, § 32-32) 
Sec. 98-21. - Deposit of hazardous or injurious material on street or sidewalk; removal. 
(a)  No person shall throw or deposit, or cause to be deposited, upon any street or sidewalk within the city, any glass bottle, glass, nail, tack, wire, can or other substance or material likely to injure any person or animal or damage any vehicle upon such street or sidewalk, nor shall any person throw or deposit, or cause to be deposited, upon any street or sidewalk, any soil, sand, mud, gravel or other substance, so as to create a hazard to the traveling public. 
(b)  Any person who drops, or permits to be dropped or thrown, upon any street or sidewalk, any destructive, hazardous or injurious material shall immediately remove such material or cause it to be removed. If any such person shall fail to remove such destructive, hazardous or injurious material immediately, the material may be removed by the city and the expense thereof shall be paid to the city by the person who failed to remove the material, which sum shall be collected as fines are collected. 
(c)  Any person removing a wrecked or damaged vehicle from a street shall remove any glass or other injurious substance dropped upon such street from such vehicle. 
(d)  Any person violating this section shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1981, § 32-33) 
Cross reference- Environment, ch. 50. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-324. 
Sec. 98-22. - Duty of property owners and occupants to cut grass and other vegetation between sidewalk and curbline and roadside ditches. 
(a)  Where grass, weeds or other vegetable matter grows between any sidewalk and the curbline, and roadside ditches, it shall be the duty of the occupant of any land or premises abutting upon such sidewalk and ditches to have such grass, weeds and other vegetable matter cut to prevent such space from becoming unsightly or offensive. If any such land or premises is unoccupied, it shall be the duty of the owner thereof to have such grass, weeds or other vegetable matter cut as provided in this section. 
(b)  The director of public works or designee shall give a 48-hour notice of the provisions of this section to any occupant or owner and shall cause the provisions of this section to be enforced. 
(c)  Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a class 3 misdemeanor and each day that grass, weeds or other vegetable matter shall remain uncut after notice to cut such grass, weeds or other vegetable matter shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1981, § 32-36; Ord. No. 12-66, 10-2-2012; Ord. No. 13-06, 1-22-2013) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to require removal of weeds from private and public property, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1115. 
Sec. 98-23. - Dangerous, diseased or decayed trees near parks, school grounds, streets or sidewalks. 
    No property owner shall maintain or allow to remain, on his property within the city, any dangerous, diseased or decayed tree near enough to any park, park place, school ground, sidewalk or street within the city to endanger the safety of persons making lawful use of such park, park place, school ground, sidewalk or street. Any property owner having any such tree on his premises shall be notified, in writing, by the city manager or the director of parks and grounds to remove such tree within a reasonable time, to be specified in such notice. Upon failure of the property owner to comply with such notice, he shall be summoned before the judge of the general district court and, if found guilty of violating the provisions of this section, shall be ordered to remove such tree, at his cost, within a reasonable time to be specified in the order. If the property owner fails to remove the tree within the time thus specified, he shall be guilty of a class 4 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1981, § 21-57) 
Sec. 98-24. - Crossing curb and gutter with vehicle. 
(a)  No person shall cross any curb and gutter in the city with any vehicle except at established driveways, unless with the approval in writing of the director of public works. Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a class 3 misdemeanor and, in addition, shall be held responsible for any damage to the curb and gutter. 
(b)  In any provision charging a violation of this section, proof that the vehicle was located on property that is adjacent to curb and gutter with no established driveways, together with proof that the defendant was at the time the registered owner of the vehicle, shall constitute in evidence a prima facie presumption that the registered owner of the vehicle was the person who committed the violation. 
(Ord. No. 03-80, 11-18-2003) 
Secs. 98-25-98-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - STREET AND CITY BUILDING NAMES; STREET NUMBERS FOR BUILDINGS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Authority of city to name street, roads and alleys, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2019. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 98-51. - City street and city building names, changes thereto. 
(a)  In order to further the public health, safety and welfare, the city council shall name new city streets and new city buildings, and existing city streets and city buildings that have not been previously named. The city council may, whenever it deems advisable, change the name of city streets and city buildings. Prior to the naming or renaming of a street, the proposed name shall be forwarded to the appropriate regional authority to avoid duplication of street names within the region. 
(b)  In determining the names of city streets and city buildings, consideration shall be given to local citizens who have made positive contributions to the city. 
(c)  Reserved. 
(d)  Any citizen (hereinafter "petitioner") interested in renaming streets within the City of Petersburg must file a request with the director of public works, or his/her agent, which shall include: 
(1)  The current street name, the proposed street name, a contact name and number (address, phone number and email address if available), reason for the change; 
(2)  Statement that the petitioner agrees to pay all costs associated with the request, including the cost of new street sign(s); 
(3)  An administrative fee of $200.00, due upon completion and submission of the application (this fee shall not be waived); 
(4)  A map showing the location of the street; and 
(5)  A listing of property owner's affected by the proposed street name and their addresses. Affected property owners include owners of all properties that abut the street in question whether containing an occupied dwelling or not. 
(e)  The request for a name change must be approved by 100 percent of all affected property owners. 
(f)  If the name change has 100 percent approval, the request will then go before city council for a public hearing. 
(g)  Upon approval by city council, the street name change will not be effective for 60 days so that sign costs can be paid by the petitioner and the signs can be fabricated and posted. Petitioner has no more than six months from the date of council approval to provide full payment. 
(h)  If the six months elapse, the permit will no longer be valid and a new application request must be submitted. No refunds will be given for failure to meet the six-month deadline. 
(i)  The director of public works, or his/her agent, shall notify all affected property owners, and all applicable entities, to include city departments, the post office, and utility companies, of the street name change and effective date. A notice will be placed in the local newspaper and on the city website to make city residents aware of the change. 
(j)  Failure of the director of public works to notify all entities and owners shall not void city council approval. 
(k)  The street names established under this section shall take precedence over any other designation except those primary highways conforming to Code of Virginia, § 33.1-12, and shall be employed in references to property abutting thereon. 
(Code 1981, § 2-11; Ord. No. 14-24, 4-15-2014) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia § 15.2-2019. 
Secs. 98-52-98-70. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - STREET NAMES 

Sec. 98-71. - Subdivisions of city; dividing lines. 
(a)  Sycamore Street shall be the line dividing the city into east and west from Old Street to the junction of South Sycamore Street and South Crater Road, from which junction to the southern city limits South Crater Road shall be the east-west division street. Washington Street shall be the line dividing the city into north and south. From the eastern terminus of Washington Street, the line dividing the city into north and south shall be a line running due east from the centerline of the street at such terminus. The four subdivisions shall be called "northwest," "northeast," "southeast" and "southwest" respectively, with reference to the intersection of Sycamore and Washington Streets. 
(b)  That part of Sycamore Street north of Washington Street shall be called North Sycamore Street and that part of it south of Washington Street shall be called South Sycamore Street. That part of Washington Street east of Sycamore Street shall be called East Washington Street and that part of it west of Sycamore Street shall be called West Washington Street. 
(Code 1981, § 32-49) 
Cross reference- Subdivisions, ch. 102. 
Sec. 98-72. - East and west and north and south streets. 
    All streets coming into or crossing Sycamore Street shall be called east or west, respectively, as they may run east or west from such street. All streets coming into or crossing Washington Street shall be called north or south, respectively, as they may run north or south from such street. 
(Code 1981, § 32-50) 
Secs. 98-73-98-90. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - STREET NUMBERS FOR BUILDINGS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 22. 

Sec. 98-91. - Laying off and numbering of street spaces generally. 
(a)  The director of public works shall lay off each street in the city into 20-foot or 25-foot spaces, beginning at the intersection of Sycamore and Washington Streets, or at the terminus of streets nearest one of those streets. Such spaces shall be numbered in succession as provided in this article and shall be used as the street address of the property. 
(b)  When the director of public works lays off spaces, as provided in this section, he shall make a record thereof and file a copy in his office. 
(Code 1981, § 32-51) 
Sec. 98-92. - Method of numbering street spaces. 
    The spaces provided for in section 98-91 shall be numbered upon the centenary plan. Beginning at the east side of Sycamore Street and going east, the spaces on streets intersecting or crossing Sycamore Street, or running in the same general direction, shall be numbered from one upward. Beginning at the west side of Sycamore Street and going westward, the spaces on all streets intersecting or crossing Sycamore Street, or running in the same general direction, shall be numbered from one upward. Beginning at the north side of Washington Street and going northward, the spaces on all streets intersecting or crossing Washington Street, or running in the same general direction, shall be numbered from one upward. Beginning at the south side of Washington Street and going southward, the spaces on all streets intersecting or crossing Washington Street, or running in the same general direction,shall be numbered from one upward. A new hundred shall be begun whenever an intersecting street is crossed, not counting intersecting lanes and alleys. When one street does not intersect or intersects, but does not cross another and it is inconvenient to apply the centenary plan, the numbering shall conform as near thereto as convenient, making the corresponding numbers parallel streets as near opposite each other as may be practicable. The odd numbers beginning with one shall be given to spaces on the right-hand side of the street looking north or west, as the case may be, from the intersection of Sycamore and Washington Streets, in the direction in which the numbering is to proceed, and the even numbers shall be given to spaces on the left-hand side of the street looking in the same direction. Looking in the opposite direction, the odd numbers beginning with one shall be given to spaces on the left-hand side and even numbers shall be given to spaces on the right-hand side. 
(Code 1981, § 32-52) 
Sec. 98-93. - Numbering on streets which do not run into or cross dividing lines. 
    All streets which do not run into or cross either Sycamore Street or Washington Street shall be numbered thus: If they have a direction north or south and are north of Washington Street, the numbering shall commence at their southern extremity, and if south of that street, at their northern extremity. All streets which do not run into or cross Sycamore Street shall be numbered thus: If they have a direction east and west and are east of Sycamore Street, the numbering shall commence at their western extremity, and if west of that street, the numbering shall commence at their eastern extremity. The first number on each street that does not run into or cross either Sycamore Street or Washington Street shall be as many hundreds, plus one, as there are squares between it and one of the before-mentioned streets. 
(Code 1981, § 32-53) 
Sec. 98-94. - Duty of property owners to obtain street address and number buildings. 
(a)  When any building is built or erected in the city, the owner shall obtain from the director of public works a street address prior to the completion of construction. When a property owner occupies more than one space, he may, at his option, receive any or all of the numbers of all the spaces which, or the greater part of which, he occupies. When any property owner occupies less than half of a lot, or less than half of each of two adjoining lots, he shall receive the number of the lot first reached in affixing the number, plus one-half. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the director of public works or his authorized agent to assign a street address to every existing main structure within the corporate limits of the city. 
(c)  It shall be the duty of the property owner to conspicuously place street address numbers on, above or at the side of the main entrance door of such structure, so that the number is plainly visible from the public right-of-way. When the entrance is not clearly visible from the public right-of-way, the number shall be placed at the walk, driveway or other suitable location that is easily discernable from the public right-of-way. Numbers shall be in Arabic numbers and shall not be less than three inches in height and of a durable and clearly visible material. The numbers shall be of a high-contrasting color with the surface upon which they are placed and may be in either horizontal or vertical order. 
(d)  The failure of any owner of a building to follow any provision of this section within 90 days after a number has been assigned shall constitute a class 4 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1981, § 32-54) 
Secs. 98-95-98-120. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SIDEWALKS 

Sec. 98-121. - Cellar doors and vaults in sidewalks. 
(a)  Not more than three feet of any public sidewalk, next to the wall, shall be occupied by any cellar door, which door shall, in all cases, be on a level with the sidewalk and shall not be enclosed with a railing or otherwise. All such doors shall be kept closed except when in actual use and shall then be carefully guarded so as to prevent accidents. 
(b)  Every owner of a building on a street which has a cellar door or vault in a public sidewalk shall keep such cellar door or vault in good repair. For failure to repair such door or vault within three days after being notified so to do by the city manager, the director of public works or a police officer, such owner shall be guilty of a class 3 misdemeanor and every day that shall elapse thereafter, without the door or vault being repaired, shall constitute a separate offense. If such owner shall fail, for five days after such notice, to repair such door or vault, it shall be the duty of the city manager or the director of public works to repair such door or vault at the expense of the city, which shall be reimbursed for its expenses by such owner. If there are several owners of any such building, it shall be sufficient to give the notice to any one of them. If the owner resides out of the city, the notice may be given to his agent or to the occupant of the building. 
(c)  Notwithstanding any other provision of this section, it shall be unlawful for any person to construct or install any new cellar door in any public sidewalk in the city after February 1, 1982. 
(d)  A violation of any provision of this section shall constitute a class 3 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1981, § 32-11) 
Sec. 98-122. - Gates and doors in fences or walls opening across sidewalk. 
    Every gate or door in any fence or wall along the line of any street shall either open inwardly from the line of the street or there shall be attached to it a swing of sufficient weight, or it shall be hung upon hinges in such manner, as to keep it closed so that such gate or door shall not be allowed to stand open upon the sidewalk. Any agent, renter or owner of property who shall violate any provision of this section shall be guilty of a class 4 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1981, § 32-13) 
Sec. 98-123. - Awnings, sheds, etc., over sidewalks. 
(a)  No awning, frame, shed or other projection shall be placed or maintained over any sidewalk of any street within the city, unless every part of such awning, frame, shed or other projection, except the curtain of cloth or other material, including any fringe or other portion thereof, is at least seven feet above the surface of the sidewalk, and unless such curtain of cloth or other material, including any fringe or other portion thereof, is at least 61/2 feet above the surface of the sidewalk. Every such awning, frame, shed or other projection shall be supported by iron brackets extending from the building to which such awning, frame, shed or other projection is fastened. 
(b)  Every awning, frame, shed or other projection not conforming to the requirements of this section shall be deemed to be an obstruction within the meaning of subsection 98-10(b). 
(c)  A violation of any provision of this section shall constitute a class 2 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1981, § 32-14) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to regulate awnings, etc., over public rights-of-way, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2010. 
Sec. 98-124. - Storing or displaying merchandise or maintaining advertising signs on sidewalks. 
(a)  No person shall place, keep or store, or exhibit or display for sale, any goods, wares or merchandise, or maintain any advertising signs, on the sidewalks of the city. 
(b)  This section shall not be construed as requiring the removal of any sign or object used for advertising, attached to the front wall of a building and projecting no more than 12 inches therefrom, or as requiring the removal of any pole or post on which a sign or other object used for advertising shall be maintained; provided, that such pole or post shall be in the line of telephone, telegraph or electric lines on the street on which such pole or post is located; and provided, that the sign or other object used for advertising was erected prior to May 20, 1941. 
(c)  A violation of this section shall constitute a class 2 misdemeanor. 
(d)  This section shall not apply to sidewalk sales conducted by licensed retail establishments located adjacent to the sidewalk, at times and places authorized in writing by the city manager, at his discretion, upon the request of such retail establishment or organization representing the interests of several establishments. Such authorization of the city manager shall preserve adequate space for pedestrian traffic, and no such authorization shall be granted for any particular place more than four continuous time periods in any one calendar year. 
(Code 1981, § 32-17) 
Cross reference- Advertising, ch. 6. 
Sec. 98-125. - Use of sidewalks for receiving and delivering merchandise. 
(a)  Nothing in section 98-124 shall prevent the use of the sidewalks upon any of the streets of the city for the purpose of receiving or delivering goods, wares or merchandise, upon or from the abutting property. Only so much of a sidewalk as may be necessary for this purpose shall be so used. A sufficient passageway shall at all times be kept open and clear of any obstructions, and such sidewalk shall be used for such purposes for such time only as may be necessary for the purpose of receiving or delivering such goods, wares or merchandise. 
(b)  Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a class 4 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1981, § 32-18) 
Sec. 98-126. - Planting of shade trees on sidewalks. 
(a)  No person shall plant any shade tree on any sidewalk of the city, without first obtaining a permit so to do from the city manager. The city manager may, when there will be no interference with the abutting owner's right of ingress and egress, and subject to the provisions of this section, grant such permit; provided, however, that no permit shall be granted for the planting of any shade tree on a sidewalk on the following streets or portions thereof: 
(1)  Sycamore Street, from Washington Street to Old Street. 
(2)  Bank Street. 
(3)  Short Market Street. 
(4)  Bollingbrook Street, from Sycamore Street to Second Street. 
(5)  Lombard Street, from Sycamore Street to Second Street. 
(b)  No permit required by this section shall be granted until the applicant files with the city manager the written consent of the abutting landowners to plant the trees. 
(c)  A permit granted under this section shall authorize the holder thereof to make proper and suitable excavations in the sidewalk, of such size and depth, and in such manner, as is prescribed by the director of public works. The permit holder shall keep each such excavation properly guarded to prevent accidents, until the excavation is properly filled, and no such excavation shall be left open at night. 
(d)  Any person violating this section shall be guilty of a class 4 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1981, § 32-24) 
Sec. 98-127. - Protection of sidewalks when building being erected. 
    All sidewalks in front of buildings in the course of erection shall be securely protected against materials falling from the structure or scaffolding. A violation of this section shall constitute a class 2 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1981, § 32-25) 
Sec. 98-128. - Duty of property owners or occupants to construct driveways across sidewalks. 
    On every paved or partially paved street, of a width of 25 feet or more, where premises are entered in such a manner as to make it necessary to cross the sidewalk with vehicles or pedestrian traffic, the owner or occupant of such premises shall construct a suitable crossing, of the same width as the sidewalk and of material and in manner approved by the director of public works pursuant to uniform city standards. If the owner of occupant of such premises neglects or refuses to construct such crossing, the city manager may direct the director of public works to cause such crossing to be constructed, and unless the cost thereof is paid by the owner or occupant of the premises, upon demand made upon him by the director of public works, the director of public works shall report to the director of finance, in writing, the amount with which such owner or occupant is charged, and the amount shall be collected in the same manner as city taxes are collected, together with a penalty of 20 percent, or the city manager may give notice to the owner or occupant of such premises and require him to construct such crossing, and if such owner or occupant shall fail so to do within ten days after such notice is given, he shall be guilty of a class 4 misdemeanor and each day, after such period of ten days, during which such crossing is not constructed, shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1981, § 32-26) 
Sec. 98-129. - Drainage across sidewalks generally. 
(a)  No water from any lot, gutter or spout shall be permitted to flow across any sidewalk, whether paved or not, except in a covered drain, the cover of which shall not be above the surface of the sidewalk, or, when required by the director of public works pursuant to uniform city standards, in a paved gutter, either of which shall be of sufficient capacity to convey the water to be discharged by it, and shall be built, kept open and in good repair by the owner or occupant of the premises from whence it proceeds. 
(b)  Any owner or occupant violating this section shall be guilty of a class 4 misdemeanor. If the owner or occupant shall, after due notice, fail to comply with the requirements of this section, the director of public works may order the work to be done and report the costs to the director of finance, who shall cause such costs to be collected from such owner or occupant. 
(Code 1981, § 32-27) 
Sec. 98-130. - Skating. 
(a)  No person, except children under 12 years of age, shall skate on any of the sidewalks of the city nor shall the parent or guardian of any minor over that age permit such minor so to do. 
(b)  Any person violating this section shall be guilty of a class 4 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1981, § 32-34) 
Sec. 98-131. - Duty of property owners and occupants to keep sidewalks clean. 
    It shall be unlawful and a class 4 misdemeanor for the occupant, owner or agent in charge of any lot in the city to permit the accumulation of leaves, wastepaper or other litter on the sidewalks in front of or abutting upon such property for a period of more than 24 hours, or to sweep or otherwise move such leaves, wastepaper or other litter across or off any sidewalk into any street or other public place. 
(Code 1981, § 32-35) 
Sec. 98-132. - Removal of snow, ice or sleet from sidewalks. 
(a)  Snow, ice or sleet in front of and along the boundaries of all buildings or lots which abut on paved streets within the limits of the city shall be cleaned from the public sidewalks by the occupants of such buildings or lots, within four hours after the snow or sleet ceases to fall or the ice ceases to form, unless the snow or sleet fell or the ice formed during the night, in which case it shall be removed by 12:00 noon on the following day, Sundays excepted. If any such building or lot is unoccupied, it shall be the duty of the owner or the person having charge thereof to comply with the requirements of this section. 
(b)  If ice or sleet on any public sidewalk cannot be removed without injury to such sidewalk, the sidewalk shall be covered, by the persons and within the period of time specified in subsection (a) of this section, with sand, ashes or some other substance which will render the sidewalk safe for use. 
(c)  Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a class 4 misdemeanor for each day of 24 hours during which the conditions prohibited by this section are allowed to remain, and if such snow, ice or sleet is not removed by the persons whose duty it is to remove the snow, ice or sleet, or if such ice or sleet is not covered as required by this section, the city manager shall cause the necessary work to be done in accordance with the provisions of subsection 98-10(b) relating to the removal of obstructions from public streets. 
(Code 1981, § 32-37) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to require removal of snow from sidewalks, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1115. 
Secs. 98-133-98-150. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - EXCAVATIONS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 98-151. - Definition. 
    For the purposes of this article, the word "excavation" shall mean any opening, caused by breaking, digging or any other means, in any street, alley or sidewalk of the city. 
(Code 1981, § 32-67) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 98-152. - Violations of article. 
    Unless otherwise specifically provided, a violation of any provision of this article shall constitute a class 2 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1981, § 32-66) 
Sec. 98-153. - Filling of trenches; notice of completion of work; barriers and lights. 
    Any person who makes any excavation in any portion of any street, alley or sidewalk shall fill the trenches immediately upon the completion of the work and ram the earth well and properly, under the supervision of the director of public works or his representative. The director of public works shall then be notified by such person that the work is ready for paving or repairing, and until such time as the city takes charge of the work, not more than three days after such notice, the person doing the work, or causing it to be done, shall protect the excavation by the erection of sufficient barriers, and place and keep sufficient lights burning around and over the excavation, to enable all persons passing to see and avoid it. 
(Code 1981, § 32-73) 
Secs. 98-154-98-170. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 98-171. - Required; deposit. 
    No person shall make or cause to be made any excavation in any portion of a street, alley or sidewalk, without having first obtained a permit so to do from the director of public works and without having first paid to the collector of city taxes such sums of money as the director of public works shall determine to be sufficient to secure the permanent repair and replacement of such street, alley or sidewalk by the city, which deposit shall not be returned. 
(Code 1981, § 32-68; Ord. No. 17-30, 7-11-2017) 
Sec. 98-172. - Permit not to be granted within five years after street paved. 
    The director of public works shall not grant a permit for the making of any excavation, for any purpose, in the pavement of any street, within five years after the completion of such pavement or its acceptance by the city. 
(Code 1981, § 32-69) 
Sec. 98-173. - Permit to be kept at site and exhibited upon demand. 
    Any person making an excavation pursuant to a permit granted under this article shall keep the permit at the site of the excavation and exhibit it, upon demand, to any police officer or representative of the director of public works. Upon failure to exhibit the permit, the work shall be ordered suspended. 
(Code 1981, § 32-72) 
Secs. 98-174-98-190. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - BOND 

Sec. 98-191. - Persons engaged in business requiring excavations. 
(a)  No permit required by this article shall be issued to any person engaged in any business that requires the making of excavations in streets, sidewalks or alleys, unless such person has executed to the city a bond, with the premium paid for one year in advance, approved by the city attorney, in the penalty of $1,000.00, with some surety company authorized to do business in the state as surety, conditioned that the provisions of this chapter be complied with and also to indemnify and save the city harmless against any damage which it may suffer or become liable for by reason of failure to conform to or comply with this article, and on account of any injury which may be caused to any person or property by reason of such failure. 
(b)  When a bond required by this section is approved by the city attorney, he shall transmit it to the director of finance to be filed in his office, and notify the director of public works, in writing, of its execution, giving the date thereof with the names of the principal and surety therein. The director of public works shall register all such bonds, with their dates and the names of the principals and sureties therein. 
(c)  The bond required by this section shall continue in force and both the principal and surety thereon shall be bound thereby until they, or one of them, shall notify the director of public works, at least 30 days in advance, of the date when such bond will be cancelled, or until a permit issued under this article is revoked by the director of public works, and thereafter as to all liability incurred thereunder until such liability shall have been discharged. 
(d)  After the expiration of each year from the date of a bond required by this section, no permit required by this article shall be given to the principal obligor, until he has filed with the director of public works a certificate from his surety that he has paid an additional premium for such bond for a period of one year. When such certificate is so filed, the director of public works shall note the filing, and the period it embraces, opposite the entry of the bond to which it applies, and transmit the certificate to the director of finance, who shall file the certificate with the bond. 
(Code 1981, § 32-70) 
Sec. 98-192. - Persons not engaged in business requiring excavations. 
(a)  Every person not engaged in a business referred to in section 98-191, who desires to make an excavation in any street, sidewalk or alley opposite his premises, for any purpose in connection with the use or occupancy of his premises, and who does not employ, to do such work, a person who has given the bond required by section 98-191, shall execute to the city a bond, approved by the city attorney, in the penalty of $50.00, with good security, conditioned to save harmless and indemnify the city against any accident that may occur in connection with such work and against any damage it may suffer or become liable for by reason of the failure of such person to do such work, or on account of any injury which may be caused to any person or property by reason of such failure. 
(b)  No permit required by this article shall be granted to any person to whom this section is applicable, until he has complied with this section. 
(Code 1981, § 32-71) 
Secs. 98-193-98-210. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - SNOW-MELTING AND LAWN-WATERING DEVICES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 98-211. - Definition. 
    For the purposes of this article, the word "devices" shall mean pipes, conduits or wires installed below the surface of a street or sidewalk for snow-melting or lawn-watering purposes. 
(Code 1981, § 32-87) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 98-212. - Violations of article. 
    A violation of any provision of this article shall constitute a class 2 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1981, § 32-86) 
Sec. 98-213. - Performance by city of permit holder's obligations under article. 
    Upon the failure, refusal or neglect of a person holding a permit under this article to comply with the provisions of this article, the city shall have the right to perform such person's obligations under this article, at such person's cost and expense, without liability to such person for damages sustained on account thereof. 
(Code 1981, § 32-92) 
Sec. 98-214. - Plans and specifications for installation. 
    The installation of devices pursuant to a permit issued under this article shall be according to plans and specifications approved by the director of public works pursuant to uniform city standards. 
(Code 1981, § 32-93) 
Sec. 98-215. - Maintenance. 
    Every person to whom a permit is issued under this article shall at all times keep the devices authorized by such permit in proper repair and shall make repairs thereto from time to time as the director of public works shall deem necessary, with materials and in a manner satisfactory to the director, for the safety of persons and property using or occupying the public streets and sidewalks of the city. 
(Code 1981, § 32-94) 
Sec. 98-216. - Protection of utilities. 
    When, because of the construction, reconstruction, repair, maintenance, operation, existence or removal of devices, the public utility of a corporation that has been granted a franchise or permit by the city to use the public streets and sidewalks of the city for its purposes is disturbed or in any way affected thereby, the person to whom the permit was issued under this article shall reconstruct, repair or replace the utility in a manner satisfactory to and under the supervision of such corporation. 
(Code 1981, § 32-95) 
Cross reference- Utilities, ch. 114. 
Sec. 98-217. - Removal to accommodate city work. 
    A person to whom a permit is issued under this article shall immediately remove the devices should they interfere with any work program of the city, when so requested by the director of public works, and shall resurface the sidewalk area with materials and in a manner that will restore such sidewalk area to a condition that is at least the quality of its former condition, as determined by the director of public works. 
(Code 1981, § 32-96) 
Secs. 98-218-98-235. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 98-236. - Permit to install, repair, etc. 
    No person shall install, construct, reconstruct, repair, maintain or remove any devices for the purposes mentioned in section 98-211 until a permit so to do has been issued by the director of public works. Any such permit issued shall reserve to the director of public works the right to revoke the permit if the work shall not, in all respects, conform to the provisions of this article and all other provisions of this Code and other ordinances relating thereto and the standards now or hereafter established and enforced by the city. 
(Code 1981, § 32-88) 
Sec. 98-237. - Indemnification of city generally. 
    Every person to whom a permit is issued under this article shall indemnify, reimburse and save the city harmless from all charges, damages or costs that the city may be required to pay or otherwise sustain by reason of the construction, reconstruction, repair, maintenance, operation, existence or removal of the devices and by reason of any person being injured or damaged in any way, in person or property, by the construction, reconstruction, repair, maintenance, operation, existence or removal of the devices; and in the event that suit is brought against the city, either independently or jointly with the permit holder, on account thereof, the permit holder shall defend the city in any such suit at the cost of the permit holder, and in the event of a final judgment being obtained against the city, either independently or jointly with the permit holder, the permit holder shall pay such judgment, with all costs, and hold the city harmless therefrom. 
(Code 1981, § 32-89) 
Sec. 98-238. - Permit holder's insurance. 
    Every person to whom a permit is issued under this article shall furnish the city a liability insurance contract to indemnify, reimburse and hold the city harmless from all charges, damages or costs that the city may be required to pay or otherwise sustain by reason of the construction, reconstruction, repair, maintenance, operation, existence and removal of the devices. The contract shall be for not less than $100,000.00 to cover the injury to or death of one person and $300,000.00 to cover the injury to or death of more than one person in any one accident, together with property damage coverage of not less than $50,000.00. The contract shall be approved by the city attorney. The permit holder shall pay all premiums chargeable for the contract and shall keep the contract in full force and effect at all times during the construction, existence and removal of the devices. The contract shall contain a provision that it shall not be terminated or otherwise allowed to expire prior to 60 days after written notice to that effect is given the director of public works. 
(Code 1981, § 32-90) 
Sec. 98-239. - Permit holder's bond. 
    Every person to whom a permit is issued under this article shall furnish the city a bond, with corporate surety approved by the city attorney, in the sum of $5,000.00, conditioned upon the removal of the devices and replacement and restoration of the sidewalk area and any public utility therein damaged, disturbed or destroyed thereby, in a manner satisfactory to the director of public works, when ordered so to do by the director of public works or upon repeal of this article or upon the failure, refusal or neglect of the permit holder to comply fully and in all respects with the provisions of this article or any other provision of this Code or any other ordinance relative thereto. The permit holder shall pay all premiums chargeable for the bond and shall keep the bond in full force and effect at all times during the existence and removal of the devices and replacement and installation of the sidewalk area and any public utility therein damaged, disturbed or destroyed thereby. The bond shall contain a provision that it shall not be terminated or otherwise allowed to expire prior to 60 days after written notice to that effect is given the director of public works. 
(Code 1981, § 32-91) 
Secs. 98-240-98-260. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - PARADES; PROCESSIONS; DEMONSTRATIONS; PERFORMANCES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 98-261. - Violations of article. 
    Any person violating any provision of this article shall be guilty of a class 2 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1981, § 32-109) 
Sec. 98-262. - Funeral processions exempt from article. 
    The provisions of this article shall not be construed to apply to funeral processions. 
(Code 1981, § 32-108) 
Secs. 98-263-98-280. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 98-281. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to promote, organize or hold, or to assist in organizing or holding, or to take part or participate in, any parade, procession or other public demonstration, or to perform as an organ grinder, bagpipe blower, violin, guitar or mandolin player, or the like, on the streets or other public ways of the city, unless a permit therefor has been secured from the chief of police. 
(Code 1981, § 32-121) 
Sec. 98-282. - Application and fee. 
(a)  Any person desiring a permit required by this division shall file a written application therefor with the chief of police, setting forth: 
(1)  The hour and date of the proposed parade, procession, demonstration or performance; 
(2)  The probable number of persons, vehicles and animals to be engaged in the proposed parade, procession, demonstration or performance; 
(3)  The purpose for which it is to be held or had; and 
(4)  The streets to have or hold such parade, procession, demonstration or performance. 
(b)  No application for a permit required under this division shall be accepted or considered by the chief of police unless the person applying for the permit pays to the city a fee of $50.00, to aid in defraying the cost involved in considering the application for the permit and taking action with respect thereto, which fee shall not be refunded. 
(Code 1981, § 32-122) 
Sec. 98-283. - Issuance or refusal; streets to be designated; use of undesignated streets prohibited. 
    Upon the filing of an application for a permit under this division, the chief of police shall grant a written permit for the parade, procession, demonstration or performance in question, prescribing the streets or other public ways which may be used therefor, unless, in his judgment, the public welfare, peace, safety, health, decency, good order, morals or convenience require that the permit be refused. It shall be unlawful for any person to use for such purposes, at the hour and on the date requested, any other streets or public ways than those set out in the permit. 
(Code 1981, § 32-123) 
Chapter 102 - SUBDIVISIONS[1]

Chapter 106 - TAXATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) ---

Cross reference- Any ordinance promising or guaranteeing the payment of money by or for the city or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the city or any evidence of the city's indebtedness or any contract or obligation assumed by the city saved from repeal, § 1-7(1); any ordinance appropriating funds, levying or imposing taxes or relating to an annual budget saved from repeal, § 1-7(3); administration, ch. 2; finance, § 2-311 et seq.; businesses, ch. 26; exceptions to business taxes in urban enterprise zone; solicitation, ch. 35; aggressive solicitation, ch. 36. 
State Law reference- Municipal taxes and assessments, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1104; advertising certain tax ordinances in codification, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1433; taxation generally, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-1 et seq.; priority of taxes in distribution of assets of person or corporation, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-6 et seq.; Setoff Debt Collection Act, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-520 et seq.; local sales and use taxes, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-605 et seq.; local bank franchise tax, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-1208 et seq.; local taxes generally, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3000 et seq.; enforcement, collection, refunds, remedies and review of local taxes, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3900 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 106-1. - Rate of taxation on real and personal property. 
    The city council shall annually fix the rate of taxation which shall be assessed upon real and personal property. 
(Code 1981, § 34-1) 
Sec. 106-2. - Exemptions generally. 
    No tax shall be assessed or collected on any property, real or personal, which, by the Constitution or laws of the state, is exempt from taxation by the city. 
(Code 1981, § 34-2) 
Sec. 106-3. - Exemption of certified pollution control equipment and facilities. 
(a)  Declared separate class of property. Certified pollution control equipment and facilities, as defined in this section, are hereby declared to be a separate class of property and shall constitute a classification for local taxation separate from other such classification of real or personal property and such property. Such property shall be exempt from local taxation. 
(b)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Certified pollution control equipment and facilities means any property, including real or personal property, equipment, facilities, or devices, used primarily for the purpose of abating or preventing pollution of the atmosphere or waters of the commonwealth and which the state certifying authority having jurisdiction with respect to such property has certified to the state department of taxation as having been constructed, reconstructed, erected, or acquired in conformity with the state program or requirements for abatement or control of water or atmospheric pollution or contamination. 
    State certifying authority means the state water control board, for water pollution; the state air pollution control board, for air pollution; the state department of mines, minerals and energy, for coal, oil, and gas production, including gas, natural gas, and coalbed methane gas; and the state waste management board, for waste disposal facilities, and shall include any interstate agency authorized to act in place of a certifying authority of the commonwealth. 
(Code 1981, § 34-3) 
State Law reference- Authority for above section, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3660. 
Sec. 106-4. - Exemption of certain personal property. 
    The following items shall be classified separately from other tangible personal property and no tax shall be assessed or collected thereon: 
(1)  Horses, mules and other kindred animals. 
(2)  Cattle. 
(3)  Sheep and goats. 
(4)  Hogs. 
(5)  Poultry. 
(6)  Grains and other feeds used for the nurture of farm animals. 
(7)  Farm machinery other than the farm machinery described in subsection (8) of this section, and farm implements, which shall include equipment and machinery used by farm wineries as defined in Code of Virginia, § 4.1-100, in the production of wine. 
(8)  Farm machinery designed solely for the planting, production or harvesting of a single product or commodity. 
(Code 1981, § 34-4) 
State Law reference- Authority for above section, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3505. 
Sec. 106-5. - General duties of commissioner of the revenue. 
    The duties of the commissioner of the revenue, except so far as modified by this chapter, the license ordinances of the city and the ordinances passed by the city council with respect to the imposition, assessment and collection of taxes, shall be the same as those prescribed for him by state law. 
(Code 1981, § 34-5) 
Charter reference- General duties of commissioner of the revenue, §§ 3-11, 6-8. 
State Law reference- Commissioners of the revenue, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3100 et seq. 
Sec. 106-6. - Commissioner of the revenue to obtain returns from taxpayers. 
    The commissioner of the revenue shall obtain full and complete tax returns from every taxpayer within his jurisdiction who is liable under the law to file such return with him for all taxes assessed by his office. This duty of the commissioner of the revenue to obtain such returns shall in no manner diminish the obligation of the taxpayer to file the required returns without being called upon to do so by the commissioner of the revenue or any other officer. 
(Code 1981, § 34-6) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3107. 
Sec. 106-7. - Refusal of taxpayer to furnish information to commissioner of the revenue. 
    Any person who refuses to (i) furnish to the commissioner of the revenue access to books of account or other papers and records, (ii) furnish information to the commissioner of the revenue relating to the assessment of taxes, (iii) answer under oath questions touching any person's tax liability, or (iv) exhibit to the commissioner of the revenue any subject of taxation liable to assessment by the commissioner of the revenue, shall be deemed guilty of a class 3 misdemeanor. Each day's refusal to furnish such access or information shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1981, § 34-7) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3111. 
Sec. 106-8. - Personal property tax lists; personal property assessments to be furnished to collector of city taxes. 
    The commissioner of the revenue shall ascertain and list such personal property and subjects as are taxable by the city, which lists shall be embraced in his annual return. The original of such lists shall be retained by the commissioner of the revenue as long as he shall remain in office and shall then be delivered to his successor. The commissioner of the revenue shall furnish a copy of the personal property assessments to the collector of city taxes by January 20 and April 30 of each year, and in default of his furnishing such copy to the collector of city taxes, as required, he shall pay a fine of $10.00 per day for every day thereafter until the personal property assessment is furnished. 
(Code 1981, § 34-8; Ord. No. 14-83, 9-2-2014; Ord. No. 17-30, 7-11-2017) 
Sec. 106-9. - Objections to personal property assessments; authority of commissioner of the revenue to examine witnesses, administer oaths, etc. 
    The commissioner of the revenue shall hear and consider all objections which may be made as to the assessment of personal property, and shall have power to alter, add to, take from and otherwise correct and revise his assessment. The commissioner of the revenue shall have power to examine any person, on oath, as to the value of his personal property, and also to examine, under oath, such other persons, as witnesses in relation thereto, as he may deem proper, and for that purpose, may administer oaths and issue process to compel the attendance of witnesses before him. 
(Code 1981, § 34-9) 
Sec. 106-10. - Proration of personal property tax. 
(a)  The tangible personal property tax, at a rate established by the ordinance which annually fixes such rate, shall be levied upon motor vehicles, trailers, semitrailers and boats which have acquired a situs within the city on January 1 of any tax year. The tax shall be due and owed on or before February 28 of each year and June 10 of each year after being billed by the collector of city taxes. Any person failing to pay any taxes on or before the due date shall incur penalties and interest as established in the ordinance which annually fixes the rate for personal property tax. 
(b)  When any person acquired a motor vehicle, trailer, semitrailer or boat with situs in the city after January 1 or situs day, the tax shall be assessed for the portion of the tax year during which the new owner owns the motor vehicle, trailer, semitrailer or boat and it has situs in the city. 
(c)  When any motor vehicle, trailer, semitrailer or boat loses it situs after January 1 or after the day on which it acquired situs ("situs day"), the tax shall be relieved and the appropriate amount of tax which shall be prorated on a monthly basis, shall be refunded if such tax has already been paid. 
(d)  When any person sells or otherwise transfers title to a motor vehicle, trailer, semitrailer or boat with a situs in the city after January 1 or situs day, the tax shall be relieved, prorated on a monthly basis, and the appropriate amount of tax already paid shall be refunded. 
(e)  For the purposes of proration under subsections (a) through (d) of this section, a period of more than one-half of a month shall be counted as a full month and a period of less than one-half of a month shall not be counted. 
(f)  Any refund shall be made within 30 days of the date the city determines that the tax is properly relieved. At the option of the tax payer, any refund due under subsections (c) and (d) of this section may be credited against the tax due on any motor vehicle, trailer, semitrailer or boat owned by the taxpayer during the same tax year. 
(Code 1981, § 34-10; Ord. No. 97-12, § 34-10, 1-21-1997; Ord. No. 14-83, 9-2-2014; Ord. No. 17-16, 4-4-2017; Ord. No. 17-17, 5-2-2017; Ord. No. 17-30, 7-11-2017) 
Sec. 106-11. - Filing of returns; late penalty; interest. 
    All returns of motor vehicles, trailers, semitrailers and boats which acquire situs in the city or are transferred to a new owner in the city after January 1 or situs day, shall be filed by every person liable for the tax with the office of the commissioner of the revenue on or before the 30th day from: 
(1)  Situs day; or 
(2)  The date of transfer to the new owner if situs remains in the city. 
(Code 1981, § 34-11; Ord. No. 97-12, § 34-11, 1-21-1997) 
Sec. 106-12. - Exemptions. 
    Property shall be exempt from the levy of such tax for any tax year or portion thereof during which the property was legally assessed by another jurisdiction in the commonwealth and the tax was paid and not refunded in whole or in part. 
(Code 1981, § 34-12; Ord. No. 97-12, § 34-12, 1-21-1997) 
Sec. 106-13. - Minimum assessments. 
    The commissioner of the revenue shall not make an assessment under the provisions of this article if the assessment would result in the issuance of a tax bill in an amount less than $5.00. 
(Code 1981, § 34-13; Ord. No. 97-12, § 34-13, 1-21-1997) 
Sec. 106-14. - Permanent board of equalization. 
(a)  Created; membership. There is hereby created, in accordance with Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3373, a permanent board of equalization. Such board shall consist of three members, to be appointed by the circuit court. 
(b)  Terms of members. The members of the permanent board of equalization shall be appointed for staggered terms of three years. 
(Code 1981, §§ 34-80, 34-81) 
Sec. 106-15. - Personal property tax relief. 
(a)  Purpose; definitions; relation to other ordinances. 
(1)  The purpose of this section is to provide for the implementation of the changes to PPTRA effected by legislation adopted during the 2004 Special Session I and the 2005 Regular Session of the General Assembly of Virginia. 
(2)  Terms used in this section that have defined meanings set forth in Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3523, as amended. 
(3)  To the extent that the provisions of this section conflict with any prior ordinance or provision of the City Code, this section shall control. 
(b)  Method of computing and reflecting tax relief. 
(1)  For tax years commencing in 2006, the city adopts the provisions of Item 503.E of the 2005 Appropriations Act, providing for the computation of tax relief as a specific dollar amount to be offset against the total taxes that would otherwise be due but for PPTRA and the reporting of such specific dollar relief on the tax bill. 
(2)  The council shall, as part of the annual budget, set the rate of tax relief at such a level that it is anticipated fully to exhaust PPTRA relief funds provided to the city by the commonwealth. Any amount of PPTRA relief not used within the city's fiscal year shall be carried forward and used to increase the funds available for personal property tax relief in the following year. 
(3)  Personal property tax bills shall set forth on their face the specific dollar amount of relief credited with respect to each qualifying vehicle, together with an explanation of the general manner in which relief is allocated. 
(c)  Allocation of relief among taxpayers. 
(1)  Allocation of PPTRA relief shall be provided in accordance with the general provisions of this section, as implemented by the specific provisions of the city's annual budget relating to PPTRA relief. 
(2)  Relief shall be allocated in such a manner as to eliminate personal property taxation of each qualifying vehicle with an assessed value of $1,000.00 or less. 
(3)  Relief with respect to qualifying vehicles with assessed values of more than $1,000.00 shall be provided at a rate, annually fixed in the city budget and applied to the first $20,000.00 in value of each such qualifying vehicle, but is estimated fully to use all available state PPTRA relief. The rate shall be established annually as a part of the adopted budget for the city. 
(d)  Transitional provisions. 
(1)  Pursuant to authority conferred in Item 503.D of the 2005 Appropriations Act, the collector of city taxes is authorized to issue a supplemental personal property tax bill, in the amount of 100 percent of tax due without regard to any former entitlement to state PPTRA relief, plus applicable penalties and interest, to any taxpayer whose taxes with respect to a qualifying vehicle for tax year 2005 or any prior tax year remain unpaid on September 1, 2006, or such date as state funds for reimbursement of the state share of such bill have become unavailable, whichever earlier occurs. 
(2)  Penalty and interest with respect to bills issued pursuant to subsection (a) of this section shall be computed on the entire amount of tax owed. Interest shall be computed at the rate otherwise authorized by the City Code or general law. 
(Ord. No. 05-116, 12-13-2005; Ord. No. 17-30, 7-11-2017) 
Secs. 106-16-106-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CITY TREASURER[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Charter reference- Collector of city taxes, § 3-14 et seq. 
Cross reference- Officers and employees, § 2-61 et seq. 

Secs. 106-31-106-33. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 17-30, adopted July 11, 2017, repealed §§ 106-31-106-33. Former § 106-31 pertained to bond, compensation, general powers and duties and derived from the Code of 1981, § 34-21. Former § 106-32 pertained to the office of the city treasurer and the keeping of the books and accounts and derived from the Code of 1981, § 34-22. Former § 106-33 pertained to a limitation on the keeping of city money and derived from the Code of 1981, § 34-23. 
Sec. 106-34. - Reports to finance department. 
    The collector of city taxes shall report on a daily basis, to the finance department, all funds collected by him. 
(Code 1981, § 34-24; Ord. No. 17-30, 7-11-2017) 
Sec. 106-35. - Reports to city council and city manager generally. 
    The collector of city taxes shall report to the city council, as soon as possible after the close of each fiscal year, the total amount of taxes collected from all sources for the previous year, and at the same time make a return of the uncollected and uncollectible taxes for the fiscal year ending June 30 of the previous year. The collector of city taxes shall also make reports to the city council and the city manager, from time to time as he may be directed by the city council. 
(Code 1981, § 34-25; Ord. No. 17-30, 7-11-2017) 
Sec. 106-36. - Duties and powers with respect to delinquent taxes. 
(a)  The duties of the collector of city taxes with respect to delinquent taxes and levies shall be the same as those prescribed by general law for treasurers with respect to such taxes and levies. 
(b)  The collector of city taxes shall collect all delinquent taxes due to the city and, for that purpose, he shall have full power and authority to levy for all taxes due and unpaid by distress and sale of the goods and chattels of the delinquent taxpayer or any goods and chattels legally liable therefor, in like manner as is now or may hereafter be provided by the laws of the state in case of nonpayment of county levies, or by any other laws of the state, or as is now or may hereafter be provided by the charter and ordinances of the city. The collector of city taxes is hereby granted, for the purpose aforesaid, the power of garnishment which is vested in the state officers by state law. 
(c)  It shall be the duty of the collector of city taxes to turn over to the director of finance, at such time as the city council shall direct, the tax books for any preceding year or years, containing the list of the names of the delinquent taxpayers for such year or years, and the director of finance shall thereupon credit the collector of city taxes with the amount of taxes shown upon such list and return the list to the collector of city taxes and charge him with the amount of taxes shown thereon. 
(d)  The collector of city taxes shall submit to the city council annually, as soon as possible after the close of the fiscal year, a statement of all money collected under this section by him during the preceding fiscal year, and the particular assessment or account upon which collected, and at the expiration of his term of office, shall submit to the city council a statement of the amount remaining uncollected. If the collector of city taxes shall return as not paid any taxes upon real and personal property for which he found, or by due diligence might have found, sufficient property within the city, liable to distress for such taxes, upon settlement of his annual account he shall be charged and held liable for all such taxes. 
(Code 1981, § 34-26; Ord. No. 17-30, 7-11-2017) 
State Law reference- Collection by treasurers, etc., Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3910 et seq. 
Sec. 106-37. - Fees for administrative costs, etc. 
    There is hereby imposed on delinquent taxpayers a fee to cover the administrative costs associated with the collection of delinquent taxes. Such fee shall be $20.00 for taxes collected subsequent to the filing of a warrant or other appropriate legal document in the appropriate court but prior to judgment, and $25.00 for taxes collected subsequent to judgment. Such fee shall be in addition to the tax and all penalties and interest owing thereon. Additionally, there is hereby imposed on delinquent taxpayers a fee to cover the reasonable attorney's or collection agency's fees actually contracted for. The attorney's or collection agency's fees shall not exceed 20 percent of the taxes or other charges so collected. 
(Code 1981, § 34-27; Ord. No. 99-05, § 34-27, 1-5-1999) 
Secs. 106-38-106-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - REAL ESTATE TAXES[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Charter reference- Assessment and reassessment of real estate, § 6-5 et seq. 
State Law reference- Real property tax, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3200 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 106-61. - Assessments generally. 
    There shall be, in accordance with methods prescribed by general law, a biennial assessment, reassessment and equalization of assessments of real estate for local taxation in the city. 
(Code 1981, § 34-37; Ord. No. 19-10, 2-5-2019) 
State Law reference- Real estate assessments, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3250 et seq. 
Sec. 106-62. - Assessment office established. 
    There is hereby established in the city, under the provisions of article II of chapter 6 of the Charter, a city real estate assessment office. 
(Code 1981, § 34-38) 
Sec. 106-63. - Time of biennial assessment and reassessment of real estate. 
    Pursuant to the Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3253, 1950, as amended, there shall be a biennial assessment and reassessment and equalization of assessments of all real estate in the city, such real estate to be assesed as of January 1 of each even numbered year, such biennial assessment shall become effective August 1, 2018 with the next reassessment being in 2020. The January 1 assessed value shall become effective for taxes on July 1. There shall be a lien on real estate for the taxes assessed thereon, with charges and interest thereon, as provided by law. 
(Code 1981, § 34-39; Ord. No. 19-10, 2-5-2019) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 19-10, adopted Feb. 5, 2019, amended § 106-63 by changing the title from "time for assessment; tax lien" to read as set out herein. 
Sec. 106-64. - Transfer of property upon land book. 
    The commissioner of the revenue shall transfer upon the land book all land which appears by competent evidence to have changed ownership. 
(Code 1981, § 34-40) 
Charter reference- Duty of commissioner of the revenue relative to land book, § 6-8. 
Sec. 106-65. - Additional authority to sell land for delinquent taxes. 
    In addition to the authority provided by Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3965, subsection A, as amended, and in accordance with Code of Virginia § 58.1-3965.1, the city may also institute proceedings to sell in accordance with law any real estate when taxes on such real estate are delinquent on December 31 following the first anniversary of the date on which such taxes have become due. The ordinance from which this section derives shall stand as the ordinance of institution for each and every such proceeding commenced in accordance with this section. Notice shall be given in accordance with relevant law. 
(Ord. No. 01-09, 3-6-2001) 
Sec. 106-66. - Reserved. 
Sec. 106-67. - Deadline for appeal of assessment to city assessor. 
    Any property owner in the city shall have the right to appeal any real estate assessment to the city assessor between January 28 and March 1, or 30 days after the mailing date of a change of assessment notice, whichever is later. All appeals shall be submitted on forms supplied by the city assessor. Any appeal not timely filed shall not be considered. 
(Ord. No. 19-11, 2-5-2019) 
Sec. 106-68. - Deadline for appeal of assessment to the board of equalization. 
    Any appellant to the city assessor remaining unsatisfied with the action taken on appeal to the city assessor may further appeal to the city's board of equalization. Application to the board of equalization may be made between January 28 and April 1, or 60 days after the mailing date of a change of assessment notice, whichever is later. All appeals shall be submitted on forms supplied by the board of equalization. Any appeal not timely filed shall not be considered. Any appellant unsatisfied with the action taken by the board of equalization may appeal such decision to the circuit court; however, timely appeal to, and final disposition by the county's board of equalization shall be a prerequisite to the jurisdiction of the circuit court in hearing any application for relief made under this article. 
(Ord. No. 19-11, 2-5-2019) 
Sec. 106-69. - Assessment of new buildings substantially complete, etc; extension of time for paying assessment. 
    Pursuant to the authority of the Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3292, all new buildings substantially completed or fit for use and occupancy prior to May 1 of the year of completion shall be assessed when so completed or fit for use and occupancy, and the commissioner of the revenue shall enter in the books the fair market value of such building. No partial assessment as provided herein shall become effective until information as to the date and amount of such assessment is recorded in the office of the official authorized to collect taxes on real property and made available for public inspection. The total tax on any such new building for that year shall be the sum of (i) the tax upon the assessment of the completed building, computed according to the ratio which the portion of the year such building is substantially completed or fit for use and occupancy bears to the entire year, and (ii) the tax upon the assessment of such new building as it existed on July 1 of that assessment year, computed according to the ratio which the portion of the year such building was not substantially complete or fit for use and occupancy bears to the entire year. With respect to any assessment made under this section after March 1 of any year, the penalty for nonpayment by June 30 shall be extended to September 30 of the succeeding year. 
(Ord. No. 19-12, 2-5-2019) 
Secs. 106-70-106-80. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - SPECIAL ASSESSMENT FOR LAND PRESERVATION[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Authority of city to adopt ordinance to provide for certain use value assessment and taxation, Code of Virginia, § 58.2-3231. 

Sec. 106-81. - Finding of fact. 
    The city council has determined that the preservation of real estate devoted to agricultural, horticultural, forest and open space uses within its boundaries is in the public interest and, having heretofore adopted a land use plan, hereby ordains that such real estate shall be taxed in accordance with the provisions of this division and Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3230 et seq. 
(Code 1981, § 34-51; Ord. No. 01-29, 5-15-2001; Ord. No. 01-43, 6-10-2001) 
Sec. 106-82. - Application for classification, assessment, etc., generally. 
(a)  The owner of any real estate meeting the criteria set forth in Code of Virginia, §§ 58.1-3230 and 58.1-3233(2), may, on or before May 1 of each year, apply to the city assessor for the classification, assessment and taxation of such property for the next succeeding tax year on the basis of its use, under the procedures set forth in Code of Virginia, §§ 58.1-3234 and 58.1-3236. Such application shall be on forms provided by the state department of taxation and supplied by the city assessor and shall include such additional schedules, photographs and drawings as may be required by the assessor. 
(b)  A separate application under this section shall be filed for each use for which qualification is sought. 
(Code 1981, § 34-52; Ord. No. 01-29, 5-15-2001; Ord. No. 01-43, 6-10-2001) 
Sec. 106-83. - Determinations of assessor. 
(a)  Promptly upon receipt of any application under this division, the city assessor shall determine whether the property meets the criteria for taxation under this division. If the assessor determines that the property meets the criteria, he shall determine the value of such property for its qualifying use, as well as its fair market value. 
(b)  In determining whether the real estate meets the criteria set forth in Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3230, and the standards prescribed thereunder to qualify for one of the classifications set forth therein, the assessor may request an opinion from the director of the state department of conservation and recreation, the state forester or the state commissioner of agriculture and consumer services. Upon the refusal of the state commissioner of agriculture and consumer services, the state forester or the director of the state department of conservation and recreation to issue an opinion or in the event of an unfavorable opinion which does not comport with standards set forth in the statements filed pursuant to Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3240, the party aggrieved may seek relief in the circuit court of the city, and in the event that the court finds in his favor, it may issue an order which shall serve in lieu of an opinion for the purposes of this division. 
(Code 1981, § 34-53; Ord. No. 01-29, 5-15-2001; Ord. No. 01-43, 6-10-2001) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, §§ 58.1-3233, 58.1-3240. 
Sec. 106-84. - Land book entries; tax to be extended from use value. 
    The use value and fair market value of any property qualifying under this division shall be placed on the land book before delivery of such book to the collector of city taxes, and the tax for the next succeeding tax year shall be extended from the use value. 
(Code 1981, § 34-54; Ord. No. 01-29, 5-15-2001; Ord. No. 01-43, 6-10-2001; Ord. No. 17-30, 7-11-2017) 
Sec. 106-85. - Change in use or zoning; roll-back tax. 
    There is hereby imposed a roll-back tax, in such amount as shall be determined under Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3237, upon any property as to which the use changes to a nonqualifying use under any special real estate tax assessment for land preservation (land use)or the zoning is changed to a more intensive use at the request of the owner or his agent, plus simple interest on such roll-back taxes at the same interest rate applicable to delinquent real estate taxes pursuant to applicable ordinances enacted in accordance with section 106-1 of this Code. The owner of any real estate liable for roll-back taxes shall report to the collector of city taxes, on forms to be prescribed, any change in the use of such property to a nonqualifying use, or any such change in the zoning of the property to a more intensive use, and shall pay the roll-back tax then due. On failure to report and pay the taxes due within 60 days following such change, the owner shall be liable for an additional penalty equal to ten percent of the amount of the roll-back tax, which penalty shall be collected as a part of the tax. In addition to such penalty, there is hereby imposed interest of one-half percent of the amount of the entire roll-back tax due for each month or fraction thereof during which the failure to pay the tax continues. 
(Code 1981, § 34-55; Ord. No. 01-21, 4-17-2001; Ord. No. 01-29, 5-15-2001; Ord. No. 17-30, 7-11-2017) 
Sec. 106-86. - Misstatements in application filed under division. 
    Any person making a material misstatement of fact in any application filed pursuant to this division shall be liable for all taxes, in such amounts and at such times as if such property had been assessed on the basis of fair market value as applied to other real estate in the city, together with interest and penalties thereon. if such material misstatement was made with the intent to defraud the city, he shall be further assessed with an additional penalty of 100 percent of such unpaid taxes. 
(Code 1981, § 34-56; Ord. No. 01-29, 5-15-2001; Ord. No. 01-43, 6-10-2001) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3238. 
Sec. 106-87. - Application of general tax law. 
    The provisions of Code of Virginia, tit. 58.1, applicable to local levies and real estate assessment and taxation shall be applicable to assessments and taxation under this division mutatis mutandis , including, without limitation, provisions relating to tax liens, boards of equalization and the correction of erroneous assessments, and for such purposes, the roll-back taxes shall be considered to be deferred real estate taxes. 
(Code 1981, § 34-57) 
Secs. 106-88-106-105. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - EXEMPTION FOR ELDERLY AND DISABLED[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Authority of city to provide for the exemption provided in this division, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3210. 

Sec. 106-106. - Definition. 
    The following words, terms and phrases when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Permanently and totally disabled means to be unable to engage in any substantial gainful activity, by reason of any medically determinable physical or mental impairment or deformity, which can be expected to result in death or can be expected to last for the duration of the person's life. 
(Code 1981, § 34-69) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 106-107. - Authorized. 
    Exemption from taxation of real estate and manufactured homes as defined in Code of Virginia, § 36-85.3, is provided for qualified property owners who are not less than 65 years of age or who are permanently and totally disabled, and who are eligible according to the terms of this division and Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3210. Persons qualifying for such exemption are deemed to be bearing an extraordinary real estate tax burden in relation to their income and financial worth. 
(Code 1981, § 34-70) 
Sec. 106-108. - Administration; rules and regulations of commissioner of the revenue. 
    The exemption provided for in this division shall be administered by the commissioner of the revenue according to the provisions of this division. The commissioner of the revenue is hereby authorized and empowered to prescribe, adopt, promulgate and enforce such rules and regulations in conformance with the provisions of this division, including the requirement of answers under oath, as may be reasonably necessary to determine qualifications for exemption as specified by this division. The commissioner of the revenue may require the production of certified tax returns and appraisal reports to establish income or financial worth. 
(Code 1981, § 34-71) 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 
Sec. 106-109. - General prerequisites to grant. 
    The exemption provided for in this division shall be granted to persons subject to the following provisions: 
(1)  That the title to the property for which the exemption is claimed is held, or partially held, on July 1 of the taxable year, by the person claiming the exemption. 
(2)  That the head of the household occupying the dwelling and owning the title, or partial title, thereto is 65 years or older, or is permanently and totally disabled, on June 30 of the year immediately preceding the taxable year. 
(3)  That the gross combined income of the owner during the year immediately preceding the taxable year shall be determined by the commissioner of the revenue to be in an amount not to exceed $35,000.00. The gross combined income shall include all income from all sources of the owner and of the owner's relatives living in the dwelling for which exemption is claimed; except that the first $4,000.00 of income of each relative, other than the spouse of the owner, who is living in the dwelling, shall not be included in such total. 
(4)  That the total combined financial worth of the owner and of the spouse of the owner, as of May 1 of the year immediately preceding the taxable year, shall be determined by the commissioner of the revenue to be in an amount not to exceed $70,000.00. The total financial worth shall include the value of all assets, including the equitable interest, of the owner and the owner's relatives living in the dwelling for which the exemption is claimed but shall not include the fair market value of the dwelling and the land upon which it is situated, not exceeding one acre, for which the exemption is claimed. 
(Ord. No. 04-49, 6-15-2004; Ord. No. 08-15, 2-5-2008; Ord. No. 12-83, § 1, 12-18-2012)
