    If the owner of a vehicle licensed under this division shall furnish to the commissioner of the revenue satisfactory proof of the loss of his license tag, the commissioner shall issue to him a duplicate tag, bearing the same number as the original, upon the payment of $1.00 into the city treasury. 
(Ord. No. 96-183a, § 16.1-122, 12-6-1996) 
Sec. 110-185. - Transfer of tag. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to transfer a tag issued under this division from one vehicle to another, unless the vehicle for which the tag was issued is temporarily disabled. 
(Ord. No. 96-183a, § 16.1-123, 12-6-1996) 
Sec. 110-186. - Numbering of licensed vehicles. 
    Every vehicle for which a license tax is paid under this division shall be numbered, in large figures that may be easily read, and the numbers shall be conspicuously placed on the right side of such vehicle. It shall be the duty of the commissioner of the revenue to give notice of the provisions of this section to every person obtaining a license for such a vehicle at the time of issuing such license. Any person who shall fail to comply with any provision of this section shall, upon conviction thereof, pay a fine of not less than $5.00 nor more than $200.00 for every such offense and every week of such failure shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 96-183a, § 16.1-124, 12-6-1996) 
Secs. 110-187-110-210. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - OPERATION OF VEHICLES 

Sec. 110-211. - Driving while under influence of alcohol or drugs; adoption of state law. 
(a)  Pursuant to the authority of Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1313, all of the provisions and requirements of the laws of the state contained in Code of Virginia, §§ 16.1-278 et seq. and 18.2-266 et seq., except those provisions and requirements the violation of which constitutes a felony, and except those provisions and requirements which, by their very nature, can have no application to or within the city, are hereby adopted and incorporated in this chapter by reference and made applicable within the city. References to highways of this state or commonwealth contained in such provisions and requirements hereby adopted shall be deemed to refer to the streets, highways and other public ways within the city. Such provisions and requirements are hereby adopted, mutatis mutandis, and made a part of this chapter as fully as though set forth at length in this section, and it shall be unlawful for any person within the city to violate or fail, neglect or refuse to comply with and provision of the Code of Virginia which is adopted by this section; provided that in no event shall the penalty imposed for the violation of any provision or requirement hereby adopted exceed the penalty imposed for a similar offense under the Code of Virginia. 
(b)  The provisions of the aforementioned sections shall include future amendments to the state statutes to which references are therein made. 
(Code 1981, § 18-107; Ord. No. 98-110, § 18-107, 7-7-1998; Ord. No. 99-89, § 18-107, 6-15-1999; Ord. No. 00-39, § 18-107, 6-20-2000; Ord. No. 01-44, 6-19-2001; Ord. No. 02-38, 6-18-2002; Ord. No. 03-40, 6-3-2003; Ord. No. 04-48, 6-15-2004; Ord. No. 05-39, 6-7-2005; Ord. No. 05-60, 7-5-2005; Ord. No. 06-60, 6-20-2006; Ord. No. 07-57, 6-19-2007) 
State Law reference- Adoption of future amendments to state statutes, Code of Virginia, § 1-13.39:2. 
Sec. 110-212. - Driving dangerous vehicles or when vision obscured. 
    No vehicle shall be driven or operated when so constructed, including equipment, or loaded as to be dangerous or to retard or prevent the driver from having a view sufficient for safety. 
(Code 1981, § 18-108) 
Sec. 110-213. - Driving through funeral or other processions. 
    No operator of a vehicle shall drive between the vehicles, persons or animals comprising a funeral or other authorized procession, except when otherwise directed by a police officer. This provision shall not apply to authorized emergency vehicles. 
(Code 1981, § 18-109) 
State Law reference- Right-of-way of funeral processions under police escort, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-828. 
Sec. 110-214. - Driving in funeral or other processions. 
    Each driver of a vehicle in a funeral or other procession shall drive as near to the righthand edge of the roadway as practical and shall follow the vehicle ahead as close as is practical and safe. 
(Code 1981, § 18-110) 
Sec. 110-215. - Obstructing intersections or crosswalks. 
    No driver shall enter an intersection or a marked crosswalk, unless there is sufficient space on the other side of the intersection or crosswalk to accommodate the vehicle he is operating without obstructing the passage of other vehicles or pedestrians, notwithstanding any traffic control signal indication to proceed. 
(Code 1981, § 18-111) 
Sec. 110-216. - Entering or leaving limited-access roadway. 
    No person shall drive a vehicle onto or from any limited-access roadway, except at such entrances and exits as are established by public authority. 
(Code 1981, § 18-113) 
Sec. 110-217. - Driving on streets newly paved, repaired or closed to traffic. 
    When authorized signs or markers are erected indicating that any street or part thereof is newly paved, repaired or closed to traffic, no person shall drive any vehicle over any such street until the street is officially opened to traffic. 
(Code 1981, § 18-115) 
Sec. 110-218. - Backing. 
    No vehicle shall be backed without the driver first indicating, by some sign or signal, his intention to back, and no vehicle shall be backed in any street if, by so doing, any other vehicle is impeded or any pedestrian is endangered. No vehicle shall, in any event or on any street, be backed a greater distance than 25 feet, unless it is necessary to relieve a traffic jam or on orders from a police officer. 
(Code 1981, § 18-117) 
Sec. 110-219. - Operation of go-carts on streets. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to drive, on the streets of the city, any self-propelled vehicle of the type commonly known as a go-cart, weighing less than 500 pounds, designed for transporting a person. 
(Code 1981, § 18-118) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 98. 
Sec. 110-220. - Operation of certain trucks prohibited on portions of Sycamore Street. 
    The operation of trucks of 11/2-ton rating or over on North Sycamore Street, between Washington and Bollingbrook Streets, and on South Sycamore Street, from Wythe Street south to Crater Road, is hereby prohibited; provided, however, that this section shall not be construed as prohibiting the use of trucks on such streets for the purpose of receiving loads or making deliveries on such streets or in the area served by such streets. 
(Code 1981, § 18-119) 
State Law reference- Authority for above section, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1304. 
Sec. 110-221. - Permit for operation of traction engines or tractors. 
    The chief of police may issue special permits, limited to such time as he may deem proper, authorizing the operation upon a street of traction engines or tractors having movable tracks with transverse corrugations upon the periphery of such movable tracks. A fee of $2.00 shall be charged for each such permit at the time of issuance. 
(Code 1981, § 18-120) 
State Law reference- Authority for above section, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1046. 
Sec. 110-222. - Drinking while operating motor vehicle. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to consume an alcoholic beverage while driving a motor vehicle upon a public street, road or highway within the city. 
(Code 1981, § 18-121) 
Cross reference- Alcoholic beverages, ch. 10. 
Secs. 110-223-110-250. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING[5] 
Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Charter reference- Power of city to operate parking facilities, § 4-8. 
Cross reference- Parking or stopping buses or taxicabs, § 118-2. 
State Law reference- Authority for local parking regulations, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1220. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 110-251. - General prohibitions. 
(a)  No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle, except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with law or the directions of a police officer or traffic control device in any of the following places: 
(1)  On a sidewalk. 
(2)  Within an intersection. 
(3)  On a crosswalk. 
(4)  Within 30 feet upon the approach of any flashing beacon, stop sign or traffic control signal at the side of a roadway. 
(5)  Between a safety zone and the adjacent curb or within 30 feet of points on the curb immediately opposite the ends of a safety zone, unless the traffic engineer has indicated a different length by signs or markings. 
(6)  Within 40 feet of the nearest rail of a railroad crossing. 
(7)  Upon the side of a street opposite the entrance to any fire station, within 75 feet of such entrance, when properly signposted. 
(8)  Alongside or opposite any street excavation or obstruction, when stopping, standing or parking would obstruct traffic. 
(9)  On the roadway side of any vehicle stopped or parked at the edge or curb of a street. 
(10)  Upon any bridge or other elevated structure upon a highway or within a highway tunnel. 
(11)  At any place where official signs prohibit stopping. 
(12)  In spaces clearly marked as reserved for disabled persons, whether public or private property, unless such vehicle clearly displays a special parking permit or special license plates issued to persons with disabilities or to disabled veterans. 
(13)  In an area designated as a fire lane. 
(b)  No person shall move a vehicle not lawfully under his control into any area prohibited under this section or away from a curb such distance as is unlawful. 
(Code 1981, § 18-132) 
State Law reference- Parking in front of driveways, near fire hydrants, etc., Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1239. 
Sec. 110-252. - Authority of traffic and transportation safety commission. 
    The traffic and transportation safety commission may prohibit or regulate the stopping, standing or parking of vehicles upon any street or alley, not expressly regulated by an ordinance of the city council, by causing to be erected official signs indicating the restrictions. 
(Code 1981, § 18-133) 
Sec. 110-253. - Authority of traffic engineer to designate temporary no parking areas. 
    The city traffic engineer is hereby authorized to temporarily designate no parking areas in hazardous or congested places and to temporarily remove parking in any emergency situation. Permanent removal of parking shall be subject to traffic and transportation safety commission approval. 
(Code 1981, § 18-134) 
Sec. 110-254. - Signs giving notice of parking limits and prohibitions on designated streets. 
    Whenever, in this chapter or any other ordinance of the city or any regulation of the traffic and transportation safety commission, any parking time limit is imposed or parking is prohibited on designated streets, it shall be the duty of the traffic engineer to erect appropriate signs giving notice thereof and no such regulations shall be effective unless such signs are erected and in place at the time of any alleged offense. 
(Code 1981, § 18-135) 
Sec. 110-255. - Parking or standing on private property. 
    No person shall stand or park a vehicle on any private lot or lot area, without the express or implied consent of the owner thereof. Whenever signs or markings have been erected on any lot or lot area contiguous or adjacent to a street, thoroughfare or alley, indicating that no vehicles are permitted to stand or park thereon, it shall be unlawful for any person to drive a vehicle across any curb or lot line or over any driveway from a street or alley into such lot or area for the purpose of standing or parking such vehicle, or for any person to stop, stand or park any vehicle in such lot or lot area. 
(Code 1981, § 18-136) 
Sec. 110-256. - Right-of-way of vehicle backing into vacant parking space over following vehicle. 
    A person stopping a vehicle on a street for the purpose of backing the vehicle into a vacant parking space shall have a prior right over a following vehicle to the use of such space for parking, and it shall be unlawful for the driver of such following vehicle to drive the vehicle into such space or partially into such space or to otherwise place his vehicle in such a position as to prevent the backing of the first vehicle into such parking space. 
(Code 1981, § 18-137) 
Sec. 110-257. - Parking in or near safety lanes. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to park any vehicle in any safety lane established by the traffic and transportation safety commission or within ten feet thereof. 
(Code 1981, § 18-138) 
Sec. 110-258. - Time limits. 
(a)  Certain trucks. No person shall park any truck, trailer, camping trailer, tractor truck, or semitrailer of a total outside width, including any boat or other load thereon, of more than 76 inches, or total height, including any boat or other load thereon, of more than 78 inches, on any street within the city for a period of time longer than two hours. 
(b)  Inoperable vehicles. It shall be unlawful for any person to park or store, for more than 24 hours, on any street or any parking lot belonging to or operated by the city, any motor vehicle which is incapable of being operated. 
(Code 1981, §§ 18-139, 18-140) 
Sec. 110-259. - Parking unlicensed vehicles. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to park or store, on any street or parking lot belonging to or operated by the city, any motor vehicle on which currently legal license plates are not properly displayed. 
(Code 1981, § 18-141) 
Sec. 110-260. - Parking for purpose of repairing vehicle. 
    No person shall park a vehicle on any roadway for the principal purpose of repairing such vehicle, except for repairs necessitated by an emergency. 
(Code 1981, § 18-142) 
Sec. 110-261. - Stopping for the purpose of advertising. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to stop a vehicle at any time, upon any street, for the purpose of advertising any articles of any kind, or displaying thereupon advertisements of any article, or advertisements for the sale of the vehicle itself. 
(Code 1981, § 18-143) 
Sec. 110-262. - Washing, polishing or greasing vehicle on street or sidewalk. 
    No person shall, for compensation, wash, polish or grease a vehicle upon a street or sidewalk, nor shall the owner of a vehicle permit it to be washed, polished or greased, for compensation, upon a street or sidewalk. 
(Code 1981, § 18-144) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 98. 
Sec. 110-263. - Permits for backing to curb for loading or unloading. 
    The chief of police is authorized to issue special permits to permit the backing of a vehicle to the curb for the purpose of loading or unloading merchandise or materials subject to the terms and conditions of such permit. Such permits may be issued either to the owner or lessee of real property or to the owner of the vehicle and shall grant to such person the privilege as therein stated and authorized in this section. It shall be unlawful for any permittee or other person to violate any of the special terms or conditions of any such permit. 
(Code 1981, § 18-147) 
Sec. 110-264. - Designation and use of loading zones. 
(a)  The traffic and transportation safety commission is hereby authorized to determine the location of passenger and freight curb loading zones and shall place and maintain appropriate signs indicating the location of passenger and freight curb loading zones and stating the hours during which the provisions of this section are applicable. 
(b)  No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle for any purpose or period of time, other than for the expeditious loading or unloading of passengers, in any place marked as a passenger curb loading zone during hours when the regulations applicable to such curb loading zone are effective, and then only for a period not to exceed three minutes. 
(c)  No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle for any purpose or period of time, other than for the expeditious unloading and delivery or pick-up and loading of materials, in any place marked as a freight curb loading zone during hours when the provisions applicable to such zones are in effect. In no case shall the stop for loading and unloading of materials exceed 30 minutes. 
(Code 1981, § 18-148) 
Sec. 110-265. - Duty of officers with respect to parking violations; issuance, payment, contest, etc., of parking citations; penalty for failure to respond to citation. 
(a)  Whenever any motor vehicle is found parked or stopped in violation of any of the restrictions imposed by, or pursuant to, state law, an ordinance of this city or the rules, regulations, restrictions or prohibitions made, adopted or imposed, by the traffic and transportation safety commission or the traffic engineer, the officer or other persons appointed by the city manager to enforce this article, in addition to the regular police officers of the city, finding such vehicle, shall take its registration number, and may take any other information displayed on the vehicle which may identify its user, and shall conspicuously affix to such vehicle a written citation, on a form provided by the city. Such driver may, within ten days, pay to the collector of city taxes, in person, or by mailing a check or money order, as a penalty for, and in full satisfaction of, such violation, the sum of $20.00. If the fine is not paid within the ten days to the collector of city taxes, the fine will double. The amount of such penalty for the violation of the ordinances or regulations relating to overtime parking shall be the sum of $20.00; the amount of such penalty for the violation of the ordinances or regulations relating to parking within 15 feet of fire hydrants and in fire lanes shall be $50.00; and, in special spaces reserved for disabled persons the penalty shall be the sum of $150.00. Such payment shall constitute a plea of guilty of the violation in question. Parking on or driving over a city curb to park on private or public property shall be a $50.00 fine. 
(b)  Any person who shall desire to contest a parking citation, shall present this citation at the office of the collector of city taxes, who shall certify it, on an appropriate form, to the general district court. If payment or presentment of such citation for certification to the general district court is not postmarked or received by the collector of city taxes within ten days after receipt of such citation, the violator shall be subject to payment of double the penalty as provided in this section. 
(c)  The failure of such owner to make such payment or present such citation to the collector of city taxes for certification to the general district court shall, within 30 days after receipt of such citation, render such violator subject to the penalty provided in section 110-31. 
    Overtime parking means a vehicle that remains parked in such parking space beyond the parking limit, as indicated by the parking sign, such vehicle shall be considered as parked overtime and the parking of a vehicle overtime in any part of a street where any such sign is located shall be unlawful. 
(Code 1981, § 18-152; Ord. No. 97-124, § 18-152, 9-16-1997; Ord. No. 16-18, 4-19-2016; Ord. No. 17-30, 7-11-2017) 
State Law reference- Uncontested payment of parking citations and certification of contest of parking citation, Code of Virginia, §§ 46.2-1220, 46.2-1225, 46.2-1242. 
Sec. 110-266. - Procedure for delinquent parking citations. 
(a)  The collector of city taxes shall cause a complaint or summons to be issued for citations issued pursuant to section 110-265 and not paid or presented for certification pursuant to such section within 30 days. 
(b)  Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection (a) of this section, before any summons shall issue for the prosecution of a violation covered by a citation issued under section 110-265, the violator shall have been first notified, by registered or certified mail at his last known address or at the address shown for such violator on the records of the state department of motor vehicles, that he may pay the fine provided by law for such violation, within five days of receipt of such notice, and the officer issuing such summons shall be notified that the violator has failed to pay such fine within such time. The notice to the violator, required by the provisions of this section, shall be contained in an envelope bearing the words "Law Enforcement Notice" stamped or printed on the face thereof in type at least one-half inch in height. 
(Code 1981, § 18-153; Ord. No. 17-30, 7-11-2017) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, §§ 46.2-941, 46.2-1225. 
Sec. 110-267. - Presumption in prosecutions for parking violations. 
    In any prosecution charging the violation of any law, ordinance, rule, regulation, restriction or prohibition governing the parking of a vehicle, proof that the particular vehicle described in the complaint, summons, parking ticket citation or warrant was parked in violation of such law, ordinance, rule, regulation, restriction or prohibition, together with proof that the defendant named in the complaint, summons, parking ticket citation or warrant was, at the time of such parking, the registered owner of such vehicle, as required by Code of Virginia, § 46.2-600 et seq., shall constitute in evidence a prima facie presumption that the registered owner of such vehicle was the person who parked or placed such vehicle at the point where and at the time during which such violation occurred. This presumption shall apply only when the procedure described in sections 110-265 and 110-266 has been followed. 
(Code 1981, § 18-154) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1220. 
Sec. 110-268. - Removal or immobilization of motor vehicles against which there are outstanding parking violations. 
    Any motor vehicle parked on the public highways or public grounds against which there are three or more unpaid or otherwise unsettled parking violation notices may be removed to a place within the city or in an adjacent locality designated by the chief of police for the temporary storage of the vehicle, or the vehicle may be immobilized in a manner which will prevent its removal or operation except by authorized law enforcement personnel. The removal or immobilization of the vehicle shall be by or under the direction of, an officer or employee of the police department. It shall be the duty of the law enforcement personnel removing or immobilizing the motor vehicle or under whose direction such vehicle is removed or immobilized, to inform as soon as practicable the owner of the removed or immobilized vehicle of the nature and circumstances of the prior unsettled parking violation notices for which the vehicle was removed or immobilized. In any case involving immobilization of a vehicle pursuant to this section, there shall be placed on the vehicle, in a conspicuous manner, a notice warning that the vehicle has been immobilized and that any attempt to move the vehicle might damage it. The owner of an immobilized vehicle, or other person acting on his behalf, shall be allowed at least 24 hours from the time of immobilization to repossess or secure the release of the vehicle. Failure to repossess or secure the release of the vehicle within that time period may result in the removal of the vehicle to a storage area for safekeeping under the direction of law enforcement personnel. The owner of the removed or immobilized motor vehicle, or other person acting on his behalf, shall be permitted to repossess or to secure the release of the vehicle by payment of the outstanding parking violation notices for which the vehicle was removed or immobilized and by payment of all costs incidental to the immobilization, removal, and storage of the vehicle, and the efforts to locate the owner of the vehicle. Should the owner fail or refuse to pay such fines and costs, or should the identity or whereabouts of the owner be unknown and unascertainable, the motor vehicle may be sold in accordance with the procedures set forth in Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1213. 
(Code 1981, § 18-155) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1216. 
Sec. 110-269. - Removal or alteration of marks placed upon vehicle in furtherance of enforcement of parking regulations. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, with the intent to evade the enforcement of any violation of this article, to remove or alter any mark placed upon a vehicle by a police officer or other person appointed by the city manager to enforce the provisions of this article. Additionally, it shall be unlawful for any person with the intent to evade the enforcement of any violation of this article to move or relocate such marked vehicle from one location to another in the same public parking lot. 
(Code 1981, § 18-156) 
Sec. 110-270. - Passing stopped school buses; civil penalty. 
    The school division may install and operate a video-monitoring system on any school bus operated by the division for the purpose of recording violations as provided for in this section. 
(a)  The driver of a motor vehicle approaching from any direction a clearly marked school bus which is stopped on any highway or school driveway for the purpose of taking on or discharging children, the elderly, or mentally or physically handicapped persons, who, in violation of Code of Virginia, § 46.2-859, as amended, fails to stop and remain stopped until all such persons are clear of the highway or school driveway, shall be subject to a civil penalty of $250.00 and any such prosecution shall be instituted and conducted in the same manner as prosecutions for traffic infractions. 
(b)  A prosecution or proceeding under Code of Virginia, § 46.2-859, as amended, shall be a bar to a prosecution or proceeding under this section for the same act, and a prosecution or proceeding under this section shall be a bar to a prosecution or proceeding under Code of Virginia, § 46.2-859, as amended, for the same act. 
(c)  In any prosecution for which a summons charging a violation of this section was issued within ten days of the alleged violation, proof that the motor vehicle described in the summons was operated in violation of this section, together with proof that the defendant was at the time of such violation the registered owner of the vehicle, as required by Code of Virginia, title 46.2, chapter 6, as amended, shall give rise to a rebuttable presumption that such registered owner of the vehicle was the person who operated the vehicle at the place where, and for the time during which, such violation occurred. 
(d)  The testimony of the school bus driver, the supervisor of school buses or a law enforcement officer that the vehicle was yellow, conspicuously marked as a school bus, and equipped with warning devices as prescribed in Code of Virginia, § 46.2-844, as amended, is prima facie evidence that the vehicle is a school bus. 
(e)  Any civil penalty levied for a violation of this section shall be payable to the local school division. 
    For purposes of this section, "school division" means the division of Petersburg Public Schools. "Video-monitoring system" means a system with one or more camera sensors and computers installed and operated on a school bus that produces live digital and recorded video of motor vehicles being operated in violation of the Code of Virginia, § 46.2-859. 
(Ord. No. 15-47, 6-2-2015) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, §§ 46.2-844, 46.2-859. 
Secs. 110-271-110-285. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PARKING METERS[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Charter reference- Authority of city with respect to parking meters, § 4-8. 
State Law reference- Authority of city with respect to parking meters, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1220. 

Sec. 110-286. - Marking of parking spaces and installation of meters. 
    On streets where parking is limited in time, the traffic and transportation safety commission may cause parking spaces, approximately 20 feet in length, to be marked by lines on the curb or pavement or by other appropriate markings, and on the sidewalk adjacent to each such parking space may cause to be erected a parking meter, which, upon the deposit of a coin as provided for in this division, will indicate the duration of the legal parking period and the time when such period has elapsed. Such meters may also be erected for spaces marked off in any off-street parking lot owned or operated by the city. 
(Code 1981, § 18-166) 
Sec. 110-287. - Method of parking in metered spaces. 
(a)  Any vehicle parked on the street in any parking space for which a parking meter has been installed shall be parked with the hood of such vehicle alongside of or next to the parking meter alongside of such parking space and within the lines marked on the street for such parking space. 
(b)  Any vehicle parked in an off-street parking lot owned or operated by the city and in which parking is regulated by parking meters shall be parked entirely within the lines of a parking space, with the front end of the vehicle near the parking meter provided for such space. 
(Code 1981, § 18-167) 
Sec. 110-288. - Rate for parking in metered space. 
    The rate for parking in a metered parking space shall be $0.10 per hour. 
(Code 1981, § 18-168) 
Sec. 110-289. - Deposit of coin; overtime parking. 
(a)  When any vehicle is parked in any parking space for which a parking meter has been installed, either on a street or in an off-street parking lot, between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. on all days, except Sunday, New Year's Day, Memorial Day (May 30), July 4th, Labor Day, Thanksgiving Day and Christmas Day, the person parking such vehicle shall immediately deposit a coin of the United States, in the amount of $0.10 per hour, in payment of the fee imposed for such parking privilege, and shall operate such lever or other mechanical device on such parking meter as may be necessary for the proper functioning of the parking meter. Failure to do so shall constitute a violation of this section. 
(b)  No vehicle shall be permitted to remain parked in any parking space referred to in subsection (a) of this section beyond the parking time limit fixed for such space. Whenever a parking meter shall display a sign or signal showing illegal parking of a vehicle in such parking space, it shall be prima facie evidence that such vehicle has been parked in violation of this section. 
(c)  During actual loading and unloading of delivery vehicles within parking meter zones, the operators of such delivery vehicles shall be exempt from the provisions of this section. 
(Code 1981, § 18-169) 
Sec. 110-290. - Purpose of required deposit. 
    The coins required to be deposited as provided in this division are hereby levied under the power of the city to enforce police regulations and as fees to provide for the proper regulation and control of traffic upon the public streets of the city; to cover the costs of such meters and the installation of the meters; to cover the cost involved in the inspection, installation, operation, control and use of the parking spaces and the parking meters referred to in this division and the inspection and regulation involved in monitoring and regulating the parking of vehicles in the parking meter zones created by this division. 
(Code 1981, § 18-170) 
Sec. 110-291. - Vehicle owner not to cause or permit parking in violation of division. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to cause, allow or permit any vehicle registered in his name to be parked in violation of this division. 
(Code 1981, § 18-172) 
Sec. 110-292. - Injuring, tampering with, etc., meters. 
    It shall be unlawful and a class 1 misdemeanor for any person to deface, injure, tamper with, open or willfully break, destroy or impair the usefulness of any parking meter installed under the terms of this division. 
(Code 1981, § 18-173) 
State Law reference- Stealing from or tampering with parking meter, etc., Code of Virginia, § 18.2-152. 
Secs. 110-293-110-310. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PERMIT PARKING ZONES[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
State Law reference- Authority of city to issue parking permits, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1230. 

Sec. 110-311. - Zones established; permit required. 
(a)  The following areas of the city are hereby designated as permit parking zones, within which it shall be unlawful for any motor vehicle to be parked on a public right-of-way or street unless such vehicle shall properly display a parking permit validly issued in accordance with regulations adopted pursuant to this division: 
Centre Hill Court. That area encompassing and including those streets or rights-of-way formerly or presently known as and named Centre Hill Court, West Court, East Court, North Court and Centre Hill Avenue. 
(b)  The streets designated in the descriptions in subsection (a) of this section of permit parking zones shall be considered to be portions of such zones; provided, that no permit shall be required for parking on any street or portion of a street within such zone unless and until such street or portion thereof shall have been designated as a permit area pursuant to the regulations adopted under section 110-312. 
(Code 1981, § 18-179) 
Sec. 110-312. - Adoption of regulations. 
(a)  The city manager is hereby authorized and directed to promulgate such rules and regulations as may be deemed necessary and reasonable for the efficient and safe administration and control of parking within each such permit parking zone as from time to time may be established. Such regulations may include, but need not be limited to, the following matters: 
(1)  The format, display and method of issuance of permits to be issued pursuant to such regulations; 
(2)  The notification to be given to residents of the zone before implementation of the permit requirement and the standards for posting of signs or notices to indicate to the public the areas and times for which permits are required; 
(3)  The methods for determining additional areas in which a need for establishment of a permit parking zone exists, and for assuring that the interests of the residents of any such area are given full consideration before any such zone shall be recommended to the city council. 
(b)  Such rules and regulations and any subsequent amendments shall be submitted to the traffic and transportation safety commission for review and approval. 
(Code 1981, § 18-180) 
Secs. 110-313-110-330. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - PARKING LOTS 

Sec. 110-331. - Use of city parking lots for commercial purposes. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to use any part of any parking lot belonging to or operated by the city for the purpose of parking or storing thereon any motor vehicle for commercial purposes. The storing or parking of each such motor vehicle on any such lot shall be regarded as a separate offense under this section. 
(Code 1981, § 18-145) 
Secs. 110-332-110-350. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - BICYCLES; MOPEDS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 110-351. - Violations of article. 
    Unless otherwise specifically provided, a violation of any provision of this article shall constitute a class 4 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1981, § 7-1) 
Sec. 110-352. - Removing, altering, etc., frame number. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any unauthorized person to remove, destroy, mutilate or alter the number of any bicycle frame registered pursuant to this article. 
(b)  Nothing in this section shall prohibit the chief of police from stamping a number on the frame of a bicycle on which no serial number can be found or on which such number is illegible or insufficient for identification purposes. 
(Code 1981, § 7-2) 
Sec. 110-353. - Reports by dealers in secondhand bicycles and parts thereof. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person engaged in the business of buying secondhand bicycles, or any parts of secondhand bicycles, to fail to report to the chief of police, within 48 hours, the acquisition of any secondhand bicycle or parts thereof. Such report shall include the registration number and the frame number of such bicycle, a description thereof, together with the name and address of the person from whom the secondhand bicycle was acquired. In case of the purchase of any bicycle parts, the report shall describe each part and give the name and address of the person from whom the part was acquired. 
(Code 1981, § 7-3) 
Sec. 110-354. - Riding on frame or handlebars. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to ride, or to permit another to ride, on the frame or on the handlebars of any bicycle operated on any street, alley or highway in the city. 
(b)  A violation of this section shall constitute a traffic infraction punishable by a fine of not more than $200.00. 
(Code 1981, § 7-4) 
Sec. 110-355. - Use of a protective helmet while on a bicycle. 
(a)  Any person under 15 years of age shall wear a protective helmet that meets the standards promulgated by the American National Standards Institute or the Snell Memorial Foundation while riding or being carried on a bicycle on any highway, sidewalk, or public bicycle path. The term "highway" has the meaning set forth in Code of Virginia, § 46.2-100. Any person who violates this section shall be punishable by a fine of $25.00. However, such a fine shall be suspended for first-time violators and for violators who, subsequent to the violation but prior to imposition of the fine, purchase helmets of the type required by this section. 
(b)  A violation of this section shall not constitute negligence, assumption of risk, be considered in mitigation of damages of whatever nature, be admissible in evidence, or be the subject of comment by counsel in any action for the recovery of damages arising out of operation of any bicycle, nor shall anything in this section change any existing law, rule, or procedure pertaining to any civil action. 
(Ord. No. 00-58, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 110-356. - Riding of bicycles on sidewalks prohibited. 
    No person, except a law enforcement officer in the performance of his official duties, shall ride any bicycle on any sidewalk. 
(Ord. No. 02-29, 5-21-2002) 
Secs. 110-357-110-370. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - REGISTRATION[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
State Law reference- Authority of city as to licensing of bicycles and mopeds, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1720; registration of bicycle serial numbers, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-908. 

Sec. 110-371. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or use a bicycle or moped upon any of the streets, alleys or public highways of the city, without first obtaining a certificate of registration from the chief of police. 
(Code 1981, § 7-16) 
Sec. 110-372. - Application; fee. 
    Application for registration of a bicycle or moped shall be filed with the chief of police on numbered forms provided for that purpose. Such application shall be accompanied by a registration fee of $1.00. All such fees collected shall be turned over to the collector of city taxes, who shall pay the fees into the city treasury. 
(Code 1981, § 7-17; Ord. No. 17-30, 7-11-2017) 
Sec. 110-373. - Plates and cards generally. 
    The city shall provide metallic registration plates and seals, together with registration cards, for bicycles and mopeds, both to be numbered in numerical order, beginning with number one, the design and identification lettering to be approved by the chief of police. It shall be the duty of the chief of police to issue such a registration plate to each person applying for registration under this division and paying the registration fee, and to issue a corresponding registration card to such person. 
(Code 1981, § 7-18) 
Sec. 110-374. - Display of plate. 
    Upon the issuance of a registration plate under this division, the owner of the bicycle or moped for which it was issued shall attach the registration plate to the frame of such bicycle or moped. Such plate shall remain attached to the bicycle or moped during the period such bicycle or moped is operated within the city. 
(Code 1981, § 7-19) 
Sec. 110-375. - Removal, destruction, etc., of plate or card. 
    It shall be unlawful for any unauthorized person to remove, destroy, mutilate or alter any registration plate or registration card issued pursuant to the provisions of this division during the time in which such registration plate or card is operative. 
(Code 1981, § 7-20) 
Sec. 110-376. - Transfer. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, other than a licensed bicycle or moped dealer, to sell or transfer ownership of any bicycle or moped, without reporting to the chief of police, within 48 hours from the time thereof, full and complete information relative to such transfer, so that such bicycle or moped may be registered in the name of the transferee. The purchaser or transferee of any such bicycle or moped shall apply for a transfer of registration within five days from the time the bicycle or moped is acquired by him. There shall be no fee or charge for such transfer of registration. 
(Code 1981, § 7-21) 
Sec. 110-377. - Records to be kept. 
    The chief of police shall keep a permanent register in which shall be entered the name, address and age of the owner of each registered bicycle or moped, the date of registration and sufficient information to identify such bicycle or moped. 
(Code 1981, § 7-22) 
Secs. 110-378-110-400. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - PEDESTRIANS[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 98. 

Sec. 110-401. - Pedestrians to obey traffic signs, signals, etc. 
    Pedestrians shall obey signs and signals erected on highways or streets for the direction and control of travel and traffic and they shall obey the orders of police officers engaged in directing travel and traffic on the highways and streets. 
(Code 1981, § 18-16) 
State Law reference- Authority for above section, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-935. 
Sec. 110-402. - Right of pedestrians to cross intersection diagonally. 
    Pedestrians may cross an intersection diagonally when all traffic entering the intersection has been halted by lights, by other traffic control devices or by a peace officer or police officer. 
(Code 1981, § 18-17) 
State Law reference- Authority for above section, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-923. 
Sec. 110-403. - Playing or loitering on streets. 
    No person shall play or loiter on any street within this city in such manner as to impede the progress of any vehicle or to render dangerous the vehicular use of any street. Any person violating this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by a fine not to exceed $200.00. 
(Ord. No. 97-69, § 32-38, 6-3-1997) 
Secs. 110-404-110-430. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - ACCIDENTS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 110-431-110-445. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - REPORTS 

Sec. 110-446. - Reports by drivers. 
    The driver of a vehicle involved in an accident resulting in injury to or death of any person or total property damage to an apparent extent of $250.00 or more shall, within five days after the accident, file, with the police department, a copy of the report referred to in Code of Virginia, § 46.2-372. Such driver shall also file, with the police department, a copy of any supplemental report filed pursuant to such section. A willful failure to file a report required in this section shall constitute a violation of this section. 
(Code 1981, § 18-19) 
State Law reference- Authority for above section, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-381. 
Sec. 110-447. - Reports by passengers. 
    Whenever the driver of a vehicle is physically incapable of making an immediate or a written report of an accident, as required by this chapter or the state law adopted by this chapter, each other occupant of the vehicle at the time of the accident, if any, who is capable of so doing must make the report required to be made by the driver. A willful failure to make such report shall constitute a violation of this section. 
(Code 1981, § 18-20) 
Sec. 110-448. - Report by investigating officer. 
    Every law enforcement officer who, in the course of duty, investigates a motor vehicle accident of which report must be made, either at the time of and at the scene of the accident or thereafter and elsewhere, by interviewing participants or witnesses shall, within 24 hours after completing the investigation, forward to the police department a copy of the report required by Code of Virginia, § 46.2-373. 
(Code 1981, § 18-21) 
Secs. 110-449-110-470. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - ABANDONED AND INOPERATIVE VEHICLES[10] 
Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
State Law reference- Abandoned vehicle ordinance authorized, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1201; removal of certain unattended vehicles, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1213; regulation of certain towing, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1217. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 110-471. - Keeping of inoperative vehicles on residential, commercial or agricultural property; penalty for violations; removal of such vehicle. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to keep, except within a fully enclosed building or structure on any property zoned for residential or commercial or agricultural purposes, any motor vehicle, trailer or semitrailer, as such are defined in Code of Virginia, § 46.2-100, which is inoperative. As used in this section, an inoperative motor vehicle shall mean any motor vehicle, trailer or semitrailer which is not in operating condition; or does not display valid license plates, or does not display an inspection decal that is valid, or does display an inspection decal that has been expired for more than 60 days. 
(b)  Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be deemed guilty of a class 4 misdemeanor. 
(c)  The owners of property zoned for residential or commercial or agricultural purposes shall, within 15 days after receiving written notice from the city, remove therefrom any such inoperative motor vehicles, trailers or semitrailers that are not kept within a fully enclosed building or structure. Upon failure of the owner of such property to do so after such notice, the city, through its own agents or employees, may remove any such inoperative motor vehicles, trailers or semitrailers. If the city removes any such motor vehicles, trailers or semitrailers, the city may dispose of such motor vehicles, trailers or semitrailers after giving 15 days' notice to the owner of the vehicle. The cost of any such removal and disposal shall be chargeable to the owner of the vehicle who shall be primarily responsible for such cost. If the city cannot collect from the owner of the vehicle, the owner of the premises shall be responsible for the cost. Such cost may be collected by the city as taxes and levies are collected. Every cost authorized by this section with which the owner of the premises has been assessed shall constitute a lien against the property from which the vehicle was removed, the lien to continue until actual payment of such costs has been made to the city. 
(d)  Nothing in this section shall affect other ordinance provisions of the city, including the zoning ordinance, concerning motor vehicles, trailers or semitrailers; and the provisions of this section shall not apply to a licensed business which on June 26, 1970, is regularly engaged in business as an automobile dealer, salvage dealer or scrap processor. 
(Code 1981, § 21-58; Ord. No. 98-171, § 21-58, 9-30-1998) 
Editor's note- The zoning ordinance is on file in the office of the clerk of the city council. 
State Law reference- Authority for above section, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-904. 
Secs. 110-472-110-490. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ABANDONED VEHICLES 

Sec. 110-491. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Abandoned motor vehicle means a motor vehicle, trailer, or semitrailer or part of a motor vehicle, trailer or semitrailer that: 
(1)  Is inoperable and is left unattended on public property, other than an interstate highway or primary highway, for more than 48 hours; 
(2)  Has remained illegally on public property for more than 48 hours; 
(3)  Has remained for more than 48 hours on private property without the consent of the property's owner, regardless of whether it was brought onto the private property with the consent of the owner or person in control of the private property; 
(4)  Is inoperable, left unattended, or both, on an interstate highway; or 
(5)  Is inoperable, left unattended, or both, on the shoulder of a primary highway. 
    Demolisher means any person whose business is to convert a motor vehicle, trailer or semitrailer into processed scrap or scrap metal or otherwise to wreck or dismantle such vehicles. 
    Traffic hazard means any motor vehicle, trailer or semitrailer found on the public streets or grounds of the city, unattended by the owner or operator and constituting a hazard to traffic, or which is parked in such a manner as to be in violation of law. 
(Code 1981, § 18-185) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1200. 
Sec. 110-492. - City may take into custody; indemnity of city when vehicle removed from private property. 
(a)  The city may remove and take into custody any abandoned motor vehicle or any motor vehicle, trailer or semitrailer which is a traffic hazard. In this connection, the city may employ its own personnel, equipment and facilities or hire persons, equipment or facilities or firms or corporations that may be independent contractors for the purpose of removing, preserving, storing and selling at public auction such vehicles. 
(b)  If an abandoned motor vehicle is on private property, the vehicle shall not be removed under this section, without the written request of the owner, lessee or occupant of such property. The person requesting the removal of such vehicle shall indemnify the city against any loss or expense incurred by reason of the removal, storage or sale of the vehicle. 
(Code 1981, § 18-186) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, §§ 46.2-1201, 46.2-1213. 
Sec. 110-493. - Notice to owner of vehicle taken into custody. 
(a)  When the city or its authorized agent takes an abandoned motor vehicle into custody, it shall, within 15 days, by registered or certified mail, return receipt requested, notify the owner of record of the motor vehicle and all persons having security interests in the vehicle of record, that it has been taken into custody. The notice shall (i) state the year, make, model, and serial number of the abandoned motor vehicle; (ii) set forth the location of the facility where it is being held; and (iii) inform the owner and any persons having security interests of their right to reclaim it within 15 days after the date of the notice after payment of all towing, preservation, and storage charges resulting from placing the vehicle in custody. 
(b)  The notice shall state that the failure of the owner or persons having security interests to reclaim the vehicle within the time provided shall constitute (i) a waiver by the owner and all persons having any security interests of all right, title, and interest in the vehicle and (ii) consent to the sale of the abandoned motor vehicle at a public auction. 
(c)  If records of the state department of motor vehicles contain no address for the owner or no address of any person shown by the department's records to have a security interest, or if the identity and addresses of the owner and all persons having security interests cannot be determined with reasonable certainty, notice by publication once in a newspaper of general circulation in the area where the motor vehicle was abandoned shall be sufficient to meet all requirements of notice pursuant to this division as to any person who cannot be notified pursuant to the foregoing provisions of this section. Notice by publication may contain multiple listings of abandoned motor vehicles. Any notice of this kind shall be within the time requirements prescribed by this section for notice by mail and shall have the same contents required for a notice by mail. 
(d)  The consequences of failure to reclaim an abandoned motor vehicle shall be as set forth in a notice given in accordance with and pursuant to this section. 
(Code 1981, § 18-187) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1202. 
Sec. 110-494. - Sale of vehicle at public auction; disposition of proceeds. 
    If an abandoned motor vehicle is not reclaimed as provided for in section 110-493, the city or its authorized agent shall, notwithstanding the provisions of Code of Virginia, § 46.2-617, sell it at public auction. The purchaser of the motor vehicle shall take title to the motor vehicle free of all liens and claims of ownership of others, shall receive a sales receipt at the auction, and shall be entitled to apply to and receive from the state department of motor vehicles a certificate of title and registration card for the vehicle. The sales receipt from the sale shall be sufficient title only for purposes of transferring the vehicle to a demolisher for demolition, wrecking, or dismantling, and in that case no further titling of the vehicle shall be necessary. From the proceeds of the sale of an abandoned motor vehicle the city or its authorized agent shall reimburse itself for the expenses of the auction, the cost of towing, preserving, and storing the vehicle which resulted from placing the abandoned motor vehicle in custody, and all notice and publication costs incurred pursuant to section 110-493. Any remainder from the proceeds of a sale shall be held for the owner of the abandoned motor vehicle or any person having secure interests in the vehicle, as their interests may appear, for 90 days, and then be deposited into the treasury of the city. 
(Code 1981, § 18-188) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1203. 
Sec. 110-495. - Vehicles abandoned in garages. 
    Notwithstanding Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1200, any motor vehicle, trailer, semitrailer, or part thereof shall be considered abandoned and may be reported by the garagekeeper to the city if it has been left in a garage for more than ten days or for more than ten days beyond the period the vehicle was to remain on the premises pursuant to a contract, after notice by registered or certified mail, return receipt requested, to the owner of record and all persons having security interests of record therein, to reclaim the vehicle within 15 days of the notice. Any abandoned motor vehicle left in a garage may be taken into custody by the city in accordance with section 110-492 and shall be subject to the notice and sale provisions contained in sections section 110-493 and section 110-494. If, however, the vehicle is reclaimed in accordance with section 110-493, the person reclaiming it, in addition to the other charges required to be paid, shall pay the reasonable charges of the garagekeeper, unless otherwise provided by contract or ordinance. If the vehicle is sold pursuant to section 110-494, any garagekeeper's charges shall be paid from, and to the extent of, the excess of the proceeds of sale after paying the expenses of the auction, the costs of towing, preserving, and storing the vehicle which resulted from placing the vehicle in custody and all notice and publication costs incurred pursuant to section 110-493. Except as otherwise provided in Code of Virginia, §§ 46.2-1200-46.2-1208, nothing in this section shall restrict any rights conferred on any person under Code of Virginia, §§ 43-32-43-36. For the purposes of this section, the term "garage" means any commercial parking place, motor vehicle storage facility, or establishment for the servicing, repair, maintenance, or sale of motor vehicles whether or not the vehicle had been brought to that location with the consent of the owner or person in control of the premises and the term "garagekeeper" means the operator of a garage. 
(Code 1981, § 18-189) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1204. 
Sec. 110-496. - Disposition of inoperable abandoned vehicles. 
    Notwithstanding any other provisions of this article, any inoperable motor vehicle, trailer, semitrailer, or part of a motor vehicle, trailer, or semitrailer which has been taken into custody pursuant to other provisions of this article may be disposed of to a demolisher, without the title and without the notification procedures, by the person or locality on whose property or in whose possession the motor vehicle, trailer, or semitrailer is found. The demolisher, on taking custody of the inoperable abandoned motor vehicle shall notify the state department of motor vehicles on forms and in the manner prescribed by the commissioner of the state department of motor vehicles. Notwithstanding any other provision of law, no other report or notice shall be required in this instance. Such demolisher, in disposing of such vehicle, shall follow the provisions of Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1206. 
(Code 1981, § 18-190) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1205. 
Secs. 110-497-110-520. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XII. - RAILROADS[11] 

Footnotes: 
--- (11) --- 
Charter reference- Authority of city council to regulate railroads, § 4-2. 
State Law reference- Railroad corporations, Code of Virginia, § 56-345.1 et seq. 

Sec. 110-521. - Standing of vehicles on tracks. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to stand any wagon or other vehicle on the track of any railroad, so as to hinder or endanger a moving train. Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall be fined not less than $100.00 nor more than $500.00. 
(Code 1981, § 25-5) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 56-412.1. 
Sec. 110-522. - Trespassing on railroad track. 
(a)  Any person who goes upon the track of a railroad other than to pass over such road at a public or private crossing or who willfully rides, drives or leads any animal or contrives for any animal to go on such track except to cross as aforesaid, without the consent of the railroad company or person operating such road, shall be guilty of a class 4 misdemeanor. A second violation of the provisions of this section occurring within two years of the first violation shall be punishable as a class 3 misdemeanor. A third or subsequent violation of the provisions of this section occurring within two years of a second or subsequent violation shall be punishable as a class 1 misdemeanor. This section shall not apply to any section of track which has been legally abandoned pursuant to an order of a federal or state agency having jurisdiction over the track and is not being used for railroad service. 
(b)  For purposes of this section, the term "track" shall mean the rail, ties, and ballast of the railroad. 
(Code 1981, § 25-6) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-159. 
Sec. 110-523. - Trespassing upon trains. 
    If any person, not being a passenger or employee, shall be found trespassing upon any railroad car or train of any railroad in the city, by riding on any car, or any part thereof, on its arrival, stay or departure at or from any station or depot of such railroad, or on the passage of any such car or train over any part of any such railroad, such person shall be guilty of a class 4 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1981, § 25-7) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-160. 
Sec. 110-524. - Trespassers jumping on or off trains. 
    If any person, not being a passenger or employee, but a trespasser, shall jump on or off any railroad car or train on its arrival, stay or departure at or from any station or depot of such railroad, or on the passage of any such car or train over any part of any such railroad, such person shall be guilty of a class 4 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1981, § 25-8) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-161.

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
