ARTICLE II. - WATER SUPPLY[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- General powers of the city as to waterworks, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2109; water supply systems generally, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2134 et seq.; health regulations pertaining to public water supplies, Code of Virginia, § 32.1-167 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 07-98, adopted October 23, 2007, amended Division 1 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Division 1, §§ 114-31-114-48, pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from §§ 114-31-114-48. 

Subdivision 1. - General Provisions 

Sec. 114-31. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Applicant means a person applying for water service. 
    Property means the location for which the applicant seeks water service. 
    Property owner means the owner of the property for which water service is sought or at which the city is supplying water service. 
    Superintendent means the superintendent of the water distribution division of the city's water department. 
    Tenant means a person who occupies property owned by another pursuant to a lease between the tenant and the property owner. 
    Utility billing office means the city department responsible for accepting and reviewing applications for water service, arranging for water service initiation and cessation, issuing bills for water service, resolving billing issues, and arranging for transmission of delinquent accounts to the collector of city taxes. 
    Water distribution division or distribution division mean the water distribution division of the city's water department. 
    Water service means the provision of water to residences, business, or industry by the city using city infrastructure. 
    Water service account means an account established in the utility billing office under which the city provides water service to a water service customer in accordance with such terms and conditions as the utility billing office may specify. 
    Water service customer or customer means a person who holds a water service account. 
(Ord. No. 07-98, 10-23-2007; Ord. No. 08-107, § 1, 12-9-2008; Ord. No. 17-30, 7-11-2017) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 114-32. - Violations of article generally. 
    Unless otherwise specifically provided, a violation of any provision of this article shall constitute a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 07-98, 10-23-2007) 
Sec. 114-33. - Liability for damages and costs resulting from violations of article. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall, in addition to any penalty that may be imposed, be liable for all damages and costs resulting from such violation. 
(Ord. No. 07-98, 10-23-2007) 
Sec. 114-34. - General supervision of distribution system. 
    The director of public works shall have general supervision of the city's water distribution system. 
(Ord. No. 07-98, 10-23-2007) 
Sec. 114-35. - Appointment and general powers and duties of superintendent of distribution division. 
    The city manager shall appoint a superintendent of the water distribution division, who shall have direct charge of the city's water distribution system and its facilities, including pumping stations, water tanks and meter and repair and of all such construction work as may be necessary, along with such other duties as may be assigned to him. The superintendent shall be accountable for all expenditures of the water distribution division. The superintendent shall also, at the end of each fiscal year, render to the city manager a complete inventory of all stock and equipment in the water distribution division, together with an annual report setting forth, in detail, the operation of the water distribution system for such fiscal year. 
(Ord. No. 07-98, 10-23-2007) 
Sec. 114-36. - Inspection of reservoir, watershed, etc., by health director. 
    The health director shall thoroughly inspect the reservoir, watershed and streams of the city's water supply whenever it shall be deemed necessary, and make a report thereof, in writing, to the city council. 
(Ord. No. 07-98, 10-23-2007) 
Sec. 114-37. - Consent required for introduction of service, installation of corporation cock, etc. 
    No person, except an authorized employee of the water department in the performance of his duty, shall introduce into any lot or building water from the city pipes, or install any corporation cock or any fixture upon any of the pipes within the street lines, or turn on water to any premises, without the written consent of the superintendent, to be granted or denied pursuant to uniform city standards. 
(Ord. No. 07-98, 10-23-2007) 
Sec. 114-38. - Adequate supply required for occupied buildings; notice to health department when service suspended. 
    There shall be an adequate supply of running water, supplied by the city or approved by the health department, piped into each occupied building in the city. The health department shall be notified by the water department, within 48 hours, for necessary action, when the water service to any such building has been suspended. 
(Ord. No. 07-98, 10-23-2007) 
State Law reference- Authority to require connection of premises to city's facilities provided for furnishing water, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2143. 
Sec. 114-39. - Conditions on which service supplied. 
    The city may supply water to any person who completes the application described in subsection (a) of section 114-144 and pays any applicable deposit and fees. Any such service shall be contingent on the applicant's agreeing to comply with all of the provisions of this article, and agreeing to pay for water at the rate then existing and at such other rates as may be subsequently put into effect. 
(Ord. No. 07-98, 10-23-2007; Ord. No. 08-107, § 1, 12-9-2008) 
Sec. 114-40. - Right of entry to premises served. 
    Any owner or occupant of any lot or building into which city water is introduced shall permit the superintendent or any other authorized employee of the water department or the building inspections department to enter such lot or building at reasonable hours to inspect the work therein; and in case of refusal to allow such inspection, the water shall cut off from such premises. 
(Ord. No. 07-98, 10-23-2007) 
Sec. 114-41. - Line extensions for commercial and industrial use. 
    Applications for water line extensions for commercial and industrial use shall be referred to the city manager and will be considered by the city council upon the merits of the individual case and determined upon estimated quantities of water to be furnished. 
(Ord. No. 07-98, 10-23-2007) 
Sec. 114-42. - Installation, location, size, etc., of meters. 
(a)  Water meters and meter boxes shall be installed within the city limits by the water department. All meters shall be located at a convenient place between the curb line and the property line. All service pipes, with the exception of fire service pipes, must be equipped with meters. The size of such meters shall be determined by the superintendent. 
(b)  No water meter shall be installed to serve more than one house. In case there is more than one house on one lot, each of such houses shall be served by an individual meter. In the case of an apartment complex, one meter may be permitted to serve all the apartments, but separate meters may be installed at the curb, if the owner so desires. Separate meters may be required for each side of a double tenement house, but in every case where a deed may be given separately for each tenement, individual meters shall be required, even though such tenements are owned by the same party at the time of connecting with city water. In any case where only outside fixtures serve a house, the water shall not be brought into indoor fixtures without first making the connection serving such house conform with the requirements of this article. 
(Ord. No. 07-98, 10-23-2007) 
Sec. 114-43. - Damage to meter by hot water. 
    If, on removing any water meter for repairs, it is found that such meter has, in the judgment of the superintendent, been damaged by the passage of hot water through it, the cost of the necessary repairs to such meter shall be added to the water bill of the owner of the property served and shall be treated as a part of such bill. If, in any particular case, it is evident to the superintendent that such damage will frequently recur, the property owner shall be required to install a check valve or such other suitable means of protecting the meter as the superintendent may direct, within ten days after receiving written notice from the superintendent to do so. On failure to comply with such notice, the water shall be cut off from the premises. 
(Ord. No. 07-98, 10-23-2007) 
Sec. 114-44. - Discontinuance of service for failure to pay bill for fixtures, material, work or repairs furnished or done by water department. 
    If any bill for fixtures, material, work or repairs furnished or done by the water department remains unpaid at the end of the month succeeding the furnishing of such fixtures or material or the completion of such work or repairs, the superintendent may cut off the city water from the premises involved; and the water shall remain cut off until all such bills are paid. 
(Ord. No. 07-98, 10-23-2007) 
Sec. 114-45. - Waste of water; repair of leaks. 
(a)  No person shall unnecessarily consume any city water by a careless or extravagant use of the water or permit the water to run from any hydrant, cock or fixture without proper care to prevent waste. 
(b)  If any pipe, hydrant, cock or other fixture is found leaking, the owner of the premises shall have the necessary repairs made, within five days after receipt of notice from the superintendent to do so. 
(c)  If the necessary repairs are not made within five days, the water shall be cut off and shall not be turned on again until such repairs have been made. A fee of $20.00 shall be charged for turning on the water after it has been cut off. 
(Ord. No. 07-98, 10-23-2007; Ord. No. 08-107, § 1, 12-9-2008) 
Sec. 114-46. - Use of public hydrants. 
    The public hydrants shall be for the reasonable use of the public and the superintendent shall cut off the water from the public hydrants, whenever it is found that the water from such hydrants is being wasted or otherwise misused. 
(Ord. No. 07-98, 10-23-2007) 
Sec. 114-47. - Damaging, tampering with, etc., water department property, fixtures, etc. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to damage or deface any property of the water department or to cut any trees or shrubbery or dump any refuse or rubbish upon any part of the property of the water department. 
(b)  No person shall tamper with any valve, hydrant, pump, motor, curb cock, meter or any other equipment or fixture of the water department wherever situated. 
(c)  This section shall not apply to authorized employees or agents of the city in the lawful performance of their duties. 
(Ord. No. 07-98, 10-23-2007) 
Sec. 114-48. - Climbing on water tanks, standpipes, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, except an authorized employee or agent of the city, to climb upon any elevated tank, standpipe or other structure of the water distribution system. Any person violating this section shall be guilty of a class 4 misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 07-98, 10-23-2007) 
Subdivision II. - Water Conservation 

Sec. 114-49. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this subdivision, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Bucket means a bucket or other container holding five gallons or less when used singly by one person. 
    Established landscape means landscape plants existing in an area after such period of time as to accomplish an establishment and maintenance of growth. 
    Fountain means a water display where water is sprayed strictly for ornamental purposes. 
    Garden means any non-commercial garden planted primarily for household use. The term "non-commercial" as used in this definition includes the incidental direct sale of items from such a garden to the public. 
    Handheld hose means a hose attended by one person and fitted with a manual or automatic shutoff nozzle. 
    Landscape plant means any member of the kingdom Plantae, including any tree, shrub, vine, herb, flower, succulent, ground cover or grass species that grows or has been planted outdoors. 
    New landscape means any landscape made up of plants or seeds planted in or transplanted to an area within such period of time as to accomplish a reasonable establishment and maintenance of growth. 
    Paved areas means streets, sidewalks, driveways, patios, parking lots, and other surface areas covered with brick, paving, tile or other material through which water cannot pass. 
    Recycled water means water originally potable but circulated for reuse after delivery from the public water system. 
    Swimming pool means any structure, basin, chamber or tank, including hot tubs, containing an artificial body of water for swimming, diving or recreational bathing and having a depth of two feet or more at any point. 
(Ord. No. 07-98, 10-23-2007) 
Sec. 114-50. - Purpose; enforcement; exemptions. 
(a)  Purpose. The purpose of this subdivision is to establish water conservation reduction measures to be imposed when the Appomattox River Water Authority ("ARWA") requests or directs such restriction or when the governor of the Commonwealth or other state or federal authority, pursuant to applicable law, declares an emergency, imposes mandatory water conservation measures, and authorizes the city to enforce such measures. 
(b)  State or federal measures. Should the Governor or other state or federal authority, pursuant to applicable law, declare an emergency, impose mandatory water conservation measures, and authorize the city to enforce such measures, the city shall enforce those measures pursuant to this article to the extent that such measures impose greater restrictions on the use of water than those in this article. Otherwise, any water conservation measures imposed by this article shall remain in effect as provided in this article. 
(c)  Exemptions. This article shall not apply to any governmental activity, institution, business, residence, or industry when it has been determined by the city manager that an exemption is necessary for the following: 
(1)  The public health, safety and welfare; 
(2)  The prevention of severe economic hardship or the substantial loss of employment; or 
(3)  The health of any person. 
Recycled water and water supplied from public or private groundwater sources shall also be exempt from this article. 
(Ord. No. 07-98, 10-23-2007) 
Sec. 114-51. - Declaration of conservation measures. 
(a)  In general. The city manager shall declare the imposition of voluntary, mandatory or emergency water conservation measures whenever the city is experiencing a water supply emergency or the need to avert a water supply emergency. Such emergency or need to avert an emergency shall be deemed to exist whenever declared by ARWA or when the Governor or other state or federal authority, pursuant to applicable law, declares an emergency, imposes mandatory water conservation measures, and authorizes the city to enforce such measures. Notices of the implementation and termination of the water conservation measures shall be publicly announced and published in a daily newspaper for at least one day. The implementation or termination of the measures shall become effective immediately upon publication of the respective notice. 
(b)  Voluntary conservation measures. When voluntary water conservation measures are in effect, the city manager shall request the general public, businesses and public agencies in the city to implement and comply with the following water use reduction measures: 
(1)  Fountains. Reduce operation to hours between 8:00 a.m. and 8:00 p.m., except that operation may be unrestricted on any two days during a week at the option of the operator or owner. 
(2)  Paved areas. Reduce washing to any hours during any two days in a week. Washing paved areas for immediate health and safety is exempted. 
(3)  Swimming pools. Reduce filling and replenishing to levels required to maintain health and safety. 
(4)  Gardens and established landscape. Reduce watering to hours between 8:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m. any day. Watering by bucket is unrestricted. 
(5)  Vehicle washing. Reduce noncommercial washing of mobile equipment to any hours during any two days in a week using a handheld hose having a positive (i.e., automatic) shutoff nozzle. Commercial mobile equipment washing businesses are exempt. 
(6)  Restaurants. No restrictions. 
(7)  Pubic utilities. Reduce scheduled sewer and hydrant flushing by 50 percent. Flushing to meet immediate health and safety requirements is exempt. 
(8)  New landscape. Watering unrestricted during the first 30 days after planting and shall conform to subsection (b)(4) of this section after the 30 days. 
(c)  Mandatory conservation measures. When mandatory water conservation measures are in effect, the general public, businesses and public agencies shall comply with the following water use restrictions: 
(1)  Fountains. Operation prohibited. 
(2)  Paved areas. Washing prohibited except for immediate health and safety requirements. 
(3)  Swimming pools. Reduce filling and replenishing to levels to maintain health and safety 
(4)  Gardens, plants, and established landscapes. Water only from 8:00 p.m. to 8:00 a.m. on any day. 
(5)  Vehicle washing. Reduce non-commercial washing or mobile equipment to one day a week using a handheld hose having a positive (i.e. automatic) shutoff nozzle. Commercial mobile equipment washing businesses are exempt. 
(6)  Restaurants. Serve water to customers only upon request. 
(7)  Public utilities. Conduct sewer and hydrant flushing only to the extent required to meet immediate health and safety needs. 
(8)  New landscape. Water unrestricted during the first 30 days after planting and shall conform to subsection (b)(4) of this section after the first 30 days. 
(d)  Emergency conservation measures. When emergency water conservation measures are in effect, the general public, businesses, and public agencies shall comply with the following water use restrictions: 
(1)  Fountains. Operation prohibited. 
(2)  Paved areas. Washing prohibited except for immediate health and safety requirements. 
(3)  Swimming pools. Reduce filling and replenishing to levels to maintain health and safety. 
(4)  Gardens, plants, and all landscapes. Water only from 8:00 p.m. on Wednesdays to 8:00 a.m. on Thursdays. 
(5)  Vehicle washing. No non-commercial washing. Commercial mobile equipment washing businesses are exempt. 
(6)  Restaurants. Serve water to customers only upon request. 
(7)  Public utilities. Conduct sewer and hydrant flushing only to the extent required to meet immediate health and safety needs. 
(Ord. No. 07-98, 10-23-2007) 
Sec. 114-52. - Violations; evidentiary presumptions. 
(a)  In General. 
(1)  Violation. It shall be a violation of this article for any person to intentionally, knowingly, recklessly or negligently use, cause the use of or permit the use of water in violation of any of the mandatory or emergency sections of this article. 
(2)  Evidentiary presumptions. For purposes of this article, when water has been used in a manner contrary to a mandatory or emergency section of this article, it shall be presumed that the person in whose name a water meter connection is registered with the department has knowingly used, caused the use of, or permitted the use of water in such a contrary manner. Proof that a particular premises had a water meter connection registered in the name of the defendant cited in a pleading filed pursuant to this article shall constitute in evidence a prima facie presumption that the defendant is the person who used, caused the use of, or permitted the use of water in a manner contrary to any mandatory or emergency section of this article. 
(b)  Violations of mandatory restrictions. On the first offense, a person violating a mandatory restriction pursuant to this article shall receive a written warning. On the second offense, the person shall be assessed a civil penalty of $50.00. On the third offense, the person shall be assessed a civil penalty of $100.00. On the fourth and any subsequent offense, the person shall be assessed a civil penalty of $200.00. Any civil penalty imposed pursuant to this paragraph shall be added to and become part of the offending person's city water bill; and such civil penalty, if unpaid, shall be collected in any manner authorized for the collection of the city's water bills. 
(c)  Violations of emergency restrictions. On the first offense, a person violating an emergency restriction pursuant to this article shall be assessed a civil penalty of $50.00. On the second offense, the person shall be assessed a civil penalty of $100.00. On the third offense, the person shall be assessed a civil penalty of $200.00. On the fourth and any subsequent offense, the person shall be assessed a civil penalty of $300.00. Any civil penalty imposed pursuant to this subsection shall be added to and become part of the offending person's city water bill; and such civil penalty, if unpaid, shall be collected in any manner authorized for the collection of the city's water bills. 
(Ord. No. 07-98, 10-23-2007) 
Sec. 114-53. - Appeals and enforcement. 
(a)  Appeals. A person shall have the right to appeal to the city manager upon receiving written notice of any violation or upon the imposition of a civil penalty. The city manager shall notify the person in writing of the time and place for the hearing of the appeal within a reasonable time prior to such hearing, which shall occur no more than 15 business days after the city manager receives written notice of the appeal. The city manager shall notify the person in writing of the city manager's final decision no more than 15 business days after the hearing. 
(b)  Enforcement. The city manager is authorized to designate any qualified personnel under his supervision to enforce this article, including the imposition of civil penalties; and he is authorized to implement policies or rules for the administration of this article. 
(Ord. No. 07-98, 10-23-2007) 
Secs. 114-54-114-65. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CONNECTIONS 

Sec. 114-66. - When required. 
(a)  All persons owning property, except vacant lots, along the line of any public facility for furnishing water, or having the right of access to any such facility, or having the right of access to a private facility for furnishing water connected with a public facility for furnishing water, shall connect their premises with such facility, within four months after the completion of any such facility. Whenever a new facility for furnishing water is completed and ready for use, the health director shall give notice of the requirements of this section to all persons owning property along the line of such facility or having the right of access thereto. 
(b)  This section shall apply to all improvements using water along the line of any public facility for furnishing water within 150 feet of the point of connection to the public facility, except when, in the discretion of the director of public works or his designated representative, the requirement for connection would cause undue and extreme hardship to result to the owner. 
(Code 1981, § 38-30) 
State Law reference- Authority to require connection of premises to city's facilities provided for furnishing water, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2143. 
Sec. 114-67. - Permit. 
(a)  Any person desiring to connect his premises with the city water system shall first obtain a permit for such connection from the director of public works. 
(b)  When any person shall desire a permit required by this section, he or his authorized agent shall make a written application for such permit to the director of public works. Such application shall set forth the name of the applicant and the location and description of the property for which the connection is desired. 
(Code 1981, § 38-31) 
Sec. 114-68. - Fees. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases when used in this division, shall have the meaning ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Laundromat means a facility containing coin-operated laundry machines that are intended for self-service operation by the customer. 
    Nursing home means a facility that provides skilled nursing care and rehabilitation services to people with illnesses, injuries or functional disabilities, either as an independent facility, or as a facility operating within a hospital or retirement community. 
(b)  Fee. Each person who desires to use the city water system shall first pay a connection fee for the privilege of connecting to the water system as specified in the following table: 
Type of Meter Connection Water 

Connection Fee Residential Use SF Residential $2,840.00 Multifamily Residential (per dwelling unit) 2,840.00 Commercial/Industrial Use 5/8 ? meter 2,840.00 1? meter 4,600.00 1.5? meter 8,040.00 2? meter 14,720.00 3? meter 29,440.00 4? meter 46,000.00 6? meter 92,000.00 8? meter 147,200.00 10? meter 264,592.00 12? meter 425,592.00 Other Use Hotels and motels (per sleeping room) 1,420.00 Hospitals (per bed) 3,408.00 Nursing homes (per bed) 2,272.00 Laundromats (per machine) 5,680.00 Connections Made Outside City Limits Fees for connections to structures located outside the geographical limits of the City of Petersburg shall be double the otherwise applicable rate shown in this table.  
(c)  Purpose of connection fee. The purpose of the water connection fees prescribed by this section is to finance the capital costs of water infrastructure, including water pumping, transmission and storage. The fees shall be fair and reasonable, and shall be established based on meter size or other waterworks capacity considerations. 
(d)  Assessment. A water connection fee shall be assessed against: 
(1)  A use or structure not connected to the water system when such use or structure connects; and 
(2)  A use or structure connected to the water system whenever such use or structure is expanded or modified so as to result in an increase in meter size or a change in the type of meter connection. 
No connection fee shall be assessed for replacement of an existing water connection if the use or structure served by the connection is not expanded or modified. 
(e)  Payment of fees. Connection fees assessed pursuant to this section and tap fees assessed pursuant to section 114-69 of this division shall be paid to the collector of city taxes at the time an application for a permit for water service connection pursuant to section 114-67 of this division is approved, except that the utility billing office may establish a payment plan for payment of tap fees for residential customers for good cause shown. No application for a permit for water service connection shall be approved until such time as the city has issued a building permit for the structure. The fees assessed under this section shall not be waived. 
(f)  Connection. The city shall connect a use or structure to the water system upon (i) payment of the fees pursuant to subsection (e); and (ii) completion of any final inspection by the public utilities division, except that the department director may authorize connection prior to completion of a final inspection for good cause shown. 
(g)  Deposit of monies. All monies collected as connection fees under this section shall be deposited into the city's general account, but shall be recorded in a dedicated account in the public utility enterprise fund. Monies shall be disbursed from that dedicated account solely to pay capital costs associated with infrastructure projects designed to develop water supply and distribution facilities that will serve the city, and related debt service on the capital costs of such projects. 
(Code 1981, § 38-32; Ord. 06-32, 3-21-2006; Ord. No. 08-93, § 1, 10-28-2008; Ord. No. 17-30, 7-11-2017) 
Sec. 114-69. - Work to be done by city; charge for such work. 
(a)  No person shall be permitted to make any taps or otherwise connect to the distribution system of the water department, except duly authorized employees of the city. 
(b)  All connections to water mains shall be installed by the city. The charge for such work shall be determined and established, from time to time, by the director of public works. The charge shall be based on the average cost of making such connections and shall be in addition to the fees prescribed in section 114-68. 
(Code 1981, § 38-33) 
Sec. 114-70. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 08-93, § 5, adopted October 28, 2008, repealed § 114-70, which pertained to payment of fees and charges and derived from § 38-34 of the 1981 Code. 
Sec. 114-71. - Minimum size of tap. 
    No tap of less than three-quarters of an inch inside diameter shall be permitted for connection to any water service pipe and no replacement shall be made of less than three-quarters of an inch pipe. 
(Code 1981, § 38-35) 
Sec. 114-72. - Severability. 
    The provisions of this division are severable, and if any section, subsection, sentence, part or application of this division be adjudged by any court of competent jurisdiction to be invalid, such judgment shall not affect, impair or invalidate any other section, subsection, sentence, part or application but shall be confined in its operation to the section, subsection, sentence, part or application at issue involved in the controversy in which such judgment shall have been rendered. 
(Ord. No. 08-93, § 2, 10-28-2008) 
Secs. 114-73-114-90. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - FIRE PROTECTION[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, ch. 54. 

Subdivision I. - In General 

Sec. 114-91. - Permit for connection and fees. 
(a)  Generally. No person shall make, or cause to be made, a connection with the water distribution system of the city, which connection is intended exclusively for fire protection purposes, unless he first obtains a written permit so to do from the superintendent. A written application for such permit shall be filed with the superintendent. Such application shall be signed by the owner of the property to be served or by his duly authorized agent. 
(b)  Outside-city fire connections. For each public fire hydrant, private or corporate fire hydrant or private or corporate fire connection located outside of the city limits, the permittee shall first pay a connection fee in the amount of $1,000.00 per fire connection or hydrant. The connection fees shall only be assessed to fire connections or hydrants which receive water directly or indirectly from the city's water distribution system. 
(Code 1981, § 38-47) 
Sec. 114-92. - Drawings of pipes, branches and outlets. 
    Each application filed under section 114-91 shall be accompanied by neat scaled drawings, showing in plan and section the location of main fire services pipes, branches and outlets, which drawings shall be kept on file in the office of the superintendent. 
(Code 1981, § 38-48) 
Sec. 114-93. - Water department to make connection and install service pipes; costs to be paid by owner. 
    Connections made pursuant to a permit provided for in section 114-91 shall be made, and service pipes shall be laid, by the water department, and the owner of the property served shall pay an amount equal to the cost of material, plus ten percent, and labor used, plus 20 percent, as determined by the superintendent, plus the cost of the use of tools and equipment. Such cost shall also include the cost of relaying the paving in its original condition. 
(Code 1981, § 38-49) 
Sec. 114-94. - Size and material. 
    Services intended exclusively for fire protection shall be not less than six inches in diameter and shall be of a material satisfactory to the superintendent. 
(Code 1981, § 38-50) 
Sec. 114-95. - Pipes to be in full view; inspections and tests; turning on water at outlet. 
(a)  All fire service pipes shall be in full view from the point where such pipes enter a building to their ends, and duly authorized employees of the water department shall be permitted to inspect such fire services whenever the superintendent may deem it advisable. 
(b)  The water shall not be turned on at any outlet of fire services, except in case of fire or unless it is desired to inspect or test the fire service. In every case, when it is desired to make a test or inspection that will require the turning on of the city water, written notice shall be given the superintendent in ample time to permit him to send an employee of the water department to witness such test. 
(Code 1981, § 38-51) 
Sec. 114-96. - Meters. 
    A meter of a type approved by the director of public works may be installed at any time on any fire service installed under this article, within the discretion of the superintendent. Such a meter may be required if the director of public works or the superintendent has reason to believe that water is being used for purposes other than fire protection. 
(Code 1981, § 38-52) 
Sec. 114-97. - Additions and alterations. 
    In no case shall any additions or alterations be made to fire service pipes, for the connection of which a permit has been obtained as provided in section 114-91, their branches and outlets, without the written consent of the superintendent. Such additions and alterations shall be subject to the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1981, § 38-53) 
Secs. 114-98-114-115. - Reserved. 
Subdivision II. - Fire Hydrants[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, ch. 54. 

Sec. 114-116. - Permit to use water-Required. 
    No person shall use water from any fire hydrant connected to the city water distribution system, until he has obtained a permit therefor from the superintendent. This section shall not apply to authorized city employees in the performance of their duties. 
(Code 1981, § 38-65) 
Sec. 114-117. - Same-Application and charges. 
(a)  Application. Any person desiring a permit required by section 114-116 shall make written application therefor to the superintendent, stating where the fire hydrant in question is located and for what purpose he desires to use the water. 
(b)  Outside-city fees. A charge of $100.00 per day, plus the cost of water and labor for any work done by the city, shall be billed for the use of a city hydrant outside the city limits. 
(Code 1981, § 38-66) 
Sec. 114-118. - Issuance. 
    Upon the filing of an application under section 114-117, the superintendent, may issue a written permit for such use when it conforms to uniform city standards. 
(Code 1981, § 38-67) 
Sec. 114-119. - Use of approved hydrant wrench. 
    Under no circumstances shall any person, city employee or otherwise, operate a fire hydrant connected to the city water distribution system, without a suitable hydrant wrench of a type or style approved by the superintendent. 
(Code 1981, § 38-68) 
Secs. 114-120-114-135. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - SERVICE CHARGES[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Water fees and charges to be fair and reasonable, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2143. 

Sec. 114-136. - Service fee and rates inside city limits. 
(a)  A nonrefundable application fee of $25.00 shall be included on the bill issued during the customer's first billing cycle. Such fee shall also be paid for any transfer of accounts from one customer to another or from one location to another. 
(b)  The monthly rates for water furnished by the city to customers within the city limits shall be based on hundred cubic feet of usage, plus capacity fee, outlined below: 
(1)  For the first 300 cubic feet, per 100 cubic feet ..... $0.597 
(2)  From 301 cubic feet through 12,500 cubic feet, per 100 cubic feet ..... 2.527 
(3)  All over 12,500 cubic feet, per 100 cubic feet ..... 1.621 
(c)  The monthly capacity fee for water furnished within the city limits shall be based upon the following meter sizes:

(Code 1981, § 38-81; Ord. No. 97-59, § 38-81, 5-20-1997; Ord. No. 01-32, 5-15-2001; Ord. No. 04-58, 7-6-2004; Ord. No. 07-23, 3-20-2007; Ord. No. 08-107, § 1, 12-9-2008; Ord.
