No. 17-25, § 1, 6-6-2017) 
Sec. 114-137. - Water rates for multifamily dwelling units. 
    Where more than one-family dwelling unit is served through one master water meter, the water rate determined by that master meter shall be the larger of the following: 
(1)  The minimum charge for each dwelling unit based upon the meter size that would be required to serve that unit, multiplied by the total number of units; or 
(2)  A rate charged for each dwelling unit based upon the average individual unit consumption, multiplied by the total number of dwelling units. 
(Code 1981, § 38-81.1) 
Sec. 114-138. - Outside city limits. 
(a)  The charges for city water supplied to customers outside the corporate limits of the city shall be provided for by special contract, or the monthly rates for water furnished shall be as follows: 
(1)  Twice inside-city rates; 
(2)  Where more than one property or dwelling unit is served through one master meter, the utility bill calculated from that master meter shall be determined based on the average individual property or dwelling unit consumption, multiplied by the total number of served properties or dwelling units. 
(b)  An annual charge shall be applied for all public fire hydrants, private or corporate fire connections, or private or corporation fire hydrants located outside of the city limits, which receive water directly or indirectly from the city's water distribution system. The annual charge shall be $200.00 per hydrant or fire connection, and shall be billed on or about January 1 of each year, and shall be paid in advance. 
(Code 1981, § 38-82) 
Charter reference- Authority of city to supply water outside city limits, § 4-3. 
Sec. 114-139. - Where not otherwise provided. 
(a)  In any case not provided for in this article, including the filling of swimming pools and hauling water, the water rates shall be as fixed by the city council. 
(b)  The charge for city water supplied to customers through the use of a public hydrant shall be $50.00 for each use of the public hydrant, plus the cost of the water furnished, as provided in this article. 
(Code 1981, § 38-83) 
Sec. 114-140. - Charge for turning water off and on at water service customer's request. 
(a)  The utility billing office may terminate and reinitiate water service provided pursuant to an active water service account at the request of the water service customer or customers holding the account. A fee of $15.00 shall be charged for this service, which fee shall be added to the next regular water bill. The water service customer shall be responsible for informing all those affected by the termination or reinitiation of water service of such termination or reinitiation. 
(b)  The utility billing office shall not charge for terminating water service in connection with closure of a water service account at the request of the account customer, provided the account is in good standing at the time of the request. 
(Code 1981, § 38-84; Ord. No. 04-37, 5-18-2004; Ord. No. 08-107, 12-9-2008) 
Sec. 114-141. - Removal of meter for unauthorized use of stopcock; charge for restoration of service. 
(a)  Only authorized employees of the water department shall use the stopcock at the meter. If water is turned on at such stopcock without the consent of the water department, the meter shall be removed and water service shall not be restored until a service charge of $75.00 and all amounts due for water service and fees have been paid, and the applicant seeking restoration of the water service has complied with all the applicable requirements of section 114-144 of this article. 
(b)  Except for good cause shown, the utility billing office shall not approve any applications for water service requested for the property at which the unauthorized usage occurred until the fees and charges assessed pursuant to subsection (a) of this section have been paid. For the purposes of this subsection, good cause may include evidence that the applicant for service is not responsible for unauthorized water usage. 
(Code 1981, § 38-85; Ord. No. 08-107, § 1, 12-9-2008) 
Sec. 114-142. - Personal liability of user. 
(a)  The amount of any charge pursuant to this article, for water usage made in accordance with the requirements of this article, shall constitute a personal liability of the person using the water and, in addition to other remedies, the city may enforce such personal liability by appropriate proceedings. 
(b)  The amount of any fees or charges assessed (i) pursuant to section 114-141 of this article or (ii) pursuant to any other provision of this article for unauthorized water service, shall constitute a personal liability of the owner of the property that received the unauthorized water service, except that no lien securing such liability shall attach to any residential real estate at which the unauthorized usage occurred unless (i) the user of the water services is the owner of the residential real estate, or (ii) the owner of the residential real estate negotiated or executed the agreement by which such water services were to be provided to that residential real estate. 
(Code 1981, § 38-86; Ord. No. 08-107, § 1, 12-9-2008) 
Sec. 114-143. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 08-107, § 2, adopted Dec. 9, 2008, repealed § 114-143, which pertained to responsibility of owner in certain cases and derived from § 38-87 of the 1981 Code. 
Sec. 114-144. - Water service accounts; application and deposit by tenant or owner of property; cancellation. 
    Water service accounts. Water service accounts shall be established and cancelled pursuant to the following provisions: 
(a)  Application for water service account. Applications for water service accounts shall be made as follows: 
1.  Single-family property served by one meter. The tenant or owner of any single-family property for which water service is desired shall (i) complete an application in such form as the utility billing office may require, (ii) pay the application fee specified in subsection (a) of section 114-136, (iii) pay any deposit specified in subsection (b) of this section, and satisfy any such other conditions as the utility billing office may establish. 
2.  Multifamily property served by one meter. The owner or his duly authorized agent, of any property served by one meter but occupied by more than one household, shall be the sole eligible applicant for water service to such property and shall be responsible for the actions identified in (i) through (iv) of subsection (a)1. 
3.  Property subject to management agreements. An applicant for service at a property that is being administered through a management agreement shall provide a copy of the management agreement and such other evidence of his authority to contract for water service as the utility billing office may require. 
4.  Property proposed for sublease. An applicant who seeks to sublet property shall provide evidence of the validity of the sublease, including agreement to the sublease by the lessee, approval of the sublease by the lessor, and such other evidence of validity as the utility billing office may require. 
(b)  Deposits. Applicants shall pay the applicable deposits established by this section in cash to the collector of city taxes. 
1.  The minimum deposit to be made shall be as follows, per unit: 
Meter Size Fee 5/8 -inch meter $75.00 3/4-inch meter 75.00 1-inch meter 75.00 11/2-inch meter 105.00 2-inch meter 205.00 3-inch meter 380.00 4-inch meter 955.00 6-inch meter 1,910.00 Hydrant meter 1,800.00  
2.  The utility billing office may increase the amount of a deposit based upon an applicant's credit history or prior service history with the city, but only upon notification to the applicant, and in no event shall the deposit amount increase by more than 50 percent. 
3.  Deposits may, upon application, be transferred from one property to another, provided all bills for water service to the date of transfer have first been paid. 
4.  Any person who has made a deposit under this section may apply to the utility billing office for refund thereof. The utility billing office shall ask the director of finance to make a check refund, if all water charges to the date of final billing and cut-off or transfer have been paid. 
5.  Any person who has made a deposit under this section may, upon his request to the utility billing office, receive a refund in the amount of that deposit, after such time that ten consecutive payments for utility services have been made on or before the respective due dates. Any person meeting this requirement on any immediate past account shall be exempt from the payment of a deposit. 
(c)  Cancellation of water service account. 
1.  A water service customer may cancel his account by requesting account closure from the utility billing office in such form as that office may require. If there is more than one water service customer included on a water service account, cancellation shall not be effective unless requested by all customers on the account, and all customers shall remain responsible for paying any charges until cancellation is effected. 
2.  The utility billing office may require evidence that the water service customer is no longer responsible for the property. Failure to submit any such evidence requested by the utility billing office may result in the account remaining open and the continued accrual of water service charges. 
3.  The water service customer shall remain responsible for all such charges until such time as the account is closed in accordance with utility billing office policy. 
4.  Upon any cancellation of service and closing of an account, the water service customer who contracted for water service at the property shall be responsible for informing the owner of the property of the cancellation and closing. 
(d)  Notice. Any notice of action by the utility billing office that is required by this article shall be deemed satisfied where the utility billing office provides such notice to the customer or customers holding the affected water service account. 
(Code 1981, § 38-88; Ord. No. 08-107, § 1, 12-9-2008; Ord. No. 17-30, 7-11-2017) 
Sec. 114-145. - Frequency of meter reading. 
    All water meters shall be read bimonthly; provided, however, that where water bills average $200.00 per month or greater, the meter may be read monthly at the owner's request. 
(Code 1981, § 38-89; Ord. No. 08-107, § 1, 12-9-2008) 
Sec. 114-146. - Charges when meter is out of order; meter testing charges. 
(a)  If any meter is out of order or fails to register accurately, the water service customer served by such a meter shall be charged at the average rate of consumption for similar billing periods as shown by the meter, when in order. 
(b)  If any water service customer is not satisfied with the meter reading and shall desire that the meter be tested, the meter shall be tested upon the utility billing office's receipt of a request for such testing. 
(1)  If the water meter is found to register more water than the amount passing through it, no charge shall be made for testing, the meter shall be replaced, and an adjustment shall be made in accordance with subsection (a) of this section. 
(2)  If the meter registers the correct amount or less water than the amount passing through it, the actual cost of testing the meter shall be charged to the water service customer who requested the testing. 
(c)  The charge for meter testing shall be determined and established from time to time by the director of public works. The charge shall be based upon the average cost of testing meters of different sizes. 
(Code 1981, § 38-90; Ord. No. 08-107, § 1, 12-9-2008) 
Sec. 114-147. - Computation; billing procedure. 
(a)  Bills for water supplied by the city shall be computed on a monthly rate, as provided in this article, and shall be billed bimonthly, unless billed monthly, quarterly, or semiannually, as specified by the director of public utilities and the director of finance. 
(b)  Statements showing the aggregate amount due for water used, the utility service tax imposed by chapter 106, article IX of this Code and the sewer service charge provided for in article III of this chapter shall be made out by the clerk of the water department and mailed to the address of the premises being served. If the owner of such premises shall request the water department to do so, such statement shall be retained in the office of the collector of city taxes or mailed to such address as the owner may designate. 
(c)  The clerk of the water department shall certify to the director of finance the total amount due, as provided in subsection (b) of this section, for each month, and the collector of city taxes shall become accountable for such amount. 
(d)  All water passing through any meter shall be charged to the address of the premises served and the bill therefor made out to such premises; provided, however, that in making such charges and bills therefor, the name of the owner of the property may be used to the extent the name of the owner is disclosed by the records of the water department. 
(e)  If any customer experiences an underground leak or a leak under the premises resulting in the loss of metered water, an adjustment shall be made upon proof that the leak has been repaired. The water charges will be assessed on the basis of the average consumption of the customer for similar billing periods, plus an additional charge of $1.00 above the Appomattox River Water Authority cost for each 1,000 cubic feet of water metered in excess of the average consumption. 
(Code 1981, § 38-91; Ord. No. 17-30, 7-11-2017) 
Sec. 114-148. - When and where payable. 
    Water bills for all premises shall be paid within 20 days of the billing, or by the indicated date for payment of the bill. Such bill shall be paid at the office of the collector of city taxes or at local banks authorized by the collector of city taxes to receive such payments. 
(Code 1981, § 38-92; Ord. No. 17-30, 7-11-2017) 
Sec. 114-149. - Lien for water charges. 
    Until such are paid, all water charges imposed or incurred for water, or the connection to or use of the water system, as established by this article, shall be a lien on the real estate so served. Where residential rental real estate is involved, no lien shall attach (i) unless the user of the water is also the owner of the real estate, or (ii) unless the owner of the real estate negotiated or executed the agreement by which such water services were provided to the property. 
(Ord. No. 99-92, § 38-92.1, 6-15-1999) 
Sec. 114-150. - When water bills are to be paid; list of delinquent premises; failure to pay penalty and interest. 
(a)  On the day following the due date for water bills, or as soon thereafter as practicable, the utility billing office shall prepare a list of such properties as are delinquent, and a penalty of ten percent, or $1.00, whichever is greater, shall be added to the bill, and the new bill reflecting this amount shall be sent as a delinquent notice to the water service customer. 
(b)  If the collector of city taxes has not received payment within ten days after a delinquent notice is sent, the water shall be cut off and an additional $50.00 shall be assessed against the water service customer. Any penalties or interest assessed for cutting off the meter or pulling the meter must be paid in addition to the delinquent payments prior to turn-on of service. 
(c)  If the fees and charges established by subsection (a) of this section are not paid within 30 days after notice of such charges, an additional 12 percent annual interest rate shall be assessed against such charges, and shall be paid by the water service customer in addition to such charges. 
(Code 1981, § 38-93; Ord. No. 04-37, 5-18-2004; Ord. No. 08-107, § 1, 12-9-2008; Ord. No. 17-30, 7-11-2017) 
Sec. 114-151. - Charging off of uncollected bills. 
    On or before September 1 of each year, the collector of city taxes shall submit to the city manager a list of uncollected bills rendered pursuant to this article, together with penalties thereon, which have become delinquent during any fiscal period ended five years or more prior to June 30 of the fiscal period preceding the fiscal period in which such list is submitted to the city manager. Upon the approval by the city manager of such list of uncollected bills and the filing of the list in the office of the director of finance, such bills shall be charged off on the books of the collector of city taxes and he shall cease to be accountable for the uncollected bills, with the exception of such bills as may be thereafter paid. Nothing contained in this section shall be construed as affecting the right of the city to collect any bill shown on such list or to pursue any remedy that it may have for the enforcement of the collection of such bill. 
(Code 1981, § 38-94; Ord. No. 17-30, 7-11-2017) 
DIVISION 5. - CROSS-CONNECTION AND BACKFLOW PREVENTION[7] 
Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
State Law reference- Commonwealth of Virginia Waterworks Regulations, Art. 3.00. 

Subdivision I. - In General 

Sec. 114-152. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this division, the words and phrases set out in this section shall have the following meanings: 
    Authorized agent: Authorized person set forth by the city council, i.e. director of public works, or his appointed representative. 
    Backflow: The flow of water or other liquids, mixtures, or substances into the distributing pipes of a potable supply of water from any source other than its intended source. 
    Backsiphonage: A reversal in the direction of water from the distribution supply. 
    Contamination: Any objectionable or hazardous physical, chemical, biological, or radiological substance or matter in water. 
    Cross-connection: Any physical connection between a potable water supply and any waste pipe, soil pipe, sewer drain, or any unapproved source or system. "Cross-connection" includes any potable water supply outlet which is submerged or can be submerged in waste water and any other source of contamination. 
    Director: Director of Public Works (or Assistant Director of {Public Works-Utility Lines Division) for the City of Petersburg, Virginia. 
    Health hazard: Any conditions, devices, or practices in the water supply system and its operation which create, or in the judgment of the director, may create a danger to the health and well being of the water consumer. 
    Plumbing fixture: Installed receptacles, devices, or appliances supplied with water or that receive or discharge liquids or liquid-borne wastes. 
    Plumbing system: The water supply and distribution pipes, plumbing fixtures and traps; soil, waste and vent pipes; building drains and building sewers, including their respective connections, devices, and appurtenances within the property lines of the premises; and water treating or water-using equipment. 
    Pollution: The presence of any foreign substance (organic, inorganic, radiological or biological) in the water that tends to degrade its quality so as to constitute a hazard or impair the usefulness of the water. 
    Protective devices: Equipment or devices which are directly connected to the water supply system providing protection from backflow and backsiphonage conditions. 
    PSIG: Pounds per square inch gage - readings of pressure greater or less than local atmospheric pressure. 
    Reduced pressure zone backflow preventer: Principal backflow preventer providing the highest level of protection against backflow on a direct connection to the potable water supply. Water flows through two independent check valves in the valve body with an intermediate zone between the check valves having an opening to atmosphere that is normally held closed until a backflow condition occurs. 
    Water-Potable: Water free from impurities in amounts sufficient to cause disease or harmful physiological effects. Its bacteriological and chemical quality shall conform to the requirements of the Virginia Waterworks Regulations of the state department of health, office of drinking water, and the requirements of the city's department of utilities. 
    Water-Nonpotable: Water that is not safe for human consumption or that is of questionable potability. 
    Water system: All structures, appurtenances and equipment owned and operated by the city and used to collect, store, transport, purify, and treat water for drinking or domestic use and the distribution of water to the public. 
    Waterworks: A system that serves piped water for drinking or domestic use to (i) the public, (ii) at least 15 connections, or (iii) an average of 25 individuals for at least 60 days out of the year. The term "waterworks" shall include all structures, equipment, and appurtenances used in the storage, collection, purification, treatment and distribution of pure water except the piping and fixtures inside the building where such water is delivered (see Code of Virginia, art. 2, ch. 1 of tit. 32.1, as amended). 
(Ord. No. 05-59, 7-5-2005) 
Sec. 114-153. - Authority-Description of program. 
    The cross-connection and backflow prevention program in the City of Petersburg is required by the Commonwealth of Virginia Waterworks Regulations, Article 3.00, entitled "Cross-Connection and Backflow Prevention Control in Waterworks." Section 12VACS-590-580 states: "The purpose of this article of the regulations is to require as a condition for the issuance and continued use of the operation permit for the waterworks that each owner of a waterworks establish and enforce a program of cross-connection control and backflow prevention for each waterworks. The cross connection control and backflow prevention program shall be approved by the commissioner prior to issuance of the operation permit." 
(Ord. No. 05-59, 7-5-2005) 
Sec. 114-154. - Personnel-Organization. 
(a)  The basic responsibility for the city's cross-connection and backflow prevention program is with the City of Petersburg, Department of Public Works; Utility Lines Division. 
(b)  The one individual assigned to this activity shall be a full-time member of the utility lines division, or a contract individual with backflow and cross-connection experience. This position will be of an inspector/technician level with responsibilities to implement and promote the cross-connection control program. This individual will report to the director through the class V operator in responsible charge of the water system. The appointed individual shall provide overall coordination of the program and shall be responsible for and perform the inspection program and surveillance and maintenance of program records. This individual manages and promotes the program and performs inspections. He must be thoroughly trained in the detection and effects of cross-connection and in the use and function of backflow prevention devices. 
(c)  All new connections to the city's water system will be inspected for cross-connections by a city plumbing inspector prior to service. 
(d)  Review of utility plans for evaluation and approval of backflow prevention devices shall be performed in conjunction with the City of Petersburg Engineering Department. Requirements for protective devices will be made based upon the degree of hazard and the type of facility. 
(Ord. No. 05-59, 7-5-2005) 
Sec. 114-155. - Water system-Cross-connections. 
(a)  The city's potable water system shall be designed, installed, and maintained in such a manner as to prevent contamination from nonpotable liquids, solids, or gases from being introduced into the potable water supply through cross-connections or any other piping connections to the system. 
(b)  Cross-connections between the city's potable water system and other systems or equipment containing water or other substances of unknown or questionable safety are prohibited except when and where, as approved by the director, suitable protective devices such as the reduced pressure zone backflow preventer or equal are installed, tested, and maintained to ensure proper operation on a continuing basis. 
(c)  Backflow and backsiphonage. Every building, premises or structure in the city shall be constructed, equipped and maintained in such a manner as to prevent the possibility of pollution of the city's water supply by cross-connection or backflow of liquids. 
(d)  The city's potable water system shall be protected against backflow and backsiphonage by installing and maintaining as near the point of connection as practical a suitable backflow prevention device at any premises deemed to have a potential backflow issue. 
(Ord. No. 05-59, 7-5-2005) 
Sec. 114-156. - Responsibility of director. 
(a)  The director, or his designated agent, shall inspect the plumbing in every building or premises in the city that is determined to pose a potential hazard to the city's water supply, unless the supply is protected near the source with an appropriate backflow prevention device. 
(b)  The director, or his designated agent, shall have the right of entry into any building, during reasonable hours, for the purpose of making inspections of the plumbing systems installed in such building or premises for cross-connection or backflow problems caused by improper installation, repair or maintenance, faulty equipment, or other causes. Upon request, the owner or occupants of property served by the city water system shall furnish to the inspection agency pertinent information regarding the piping system on such property. 
(c)  The director's responsibility shall be limited to the protection of the public water supply. If, in his judgment, the supply is adequately protected at or near the point of connection, inspections of the plumbing system on the property are not required. Cross-connections or backflows on the owners' premises are the sole responsibility of the owner. In the event of backflow into the waterworks, the purveyor shall promptly take or cause correction to confine and eliminate the pollution or contamination. The purveyor shall immediately notify the field office of the Commonwealth of Virginia, Department of Health, Office of Drinking Water when backflow condition occurs. 
(Ord. No. 05-59, 7-5-2005) 
Sec. 114-157. - Compliance with applicable rules and regulations. 
    Any cross-connection or backflow prevention device or system shall be designed, installed and maintained in such a manner as to be in compliance with the Cross-Connection Control Manual, U. S. Environmental Protection Agency, Office of Water Programs, Water Supply Division; the BOCA Basic Plumbing Code; the Uniform State Building Code; Article 3.00 of the Virginia Waterworks Regulations entitled "Cross-Connection and Backflow Prevention Control in Waterworks"; and the City of Petersburg Cross-Connection and Backflow Prevention Control Program ordinance, copies of which are on file in the department of public utilities. 
(Ord. No. 05-59, 7-5-2005) 
Sec. 114-158. - Violations and penalty. 
(a)  The director shall notify the owner, or authorized agent of the owner, of the building or premises in which thee is found a violation of this article. The director shall set a reasonable time for the owner to have the violation removed or corrected. Upon failure of the owner to have the defect corrected by the end of the specified time interval, the director may, if in his judgment an imminent health hazard exists, cause the water service to the building or premises to be terminated or deny service to such premises. 
(b)  If it is found that the backflow prevention device has been removed or bypassed, if a cross-connection exists, or if the pressure in the waterworks drops to a minimum of ten PSIG, the Director shall take positive action to ensure that the waterworks is adequately protected at all times. 
(c)  The owner, or authorized agent of the owner, responsible for the maintenance of the plumbing systems in the building who knowingly permits a violation to remain uncorrected after the expiration of time set by the director shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be subject to a fine of not more than $1,000.00 for each violation. Each day of failure to comply with the requirements of this division 5 shall constitute a separate violation. 
(Ord. No. 05-59, 7-5-2005) 
Sec. 114-159. - Reviewing of utility plans. 
(a)  Any backflow prevention device required by the utilities department shall be installed at a location and in a manner approved by the department of utilities. 
(b)  Such devices shall be of an approved type and shall have been tested by a recognized testing laboratory or evaluation agency and be of satisfactory materials and be subject to approval by the department of utilities. 
(c)  Plans for fire service connections and extension lawn or irrigation systems served by the waterworks and other facilities requiring approved backflow prevention devices shall be submitted to the department of utilities prior to construction. The department of utilities shall review the plans and advise whether they are approved or disapproved. If disapproved, the department shall advise alternatives which will be approved. The revised plans shall be re-submitted for additional review. Only after final approval by the department of utilities will construction be permitted. 
(d)  Facilities which are required to have service connection approved backflow prevention device protection are listed under Section 12VAC5-590-610 of the Commonwealth of Virginia, Waterworks Regulations dated December 1, 2003, however, this list shall not be construed as a complete list. 
(Ord. No. 05-59, 7-5-2005) 
Sec. 114-160. - Inspections. 
(a)  Inspections will be scheduled in priority according to the known degree of hazard associated with the customer being served. Services designated as severe in degree of hazard must be surveyed first. Others should come in order. 
(b)  Inspections and operational tests of backflow prevention devices which are required and installed shall be made annually. Devices should be repaired, overhauled, or replaced as required by the department of utilities. Overhaul intervals should be by the manufacturer's recommendation or five years, whichever comes first. Operational tests must be performed by certified personnel after any repairs or replacements. 
(c)  Testing procedures shall be in accordance with manufacturer's instructions and performed by certified personnel. 
(d)  New connections or reconnections to the system shall be surveyed for potential cross-connections prior to service in accordance with the Uniform Statewide Building Code. 
(Ord. No. 05-59, 7-5-2005) 
Sec. 114-161. - Inspection records. 
(a)  Inspection records shall be kept for at least ten years. They will be made available when requested by the field office, department of health, office of drinking water. The following minimum information is required: 
(1)  Date, place, location, investigator, building representative, title, phone number, water source, hazards found, corrections made, corrections to be made, and recommendations made. 
(b)  Test records and data for backflow prevention devices shall be kept on file for a period of ten years and made available to the field office of the department of health, office of drinking water, on demand. Minimum information to be included in test data is as follows: 
(1)  Name of place, service address, mailing address, contact, title, phone number, kind of device, serial number, date installed, location, and location-in-service sketch. 
(Ord. No. 05-59, 7-5-2005) 
Sec. 114-162. - References. 
(a)  Cross-Connections and Backflow Prevention, Second Edition, by Gustave T. Angele, Sr. American Water Works Association, 6666 West Quincy Avenue, Denver, Colorado 80235. 
(b)  Cross-Connection Control Manual, Water Supply Division, Office of Water Programs, U. S. Environmental Protection Agency, Superintendent of Documents, U. S. Government Printing Office, Washington, D.C. 20402. 
(c)  Backflow Prevention and Cross-Connection Control, AWWA M14, American Water Works Association, 6666 West Quincy Avenue, Denver, Colorado 80235. 
(d)  AWWA Standard for Backflow Prevention Devices - Reduced Pressure Principle and Double Check Valves Types, AWWA C506-69, American Water Works Association, 6666 West Quincy Avenue, Denver, Colorado 80235. 
(Ord. No. 05-59, 7-5-2005) 
Secs. 114-163-114-170. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SEWAGE DISPOSAL[8] 
Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
State Law reference- Sewage disposal systems generally, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2122 et seq.; septic tanks and sewage disposal when sewers not available, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2157; health regulations pertaining to sewage disposal, Code of Virginia, § 32.1-163 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 114-171. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this article, the following words and phrases shall have the meaning ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Approval authority means the Commonwealth of Virginia or its authorized agent or representative. 
    Authority means the South Central Wastewater Authority, a corporation existing under and by virtue of the laws of the Commonwealth of Virginia, or other applicable wastewater authority serving the City of Petersburg. 
    BOD (biochemical oxygen demand) means the quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedure in five days at 20 degrees Celsius, expressed in milligrams per liter (mg/l). The laboratory determination shall be made in accordance with the procedures set forth in the United States Environmental Protection Agency's General Pretreatment Regulations 40 CFR 136. 
    Building drain means all that portion of piping of a building sewer drainage system which receives the discharge from waste or other drainage pipes beginning five feet outside the building wall and conveys it to the lot property line where the building sewer lateral begins. 
    Building sewer lateral means the extension from the building drain to the public sewer or other place of disposal. 
    Categorical pretreatment standards or categorical standard means any regulation containing pollutant discharge limits promulgated by the United States Environmental Protection Agency in accordance with Section 307(b) and (c) of the Clean Water Act (33 USC 1317) which apply to a specific category of industrial users and which appear in the United States Environmental Protection Agency's General Pretreatment Regulations 40 CFR Chapter I, Subchapter N, Parts 405-471. 
    City means the City of Petersburg, Virginia, or any authorized person acting on its behalf. 
    COD (chemical oxygen demand) means the measure, expressed in mg/l, of the oxygen consuming capacity of inorganic and organic matter present in water or wastewater, expressing the amount of oxygen consumed from a chemical oxidant in a specific test, but not differentiating between stable and unstable organic matter and thus not necessarily correlating with biochemical oxygen demand. 
    COD (soluble) means the COD of the filtrate from wastewater that is filtered through a gooch crucible as required by the suspended solids test in the United States Environmental Protection Agency's General Pretreatment Regulations 40 CFR 136. 
    COD-BOD ratio means the ratio of the value of COD to BOD as these values are defined in this section. 
    Control authority means the city council or its duly authorized agent or representative. 
    Control manhole means a manhole giving access to a building sewer lateral at some point before the building sewer discharge mixes with other discharges in the public sewer. 
    Control point means the point of access to a course of discharge before the discharge mixes with other discharges in the public sewer. 
    Department means the city's department of public works. 
    Director means the director of the department of public works of the city, or his authorized deputy, agent or representative. 
    Domestic sewage means wastewater discharged into the sanitary sewers, in which the average daily concentration of total suspended solids is not more than 200 and BOD is not more than 300 mg/l, total phosphorus is not more than 15 mg/l, total Kjeldahl nitrogen is not more than 18 mg/l; and total flow is not more than 30,000 gallons per day. 
    Domestic user means any residential user which discharges domestic pollutants to the authority's wastewater treatment facility. 
    Garbage means solid wastes and residue from the preparation, cooking and dispensing of food, and from the handling, storage and sale of food products and produce. 
    Incompatible waste means a waste which is not susceptible to adequate treatment by the wastewater treatment plant as determined by the director of public works. 
    Indirect discharge or discharge means to deposit, conduct, drain, emit, throw, run, allow to seep, or otherwise to release or dispose, or to allow, permit or suffer any of these acts or omissions, resulting in the introduction of pollutants into the POTW from any nondomestic source regulated under section 307(b), (c), or (d) of the Clean Water Act. 
    Industrial user means any source regulated under Section 307(b), (c), or (d) of the Clean Water Act which discharges nondomestic pollutants to the wastewater treatment facility, or any industrial, commercial, or other nonresidential discharger to the city's sanitary sewer system. 
    Industrial waste means all waterborne solids, liquids or gaseous wastes resulting from any industrial manufacturing, trade, business or food processing operation or from the development of any natural resource, or any mixture of these with water or domestic wastes. 
    Infiltration means water entering a sewer system, including service connections from the ground, through such means as, but not limited to, defective pipes, pipe joints, connections or manhole walls. Infiltration does not include, and is distinct from, inflow. 
    Inflow means water discharged into a sewer system, including service connections from such sources as, but not limited to, roof leaders, cellar, yard and area drains, foundation drains, cooling water discharges, drains from springs and swampy areas, manhole covers, cross connections from storm sewers and combined sewers, catchbasins, stormwaters, surface runoff, street washwaters, or drainage. Inflow does not include, and is distinct from, infiltration. 
    Interference means a discharge which, alone or in conjunction with a discharge or discharges from other sources: (i) inhibits or disrupts the POTW, its treatment processes or operation or its sludge processes, use or disposal; and (ii) thereby either (a) precipitates a violation of any requirement of the POTW's VPDES permit or an increase in magnitude or duration of a violation, or (b) prevents the use or disposal of sewage sludge in a manner compliant with the following statutory provisions and regulations or permits issued thereunder: Section 405 of the Clean Water Act; the Solid Waste Disposal Act (SWDA), including title II, more commonly referred to as the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA), and including State regulations contained in any State sludge management plan prepared pursuant to subtitle D of the SWDA; the Clean Air Act; the Toxic Substances Control Act; and the Marine Protection, Research and Sanctuaries Act; or any more stringent applicable State or local regulations. 
    Milligrams per liter (mg/l) means the same as parts per million, and is a weight-to-volume ratio; the milligram-per-liter value multiplied by the factor of 8.34 shall be equivalent to pounds per million gallons of water. 
    Natural outlet means any outlet into a watercourse, ditch, lake, or other body of surface water or groundwater. 
    New source means: 
(1)  Any building, structure, facility or installation from which there is or may be a discharge of pollutants, the construction of which commenced after the publication of proposed pretreatment standards under Section 307(c) of the Clean Water Act which will be applicable to such source if such standards are thereafter promulgated in accordance with that section, provided that: 
a.  The building, structure, facility or installation is constructed at a site at which no other source is located; 
b.  The building, structure, facility or installation totally replaces the process or production equipment that causes the discharge of pollutants at an existing source; or 
c.  The production or wastewater generating processes of the building, structure, facility or installation are substantially independent of an existing source at the same site. In determining whether these are substantially independent, factors such as the extent to which the new facility is integrated with the existing plant, and the extent to which the new facility is engaged in the same general type of activity as the existing source should be considered. 
(2)  Construction on a site at which an existing source is located results in a modification rather than a new source if the construction does not create a new building, structure, facility or installation meeting the criteria of subsection (1) b. or c. of this definition but otherwise alters, replaces or adds to existing process or production equipment. 
(3)  Construction of a new source as defined under this subdivision has commenced if the owner or operator has: 
a.  Begun or caused to begin as part of a continuous on-site construction program: 
1.  Any placement, assembly or installation of facilities or equipment; or 
2.  Significant site preparation work including clearing, excavation, or removal of existing buildings, structures or facilities, which is necessary for the placement, assembly, or installation of new source facilities or equipment; or 
b.  Entered into a binding contractual obligation for the purchase of facilities or equipment which are intended to be used in its operation within a reasonable time. Options to purchase or contracts which can be terminated or modified without substantial loss, and contracts for feasibility, engineering, and design studies do not constitute a contractual obligation under this subsection. 
    Overload means the imposition of organic or hydraulic loading on a treatment facility in excess of its engineered design capacity. 
    Parts per million means a weight-to-weight ratio; the parts-per-million value multiplied by the factor of 8.34 shall be equivalent to pounds per million gallons of water. 
    Pass through means any discharge that exits the wastewater treatment facility into state water in quantities or concentrations which alone or in conjunction with a discharge or discharges from other sources will cause a violation of the wastewater facility's VPDES permit. 
    Person means any individual, partnership, co-partnership, firm, company, corporation, joint stock company, association, trust, estate, governmental entity, or any other legal entity; or their legal representatives, agents or assigns. This definition includes all federal, state, and local governmental entities. 
    pH means the logarithm (base 10) of the reciprocal of the hydrogen ion concentration of a solution. It shall be determined by one of the procedures outlined in the United States Environmental Protection Agency's General Pretreatment Regulations 40 CFR 136. 
    Phosphorus (total) means the sum of the various types of phosphate, expressed as elemental phosphorus, found in wastewater. The various forms include orthophosphate, condensed phosphate (pyro-, meta-, and poly-phosphate) and organically bound phosphates. The concentration of total phosphate is determined by the test procedures in the United States Environmental Protection Agency's General Pretreatment Regulations 40 CFR 136. 
    Pollutant means dredged spoil, solid waste, incinerator residue, filter backwash, sewage, garbage, sewage sludge, munitions, medical wastes, chemical wastes, biological materials, radioactive materials, heat, wrecked or discarded equipment, rock, sand, cellar dirt, municipal, agricultural and industrial wastes, and certain characteristics of wastewater such as pH, temperature, TSS, turbidity, color, BOD, COD, toxicity, or odor. 
    POTW (publicly owned treatment works) means a system of conveyances and treatment for sewage and industrial waste. Pretreatment means the reduction of the amount of pollutants, the elimination of pollutants, or the alteration of the nature of pollutant properties in wastewater prior to, or in lieu of, introducing such pollutants into the POTW. This reduction or alteration can be obtained by physical, chemical, or biological processes; by process changes; or by other means, except by diluting the concentration of the pollutants unless allowed by an applicable pretreatment standard. 
    Pretreatment coordinator means the person holding responsibility for supervising the pretreatment requirements under division 4.1 of this article, as designated by (i) the South Central Wastewater Authority or (ii) other applicable wastewater authority serving the City of Petersburg. 
    Pretreatment regulation means the rules and regulations implementing the industrial pretreatment program, promulgated pursuant to section 114-286 of division 4.1 of this article. 
    Pretreatment requirements means any substantive or procedural requirement related to pretreatment imposed on a user, other than a pretreatment standard. 
    Public sewer means either a sanitary or storm sewer in which all owners of abutting properties shall have equal rights, and is controlled by public authority. 
    Sanitary sewer means a sewer which carries sewage, and to which stormwaters, surface waters and groundwaters are not intentionally admitted. 
    Septic tank waste means any sewage or other wastes from holding tanks such as vessels, chemical toilets, campers, trailers, and septic tanks. 
    Sewage means human excrement and gray water, including water from household showers and dishwashing operations. 
    Sewerage means the system of sewers and appurtenances for the collection, transportation, pumping and treatment of sewage and industrial wastes. 
    Significant noncompliance means the status of an industrial user if its violations of (i) this article, (ii) any provision of regulations promulgated pursuant to section 114-286 of division 4.1 of this article, (iii) a wastewater discharge permit or order issued pursuant to those regulations, or (iv) any other pretreatment standard or requirement meet one or more of the following criteria: 
(1)  Chronic violations of permitted wastewater discharge limits, defined as those in which 66 percent or more of all of the measurements taken during a six-month period exceed (by all magnitude) the daily maximum limit or the average limit for the same pollutant parameter; 
(2)  Technical review criteria (TRC) violations, defined as those in which 33 percent or more of all of the measurements for each pollutant parameter taken during a six-month period equal or exceed the product of the daily average maximum limit or the average limit multiplied by the applicable TRC (TRC = 1.4 for BOD, total suspended solids (TSS), fats, oil, and grease, and 1.2 for all other pollutants except pH); 
(3)  Any other violation of a daily maximum or longer-term average pretreatment effluent limit that the pretreatment coordinator determines has caused, alone or in combination with other discharges, interference, pass through, or endangerment of health of the wastewater treatment facility personnel or the general public; 
(4)  Any discharge of a pollutant that has caused imminent or substantial endangerment to human health, welfare, or the environment or has resulted in the director's exercise of his authority pursuant to section 114-289 of this chapter to halt or prevent such a discharge; 
(5)  Failure to meet, within 90 days after the scheduled date, a compliance schedule milestone contained in a wastewater control mechanism or enforcement order, for starting construction, completing construction, or attaining final compliance; 
(6)  Failure to provide, within 30 days after the due date, required reports such as baseline monitoring reports, 90-day compliance reports, and reports on compliance with compliance schedules; 
(7)  Failure to accurately report noncompliance; or 
(8)  Any other violation or group of violations which the pretreatment coordinator determines will adversely affect the operation or implementation of the local pretreatment program. 
    Slug load or slug discharge means any discharge of water, sewage or industrial waste which, in concentration of any given constituent or in quantity of flow, exceeds for any period of duration longer than 15 minutes more than five times the average 24-hour concentration of flows during the normal operation. 
    Standard methods means the examination and analytical procedures set forth in the latest edition at the time of analysis of Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater, as prepared, approved and published jointly by the American Public Health Association, the American Water Works Association and the Water Environment Federation, or as defined in the United States Environmental Protection Agency's General Pretreatment Regulations 40 CFR 136. 
    Storm sewer or storm drain means a sewer which carries stormwaters and surface waters and unpolluted drainage, but excludes sewage and industrial wastes. 
    Stormwater runoff means the portion of the rainfall that is drained into the storm sewers or natural watercourses. 
    Suspended solids (SS) means solids that either float on the surface of, or are in suspension in, water, sewage or other liquids, and which are removable by laboratory filtering. Quantitative determination of suspended solids shall be made in accordance with procedures set forth in the United States Environmental Protection Agency's General Pretreatment Regulations 40 CFR 136. 
    Total Kjeldahl nitrogen (TKN) means the combined ammonia and organic nitrogen in a given wastewater, as measured by the test procedures in the United States Environmental Protection Agency's General Pretreatment Regulations 40 CFR 136. It does not include nitrite and nitrate nitrogen. 
    Toxic substances means any substance, whether gaseous, liquid or solid, which, when discharged to the sewer system in sufficient quantities, interferes with any sewage treatment process, materially increases the cost of treatment, constitutes a hazard to any beneficial use, including recreation, ascribed to the receiving waters of the effluent from the sewage treatment plant or facility, causes a hazard to any portion of the sewerage system, constitutes a hazard to living organisms, or interferes with sludge disposal. 
    Trade secrets include, but are not limited to, any formula, plan, pattern, process, tool, mechanism, compound, procedure, production data, or compilation of information, which is not patented, which is known only to certain individuals within a commercial concern, who are using it to fabricate or produce a compound, an article of trade or a service having commercial value, and which gives its users an opportunity to obtain a business advantage over competitors who do not know or use it. 
    Trap means a device designated to skim, settle or otherwise remove grease, oil, sand, flammable wastes or other harmful substances from the sanitary sewer system. 
    User or industrial user means a source of indirect discharge. 
    User charge means the charge made to those persons who discharge normal wastewater into the city's sewerage system. This charge shall include a proportionate share of the capital costs of any capital improvements to the system. 
    User surcharge means the charge made, in excess of the user charge, for all wastewater over and above the loading defined as normal wastewater. 
    VPDES means Virginia Pollution Discharge Elimination System. 
    Wastewater means a combination of the water-carried waste from residences, business buildings, institutions and industrial establishments. 
    Wastewater discharge permit means a permit issued by the director, pursuant to the provisions of this article, to permit the discharge of any liquid or matter by an industrial user into the city's wastewater system. The permit, when so issued, shall reflect the applicable effluent standards and the terms and conditions for such discharge. 
    Wastewater facilities means all facilities for collection, pumping, treating and disposing of wastewater and industrial wastes. 
    Wastewater service charge means the charge on all users of the public sewer whose wastes are treated at the wastewater treatment plant, and is the appropriate sum of the user charge and user surcharge. 
    Wastewater treatment plant means any facilities, devices and structures used for receiving, processing and treating wastewater, industrial waste, and sludges from the sanitary sewers. 
    Watercourse means a natural or manmade channel in which a flow of water occurs, either continuously or intermittently. 
(Code 1981, § 27-1; Ord. No. 08-100, § 1, 11-18-2008) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 114-172. - Right of entry to enforce article. 
(a)  The director and other duly authorized employees of the city shall be permitted to enter all properties at reasonable times for the purposes of inspection, observation, measurement, sampling and testing in accordance with the provisions of this article. The director or his representative shall have authority to inquire into any processes, including metallurgical, chemical, oil, refining, ceramic, paper or other industrial processes having a direct bearing on the kind and source of discharge to the sewers or waterways or facilities for waste treatment. 
(b)  While performing the necessary work on private properties referred to in subsection (a) of this section, the director or duly authorized employees of the city shall observe all safety rules applicable to the premises established by the owner or occupant of the premises and such owner or occupant shall be held harmless for injury or death to the city employees; and the city shall indemnify the owner or occupant against loss or damage to his property by city employees and against liability claims and demands for personal injury or property damage asserted against the owner or occupant and growing out of the gauging and sampling operation, except as such may be caused by negligence or failure of the owner or occupant to maintain safe conditions as required in section 114-274. 
(c)  The director and other duly authorized employees of the city shall be permitted to enter private properties through which the city holds easements, for the purpose of, but not limited to, inspection, observation, measurement, sampling, repair and maintenance, of any portion of the sewage works lying within such easement. All entry and subsequent work, if any, on such easement shall be done in full accordance with the terms of the duly established easement pertaining to the private property involved. 
(Code 1981, § 27-10) 
Sec. 114-173. - Hearing board for arbitration of difference on matters concerning interpretation and enforcement of article. 
(a)  A hearing board shall be appointed as needed for arbitration of differences between the director and sewer users on matters concerning interpretation and enforcement of the provisions of this article by the director. The cost of the arbitration will be divided equally between the city and the sewer user. 
(b)  The hearing board referred to in subsection (a) of this section shall be composed of three members chosen as follows: one member selected by the director, one member selected by the sewer user and the remaining member chosen by the two appointees. 
(Code 1981, § 27-11) 
Sec. 114-174. - Violations of article. 
(a)  Notice. If any person is found to be violating any provisions of this article except sections 114-179 and 114-182, the city shall serve persons discharging in violation of this article with written notice, stating the nature of the violation and providing a time limit of 90 days for satisfactory compliance, if no environmental degradation occurs as a result of the violation. The control authority reserves the right to reduce the time required to obtain satisfactory compliance, depending on the amount of environmental degradation occurring as a result of the violation. 
(b)  Penalty. Any person who violates the provisions of this article relating to prohibited discharges shall be guilty of a class 3 misdemeanor for each act of violation and for each day of violation. Additionally, the city reserves the right to terminate the sewer and water connection for any violation of the provisions of this article. 
(c)  Continuing discharges. In addition to proceeding under authority of subsection (a) of this section, the city is entitled to also act under authority of statutes or other ordinances against a person continuing prohibited discharge. 
(d)  Liability of violator to city. Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall become liable to the city for any expense, loss or damage occasioned the city by reason of such violation. In addition to sanctions provided for by this article, the city is entitled to exercise sanctions provided for by the other ordinances of the city for failure to pay the bill for water and sanitary service when due. 
(Code 1981, §§ 27-12-27-14) 
Sec. 114-175. - Director of public utilities. 
    The city manager shall appoint a director of public utilities who shall have charge of the city sewers, pumping stations and wastewater treatment plant. 
(Code 1981, § 27-2) 
Sec. 114-176. - Supervision of sewers generally. 
    The director shall exercise general supervision over the sewers of the city and all matters connected therewith, under the direction of the city manager. 
(Code 1981, § 27-3) 
Sec. 114-177. - Sewer line extensions for commercial and industrial use. 
    Applications for sewer line extensions for commercial and industrial use shall be referred to the city manager and shall be considered by the city council upon the merits of the individual case and determined upon estimated quantities of water to be furnished. 
(Code 1981, § 27-4) 
Sec. 114-178. - Maintenance or replacement of sewer laterals within street rights-of-way. 
    The city shall repair or replace all sanitary sewer laterals within the right-of-way limits of all public streets. If a lateral in need of repair or replacement was installed by the city or as a part of a subdivision, and a clean-out was installed, the entire cost of such replacement or repair shall be borne by the city. If a lateral was installed for a property owner, under an old ordinance, by a private plumbing contractor, the property owner shall pay the fee for a replacement lateral, whereupon the city shall replace or repair the lateral, install a clean-out and become responsible for future maintenance of the lateral. Where records of the city do not show city installation of the lateral, it shall be presumed that the lateral was installed for a property owner by a private plumbing contractor. 
(Code 1981, § 27-5) 
Sec. 114-179. - Unlawful disposal of sewage and other objectionable waste generally. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to place, deposit or permit to be deposited in any unsanitary manner, on public or private property within the city, or in any area under the jurisdiction of the city, any human or animal excrement, garbage or other objectionable waste. A violation of this section shall constitute a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1981, § 27-6) 
Sec. 114-180. - Discharge of sewage to natural outlets. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge to any natural outlet within the city, or in any area under the jurisdiction of the city, any sewage or other polluted waters, except where suitable treatment has been provided in accordance with the provisions of division 4 of this article. 
(Code 1981, § 27-7) 
Sec. 114-181. - Obstructing sewers. 
    No person shall obstruct or cause the obstruction of any sewer, or discharge into any sewer any substance which is liable to obstruct the flow of sewage or which will in any manner impair the efficiency of the sewer. 
(Code 1981, § 27-8) 
Sec. 114-182. - Damaging, tampering with, etc., sewage works property. 
    No unauthorized person shall intentionally break, damage, destroy, uncover, deface or tamper with any structure, appurtenance or equipment which is a part of the sewage works. Any person violating this section shall be guilty of a class 3 misdemeanor. This section shall apply only when the destruction or damage may be remedied or repaired for $200.00 or less. 
(Code 1981, § 27-9) 
Secs. 114-183-114-200. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CONNECTION TO PUBLIC SEWER; BUILDING SEWERS AND DRAINS 

Sec. 114-201. - Mandatory connections. 
(a)  All persons owning property, except vacant lots, along the line of any public sewer, or having right of access to any public sewer, or having right of access to a private sewer connected with a public sewer, shall connect their premises with such sewer within four months after the completion of any sewer. It shall be the duty of the director to give immediate notice of the requirements of this section to all persons not having such connections, and whenever a new sewer is hereafter completed and ready for use, the director shall give notice to all persons owning property along the line of such sewer or having the right of access thereto. This subsection shall apply to all properties along the line of any public sewer facility, for furnishing sewer facilities within 150 feet of the nearest property line to the public sewer main, except when, in the discretion of the city manager or his designated representative, the requirement for connection would cause undue and extreme hardship to the owner. 
(b)  If the owner of any premises fails to make a sewer connection as set forth in this section, after the completion of any sewer, he shall be deemed to be guilty of maintaining a nuisance detrimental to the public health. The city manager may, at his discretion, cause such sewer connection to be made and necessary toilet and water connections constructed, under the direction of the director, at the cost of the owner of such premises, such cost to be a lien upon the land connected with such premises, and which shall be collected in the same manner that city taxes levied upon real estate are collected. Such expenses shall be docketed in the office of the city treasurer in a book kept for that purpose, and indexed in the name of the owner of the property. Before causing such work to be done, the city manager shall cause notice thereof to be served upon the owner of such premises or his agent, ten days in advance. If the work is not begun by the owner or his agent on or before the expiration of such ten days, the city manager may, at his discretion, proceed to have the work done. 
(Code 1981, § 27-26) 
Sec. 114-202. - Procedure for building application. 
    Upon application for a building permit, the building official shall obtain from the director information regarding the availability of public sewer facilities. If such facilities are available, connection will be made in compliance with this article. If public sewer facilities are not available, the provisions of division 5 of this article shall be followed. 
(Code 1981, § 27-27) 
Sec. 114-203. - Connection and building sewer permit. 
(a)  No unauthorized person shall uncover, make any connections with or opening into, use, alter or disturb any public sewer or appurtenance thereof, without first obtaining a written permit to do so from the director. 
(b)  There shall be two classes of building sewer permits: one for residential, and one for commercial or industrial service. In either case, the owner or his agent shall make application to the director on a special form furnished by the city. The permit application shall be supplemented by any plans, supplemental permits, specifications or other information considered pertinent in the judgment of the director. 
(Code 1981, § 27-28) 
Sec. 114-204. - Connection fees. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Laundromat means a facility containing coin-operated laundry machines that are intended for self-service operation by the customer. 
    Nursing home means a facility that provides skilled nursing care and rehabilitation services to people with illnesses, injuries or functional disabilities, either as an independent facility, or as a facility operating within a hospital or retirement community. 
(b)  Fee. Each person who desires to use the city sewage system shall first pay a connection fee for the privilege of connecting to the sewer system as specified in the following table: 
Type of Meter Connection Sewer 

Connection Fee Residential Use SF residential $5,140.00 Multifamily residential (per dwelling unit) 5,140.00 Commercial/Industrial Use 5/8 ? meter 5,140.00 1? meter 10,350.00 1.5? meter 18,100.00 2? meter 33,120.00 3? meter 66,240.00 4? meter 103,500.00 6? meter 207,000.00 8? meter 331,200.00 10? meter 595,332.00 12? meter 957,582.00 Other use Hotels and motels (per sleeping room) 2,570.00 Hospitals (per bed) 6,168.00 Nursing homes (per bed) 4,112.00 Laundromats (per machine) $10,280.00 Connections Made Outside City Limits Fees for connections to structures located outside the geographical limits of the City of Petersburg shall be double the otherwise applicable rate shown in this table.  
(c)  Purpose of connection fee. The purpose of the sewer connection fees prescribed by this section is to finance the capital costs of sewer infrastructure, including sewage pumping and transmission. The fees shall be fair and reasonable, and shall be established based on meter size or other waterworks capacity considerations. 
(d)  Assessment. A sewer connection fee shall be assessed against: 
(1)  A use or structure not connected to the sewer system when such use or structure connects; and 
(2)  A use or structure connected to the sewer system whenever such use or structure is expanded or modified so as to result in an increase in meter size or a change in the type of meter connection. 
No fee shall be assessed for replacement of an existing sewer connection if the use or structure served by the connection is not expanded or modified, except as provided for in section 114-178. 
(e)  Payment of fees. Connection fees assessed pursuant to this section and tap fees assessed pursuant to section 114-205 of this division shall be paid to the collector of city taxes at the time an application for a permit for sewer service connection pursuant to section 114-203 of this division is approved, except that the utility billing office may establish a payment plan for payment of tap fees for residential customers for good cause shown. No application for connection shall be approved until such time as the city has issued a building permit for the structure. The fees assessed under this section shall not be waived. 
(f)  Connection. The city shall connect a use or structure to the sewer system upon (i) payment of the fees pursuant to subsection (e); and (ii) completion of any final inspection by the public utilities division, except that the department director may authorize connection prior to completion of a final inspection for good cause shown. 
(g)  Deposit of monies. All monies collected as connection fees under this section shall be deposited into the city's general account, but shall be recorded in a dedicated account in the public utility enterprise fund. Monies shall be disbursed from that dedicated account solely to pay capital costs associated with infrastructure projects designed to develop sewer facilities that will serve the city, and related debt service on the capital costs of such projects. 
(Code 1981, § 27-29; Ord. No. 06-32, 3-21-2006; Ord. No. 08-93, § 3, 10-28-2008; Ord. No. 17-30, 7-11-2017) 
Sec. 114-205. - Connection to be installed; installation charges. 
    Connections to sewer mains may be installed by the city. The charge for such connections shall be determined and established, from time to time, by the director. The charge shall be based upon the average cost of making such connections. 
(Code 1981, § 27-30) 
Sec. 114-206. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 08-93, § 5, adopted Oct. 28, 2008, repealed § 114-206, which pertained to payment of connection fees and installation charges and derived from § 27-31 of the 1981 Code. 
Sec. 114-207. - General construction and installation standards. 
(a)  The size, slope, alignment and materials of construction of a building sewer lateral, and the methods to be used in excavating, placing the pipe, jointing, testing and backfilling the trench, shall all conform to the requirements of the building and plumbing codes or other applicable rules and regulations of the city. 
(b)  The connection of the building sewer lateral into the public sewer shall conform to the requirements of the building and plumbing codes or other applicable rules and regulations of the city. All such connections shall be made watertight. Any deviation from the prescribed procedures and materials must be approved by the director before installation. 
(Code 1981, § 27-32) 
Sec. 114-208. - General responsibilities of owner with reference to building sewer. 
    All costs and expenses incident to the installation and connection of the building sewer lateral shall be borne by the owner. The owner shall indemnify the city from any loss or damage that may directly or indirectly be occasioned by the installation of the building sewer lateral. 
(Code 1981, § 27-33) 
Sec. 114-209. - Separate building sewer for each building. 
    A separate and independent building sewer lateral shall be provided for every building; provided, however, that upon written application to the director, showing sufficient reason, in the director's opinion, for such action, the director may grant, in writing, an exception from this requirement. 
(Code 1981, § 27-34) 
Sec. 114-210. - Use of old building sewers for new buildings. 
    Old building sewer laterals may be used in connection with new buildings only when they are found upon examination and test by the director to meet all requirements of this article. 
(Code 1981, § 27-35) 
Sec. 114-211. - Building sewer elevation; lifting devices for certain drains. 
    Whenever possible, the building sewer lateral shall be brought to the building at an elevation below the basement floor. In all buildings in which any building drain is too low to permit gravity flow to the public sewer, sanitary sewage carried by such building drain shall be lifted by an approved means and discharged to the building sewer lateral. 
(Code 1981, § 27-36) 
Sec. 114-212. - Guarding of building sewer excavations; restoration of public property disturbed by installation. 
    All excavations for building sewer lateral installation shall be adequately guarded with barricades and lights so as to protect the public from hazard. Streets, sidewalks, parkways and other public property disturbed in the course of the work shall be restored in a manner satisfactory to the city. 
(Code 1981, § 27-37) 
Sec. 114-213. - Inspection of building drain; supervision of connection. 
    The person to whom the building sewer lateral permit was issued shall notify the building official when the building drain is ready for inspection and connection to the public sewer. The connection shall be made under the supervision of the building official or his representative. 
(Code 1981, § 27-38) 
Sec. 114-214. - Connection records to be kept. 
    The director shall preserve a record of the locations and costs of constructing connection pursuant to this division. 
(Code 1981, § 27-39) 
Sec. 114-215. - Connections of downspouts, etc., to building sewers or drains. 
    No person shall make connection of roof downspouts, exterior foundation drains, areaway drains or other sources of surface runoff or groundwater to a building sewer lateral or building drain, which in turn is connected directly or indirectly to a public sanitary sewer. 
(Code 1981, § 27-40) 
Sec. 114-216. - Disconnection of downspouts, etc., from building sewers and drains. 
    Any person whose property or building presently has connections to the public sewer shall remove all roof downspouts, exterior foundation drains, areaways drains, or other sources of surface water or groundwater; provided, however, that a written exception may be granted by the director of public utilities if the owner can show in writing that undue or extreme hardship will result from compliance to this section. The director shall develop criteria and procedures which will be used to evaluate the hardship which will result from compliance with this section. If a written exception is granted, the person may be assessed additional charges for sewer service to compensate the city for collecting and treating the extra wastewater, and may be required to provide flow equalization facilities to reduce the peak flows being discharged to the public sewer. 
(Code 1981, § 27-41) 
Sec. 114-217. - Severability. 
    The provisions of this division are severable, and if any section, subsection, sentence, part or application of this division be adjudged by any court of competent jurisdiction to be invalid, such judgment shall not affect, impair or invalidate any other section, subsection, sentence, part or application but shall be confined in its operation to the section, subsection, sentence, part or application at issue in the controversy in which such judgment shall have been rendered. 
(Ord. No. 08-93, § 4, 10-28-2008) 
Secs. 114-218-114-235. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - SERVICE CHARGES 

Sec. 114-236. - Imposed; amount generally. 
(a)  Inside-city fees. The monthly commodity charge for sanitary sewer service furnished by the city to customers within the city limits shall be as follows: 
(1)  For the first 300 cubic feet, per 100 cubic feet ..... $1.335 
(2)  From 301 cubic feet thru 12,500 cubic feet, per 100 cubic feet ..... 5.742 
(3)  All over 12,500 cubic feet, per 100 cubic feet ..... 3.668 
    The monthly capacity fee for sanitary sewer service furnished within the city limits shall be based upon the following meter sizes: 
Meter Size 
(inches) Monthly Sewer
