    No driver of a taxicab shall have in his possession a lighted cigarette, cigar or pipe while any passenger is being carried in his taxicab. No driver shall engage in chewing tobacco or using snuff while any passenger is being carried in his taxicab. 
(Code 1981, § 37-100) 
Sec. 118-93. - Use of drugs by drivers. 
    At no time shall the driver of a taxicab use narcotics or other habit-forming drugs while he is operating a taxicab. 
(Code 1981, § 37-101) 
Sec. 118-94. - Possession of weapons by drivers. 
    It shall be unlawful for a driver to operate or drive a taxicab at any time while having in his possession or within the vehicle any weapon, which shall include, but not be limited to, firearms in which ammunition may be used or discharged by explosion, pneumatic pressure or mechanical contrivance. 
(Code 1981, § 37-102) 
Sec. 118-95. - Loud talk or calls to and from drivers. 
    Loud talk or calls to and from drivers of taxicabs is prohibited. 
(Code 1981, § 37-103) 
Sec. 118-96. - Driver's manifest. 
(a)  Every taxicab driver shall maintain a daily manifest upon which are recorded the time the taxicab began operation and stopped operation on the streets, the taxicab number and driver's name and all trips made each day, showing the time and place of origin and destination of each trip and the number of passengers and amount of fare. This information shall be recorded at the end of each trip. In addition, the driver shall record on each manifest, at the beginning and end of each tour of duty, the total miles, trips, extra passengers and the speedometer readings. All such completed manifests shall be returned to the certificate holder by the driver at the conclusion of the driver's tour of duty. 
(b)  If a taxicab driver changes taxicabs during his tour of duty, he shall maintain a separate manifest for that portion of the tour of duty in which another vehicle is used. 
(c)  The forms for manifests required by this section shall be furnished to the driver by the certificate holder and shall be subject to the approval of the city manager. It shall be unlawful for any driver to maintain an incomplete manifest. 
(d)  Every certificate holder shall retain and preserve all drivers' manifests in a safe place for at least 90 days and the manifests shall be made available, upon demand, for inspection by the city manager at reasonable times. 
(Code 1981, § 37-104) 
Secs. 118-97-118-115. - Reserved. 
Subdivision II. - License 

Sec. 118-116. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to drive a taxicab, from an origin within the city to a destination within the city, or to any destination other than the jurisdiction in which he is a properly licensed taxicab driver, unless he has a current taxicab driver's license issued pursuant to this division. 
(Code 1981, § 37-151) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to license taxicab drivers, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-310. 
Sec. 118-117. - Application. 
    Application for the license required by this subdivision shall be made, in person, to the chief of police. The application shall provide general information, under oath, on forms supplied by the city, that the city manager may prescribe, regarding the following concerning the applicant: 
(1)  Pertinent personal data. 
(2)  Physical condition. 
(3)  Traffic record for five years previous to the application. Only nolle prosequis, pleas of nolo contendere, convictions and forfeitures of collateral need be reported. Parking citations need not be reported. 
(4)  Criminal record. Only nolle prosequis, pleas of nolo contendere, convictions or forfeitures of collateral need be reported. 
(5)  Experience in driving motor vehicles and taxicabs, if any. 
(Code 1981, § 37-152) 
Sec. 118-118. - Applicant's fingerprints and photographs. 
    The city shall make a record of the fingerprints of each applicant for a taxicab driver's license. Each such applicant shall furnish three recent photographs of himself, of a size and manner prescribed by the city manager. 
(Code 1981, § 37-153) 
Sec. 118-119. - Qualifications of applicant. 
    A taxicab driver's license shall not be issued to any person: 
(1)  Who is covered by diplomatic immunity. 
(2)  Who has less than six months driving experience. 
(3)  Who has not been issued a driver's license by the state. 
(4)  Who is less than 18 years of age. 
(Code 1981, § 37-154) 
Sec. 118-120. - Fees. 
    Each applicant for or holder of a taxicab driver's license shall pay the following fees, when applicable, to the collector of city taxes, for the use of the general fund, and no part thereof shall be returned: 
(1)  For each original application for a taxicab driver's license the fee shall be $10.00; 
(2)  For each renewal application for a taxicab driver's license the fee shall be $10.00; 
(3)  For each fingerprinting by the city, the fee shall be $10.00; 
(4)  For each original, renewed or duplicate taxicab driver's license, the fee shall be $20.00. 
(Code 1981, § 37-155; Ord. No. 17-30, 7-11-2017) 
Sec. 118-121. - Investigation of applicant; temporary license. 
(a)  The chief of police shall have an investigation made of each applicant for a license under this division and of the facts stated in the application for such license and other relevant data. The resulting file shall be available to the applicant or his agent upon request. 
(b)  Pending the investigation provided for in subsection (a) of this section, the chief of police may, in his discretion, issue a taxicab driver's license, for a period not to exceed 30 days, to an applicant who is otherwise qualified. 
(Code 1981, § 37-156) 
Sec. 118-122. - Issuance or refusal. 
(a)  If the chief of police finds that the applicant is duly qualified, of good moral character and of sound health, he shall issue a taxicab driver's license to the applicant. 
(b)  The chief of police may refuse to issue a taxicab driver's license to an applicant for any of the following: 
(1)  Repeated and persistent violations of the motor vehicle laws or ordinances. 
(2)  Conviction of, or plea of guilty to, the violation of any law involving the commission of a felony; any sex offense; solicitating for prostitution; alcohol or narcotics; drunkenness; gambling laws or moral turpitude. 
(3)  If applicant is on parole or probation for a criminal or traffic offense. 
(c)  If the chief of police refuses to issue a taxicab driver's license, he shall transmit written notice thereof to the applicant, by certified mail directed to the address shown on the application, at the time of the decision. 
(Code 1981, § 37-157) 
Sec. 118-123. - Form. 
    The form of a taxicab driver's license shall be prescribed by the chief of police, with the proviso that the license shall bear a recent photograph of the license holder. 
(Code 1981, § 37-158) 
Sec. 118-124. - Not to be left in unattended cab. 
    No driver shall leave his taxicab driver's license in an unattended taxicab at any time. 
(Code 1981, § 37-159) 
Sec. 118-125. - Term; renewal. 
    A nontemporary taxicab driver's license shall be valid for one year from the date of issuance, unless sooner suspended or revoked. The holder of such a license shall make application for its renewal at least 30 days, but not more than 60 days, prior to the expiration of the license. 
(Code 1981, § 37-160) 
Sec. 118-126. - Not transferable; surrender when holder ceases to drive cab. 
    A taxicab driver's license is the property of the city and shall not be transferable to any other driver. Such license shall be surrendered to the chief of police by the holder, when he ceases to drive a taxicab in the city. 
(Code 1981, § 37-161) 
Sec. 118-127. - Suspension or revocation. 
(a)  The chief of police may suspend, for a period of one to 30 days, or revoke the taxicab driver's license of any person for any of the following: 
(1)  Repeated and persistent violations of the motor vehicle laws or ordinances. 
(2)  Conviction of reckless driving. 
(3)  Failure to report any accident in which the operator is involved, however slight. 
(4)  Driving of any taxicab known to the driver not to be in good order and repair. 
(5)  Two or more violations of this article in any one calendar year. 
(6)  Knowingly making a false statement of material and relevant facts on an application for a taxicab driver's license. 
(7)  Conviction or plea of nolo contendere to the violation of any law involving alcohol. 
(8)  Conviction or plea of nolo contendere to the violation of any law involving gambling. 
(9)  Conviction or plea of nolo contendere to the violation of any law involving moral turpitude. 
(b)  The taxicab driver's license of any person shall automatically become revoked and shall be immediately surrendered by him, upon his conviction of, or plea of guilty or nolo contendere to, the violation of any law involving: 
(1)  Commission of a felony. 
(2)  Any sex offense. 
(3)  Soliciting for prostitution. 
(4)  Narcotics. 
(5)  Revocation of state licenses or permits to drive. 
(c)  If a taxicab driver's license is suspended or revoked, the chief of police shall transmit written notice thereof to the license holder, by certified mail directed to the address shown on the license or the application therefor, at the time of the decision. 
(d)  A person whose taxicab driver's license has been revoked by the chief of police shall not reapply for such a license for 365 days from the date of revocation. 
(e)  An appropriately filed appeal of the chief of police's decision suspending or revoking a taxicab driver's license shall stay the effective date of the suspension or revocation only in cases of suspension or revocation pursuant to subsection (a) of this section. The automatic revocation of such a license provided for in subsection (b) of this section shall not be considered an act of the chief of police and, therefore, is not subject to appeal. 
(Code 1981, § 37-162) 
Secs. 118-128-118-145. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - VEHICLES 

Sec. 118-146. - General vehicle requirements. 
(a)  Every taxicab certificated under this article shall be either a vehicle specifically designed for use as a taxicab or a vehicle of the closed or sedan type. 
(b)  Every taxicab governed by this article shall be of good substantial appearance and so constructed and maintained as to provide for the safety of the public, continuous and satisfactory operation and operation with minimum noise and vibration. Every taxicab shall be structurally sound as to all its parts, shall not have broken or cracked fenders or glass and shall be painted to give reasonable protection to all painted surfaces from structural deterioration. All marks of identification on taxicabs shall be permanent and clearly legible at all times. 
(Code 1981, § 37-85) 
Sec. 118-147. - Equipment generally. 
    In addition to equipment required of motor vehicles by the Code of Virginia, which requirements are adopted by section 110-2 of this Code, every taxicab certificated under this article shall be equipped with the following: 
(1)  A frame or holder for the proper display of the certificate card and the taxicab driver's license provided for in this article, which shall face the passengers and be so located as to be at all times in plain view of such passengers. Such frame or holder shall be subject to the approval of the city manager. 
(2)  A heater sufficient to heat the interior of the taxicab adequately in cold weather. 
(3)  A power plant adequate to enable it to operate effectively and efficiently. 
(4)  At least two doors for the entrance and exit of passengers, in addition to the doors which give access to the driver's compartment. Passenger doors must be constructed so that they will remain securely fastened during normal operation but may be readily opened by a passenger in case of emergency. Each door shall be constructed with a double or safety lock. 
(5)  Approved safety nonshatterable glass in the windshield and all windows. The center partition, if any, between the driver's compartment and the passenger compartment, shall be of this type glass or plastic. 
(6)  A standard speedometer properly installed, maintained in good working order and exposed to view. No taxicab shall be operated in taxicab service while such speedometer is out of repair or disconnected. 
(Code 1981, § 37-86) 
Sec. 118-148. - Upholstery; cushions; floor mats. 
    With the exception of a "kick" strip not exceeding seven inches in height at the bottom of doors, no taxicab certificated under this article shall have any seat upholstery covering, unless the same is made of leather or similar nonabsorbent, material. The rear cushion in such a taxicab shall be removable. No floor mat shall be permitted in such taxicab, unless it is made of rubber, leather, metal chain or a similar nonabsorbent, washable material and is easily removable. Variations of the requirements of this section will be permitted, where strict compliance is impossible because of scarcity of materials. 
(Code 1981, § 37-87; Ord. No. 00-38, § 37-87, 6-20-2000) 
Sec. 118-149. - Color scheme, insignia and cruising light design. 
    Every taxicab covered by a certificate shall have a uniform color scheme, insignia and cruising light design approved by the city manager. Changes in the color scheme and insignia shall have prior approval of the city manager. 
(Code 1981, § 37-88) 
Sec. 118-150. - Prohibited lights and signal devices. 
    No taxicab governed by this article shall be equipped with any lights or signal devices other than those allowed by the Code of Virginia or approved by the city manager under the applicable ordinances enacted pursuant thereto. 
(Code 1981, § 37-89) 
Sec. 118-151. - Certain shades or curtains prohibited. 
    No taxicab certificated under this article shall be equipped with shades or curtains which can be manipulated in such a way as to shield the occupants or the driver from observation or obstruct the rear view window. 
(Code 1981, § 37-90) 
Sec. 118-152. - Maintenance. 
    Every taxicab governed by this article shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition and shall be swept and dusted at least once each day. At least once every seven days, the interior shall be cleansed thoroughly with a suitable antiseptic solution. 
(Code 1981, § 37-91) 
Sec. 118-153. - Inspection; correction of defects. 
(a)  The city manager may, at any reasonable time, require the owner or driver of a taxicab to have such vehicle inspected at an official inspection station of the state. No taxicab shall be operated until any defects found by such inspection have been corrected. 
(b)  The city manager shall have the authority, at any reasonable time, to inspect any taxicab, and the certificate holder shall be given a reasonable time to make such repairs or adjustments as are required. 
(Code 1981, § 37-92) 
Sec. 118-154. - Operation. 
    Every taxicab shall be operated in accordance with the laws of this state and the provisions of this Code and other ordinances of the city, with due regard to the safety, comfort and convenience of passengers and the general public. 
(Code 1981, § 37-93) 
Sec. 118-155. - Occupancy of taxicab stand. 
    No taxicab shall be placed upon or be permitted to occupy a taxicab stand, except for the purpose of being held forth for hire. 
(Code 1981, § 37-94) 
Sec. 118-156. - Use for unlawful purposes. 
    No owner or driver of a taxicab shall permit such vehicle to be used for unlawful purposes or knowingly transport persons in such vehicle to places for such purposes. 
(Code 1981, § 37-96) 
Sec. 118-157. - To be attended by driver. 
    Every taxicab, while in operation for the solicitation or transportation of passengers, shall be attended by the driver at all times, except when such driver is actually engaged in loading, unloading or answering telephones in connection with the business. 
(Code 1981, § 37-97) 
Secs. 118-158-118-175. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - PASSENGERS 

Sec. 118-176. - Maximum number of passengers generally. 
    A driver shall not permit more persons, including the driver but excluding children in arms, to be carried in a taxicab in the city at any one time than the seating capacity of the taxicab, as rated by its manufacturer. 
(Code 1981, § 37-105) 
Sec. 118-177. - Maximum number of passengers on front seat. 
    At no time shall more than two persons, in addition to the driver, ride on the front seat of any taxicab, a child in arms excepted. 
(Code 1981, § 37-106) 
Sec. 118-178. - Nonpaying passengers not to be transported with paying passenger; exceptions. 
    No nonpaying passenger shall be transported in a taxicab with a paying passenger, except bona fide officers or employees of the taxicab owner or a police officer engaged in the performance of his duty and unable to obtain other adequate means of transportation. 
(Code 1981, § 37-107) 
Sec. 118-179. - Passenger's consent required for acceptance of other passengers. 
    Whenever any taxicab is occupied by a passenger, the driver shall not permit any other person to occupy or ride in such taxicab, unless, having been requested by the driver, the passenger gives his affirmative permission. 
(Code 1981, § 37-108) 
Sec. 118-180. - Refusal of passengers. 
    Taxicab drivers shall not refuse or neglect to convey any orderly person, upon request, unless previously engaged or forbidden by the provisions of this article to do so. 
(Code 1981, § 37-109) 
Sec. 118-181. - Deception of passengers; use of shortest route to destination. 
    A driver shall not deceive or attempt to deceive any passenger who may ride in his taxicab, or who may desire to ride in such taxicab, as to his destination or the rate of fare to be charged, and shall not convey any passenger, or cause him to be conveyed, to a place other than directed by him. In no event shall any taxicab driver take a longer route to the destination than necessary, unless so requested by the passenger. 
(Code 1981, § 37-110) 
Sec. 118-182. - Compliance with requests of passengers. 
    All taxicab drivers shall comply with all reasonable and lawful requests of their passengers as to the speed of travel and the route to be taken. 
(Code 1981, § 37-111) 
Sec. 118-183. - Passengers not to be permitted to enter or leave from left side of vehicle; exceptions. 
    Drivers shall not permit passengers to enter or to leave any taxicab from the left side, except at the left curb of one-way streets or while parked perpendicular to the curb in places where such parking is permitted. 
(Code 1981, § 37-112) 
Sec. 118-184. - Loading or unloading not to impede or interfere with traffic. 
    Taxicab drivers shall not stop to load or unload passengers or their belongings in the intersection of any streets or on any crosswalk. No taxicab shall be loaded or unloaded in any such manner that will, in any way, impede or interfere with the orderly flow of traffic on the streets. 
(Code 1981, § 37-113) 
Secs. 118-185-118-200. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - FARES 

Sec. 118-201. - Zones established. 
    For the purpose of determining the proper fare to be charged for taxicab service, there shall be nine zones within the city limits, which shall be described as follows: 
Zone 1. Zone 1 shall include all that part of the city lying within the following boundaries: Beginning at the intersection of the north corporate limits and Interstate Route 95; thence southwardly and westwardly along Interstate Routes 95 and 85 to its intersection with Baylor's Lane; thence northwardly along Baylor's Lane to its intersection with Halifax Street; thence eastwardly along Halifax Street to its intersection with Young Avenue; thence westwardly along Young Avenue to its intersection with South West Street; thence northwardly along West Street to its intersection with the north corporate limits; thence eastwardly along the north corporate limits to the point of beginning. 
Zone 2. Zone 2 shall include all that part of the city lying within the following boundaries: Beginning at the intersection of the north corporate limits and Interstate Route 95; thence eastwardly and southwardly along the corporate limits and an extension of same to its intersection with the Norfolk and Western Railway; thence southwardly along the Norfolk and Western Railway to its intersection with County Drive; thence westwardly along County Drive and U.S. Route 460 to its intersection with Graham Road and Crater Road; thence westwardly along Graham Road to its intersection with Interstate Route 85; thence northwardly along Interstate Routes 85 and 95 to the point of beginning. 
Zone 3. Zone 3 shall include all that part of the city lying within the following boundaries: Beginning at the intersection of the north corporate limits and North West Street (projected); thence southwardly along West Street to its intersection with Young Avenue; thence eastwardly along Young Avenue to its intersection with Halifax Street; thence westwardly along Halifax Street to its intersection with Baylor's Lane; thence southwardly to its intersection with Defense Road; thence westwardly along Defense Road to its intersection with Boydton Plank Road; thence westwardly along Boydton Plank Road to the west corporate limits to its intersection with the north corporate limits; thence eastwardly along the north corporate limits to the point of beginning. 
Zone 4. Zone 4 shall include all that part of the city lying within the following boundaries: Beginning at the intersection of the north corporate limits and the east corporate limits; thence southwardly along the east corporate limits to its intersection with Hickory Hill Road; thence westwardly along Hickory Hill Road to its intersection with County Drive; thence westwardly along County Drive to its intersection with the Norfolk and Western Railway; thence northwardly along the Norfolk and Western Railway to a creek; thence northwardly along such creek to the north corporate limits; thence eastwardly along the north corporate limits to the point of beginning. 
Zone 5. Zone 5 shall include all that part of the city lying within the following boundaries: Beginning at the intersection of Interstate Route 85 and Graham Road; thence eastwardly along Graham Road to its intersection with Crater Road; thence southwardly along Crater Road to its intersection with South Boulevard; thence westwardly along South Boulevard to its intersection with Baylor's Lane; thence northwardly along Baylor's Lane to its intersection with Interstate Route 85; thence eastwardly along Interstate Route 85 to the point of beginning. 
Zone 6. Zone 6 shall include all that part of the city lying within the following boundaries: Beginning at the intersection of Hickory Hill Road and the east corporate limits; thence southwardly and westwardly along the east corporate limits and the south corporate limits to its intersection with Interstate Route 95; thence northwardly along Interstate Route 95 to its intersection with County Drive; thence eastwardly along County Drive and Hickory Hill Road to the point of beginning. 
Zone 7. Zone 7 shall include all that part of the city lying within the following boundaries: Beginning at the intersection of Defense Road and Banister Road; thence southwardly along Banister Road to its intersection with the old corporate limits; thence eastwardly and southwardly along the old corporate limits to the Norfolk and Western Railway; thence westwardly along the Norfolk and Western Railway and the corporate limits to the west corporate limits; thence northwardly along the west corporate limits to its intersection with Boydton Plank Road; thence eastwardly along Boydton Plank Road and Defense Road to the point of beginning. 
Zone 8. Zone 8 shall include all that part of the city lying within the following boundaries: Beginning at the intersection of County Drive and Interstate Route 95; thence southwardly along Interstate Route 95 to its intersection with the Norfolk and Western Railway; thence westwardly along the Norfolk and Western Railway to its intersection with the old corporate limits; thence northwardly and westwardly along the old corporate limits to Banister Road; thence northwardly along Banister Road to its intersection with Defense Road; thence eastwardly along Defense Road and South Boulevard to its intersection with Crater Road; thence northwardly along Crater Road to its intersection with Graham Road and U.S. Route 460; thence eastwardly along U.S. Route 460 to the point of beginning. 
Zone 9. Zone 9 shall include all that part of the city lying within the following boundaries: Beginning at the intersection of the Norfolk and Western Railway and Interstate Route 95; thence southwardly along Interstate Route 95 to its intersection with the south corporate limits; thence westwardly along the south corporate limits to its intersection with the west corporate limits; thence northwardly along the west corporate limits to its intersection with the Norfolk and Western Railway; thence eastwardly along the Norfolk and Western Railway to the point of beginning. 
(Code 1981, § 37-174) 
Sec. 118-202. - Rates generally. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to charge other than the following rates of fare, as determined by the city council, for taxicab service: 
(1)  Rates inside corporate limits: 
One-zone trip ..... $5.25 
Two-zone trip ..... 5.75 
Three-zone trip ..... 6.25 
Four-zone trip ..... 6.75 
Five-zone trip ..... 7.25 
(2)  Rates outside corporate limits: 
Hopewell ..... 12.75 
Ettrick ..... 5.75 
Southpark ..... 7.00 
Fort Lee ..... 7.25 
Central State ..... 7.25 
If more than one person is transported, $0.50 for each additional passenger shall be added to the rates set out in (1) and (2) above. 
(b)  The city council may, from time to time, after public notice and upon hearing, and upon determination that taxicab rates previously prescribed are not just and reasonable, prescribe just and reasonable changes in rates or regulations as to rates of fare. The rates so prescribed may be maximum rates or rates certain. It shall be unlawful for any person to charge in excess of the maximum rates, if they be prescribed, or other than the rates certain, if they be prescribed. 
(Code 1981, § 37-175; Ord. No. 00-38, § 37-175, 6-20-2000; Ord. No. 00-51, § 37-175, 7-18-2000; Ord. No. 05-103, 11-1-2005) 
Sec. 118-203. - Rates to be entered on taxicab certificate card. 
    The rates of fare for taxicab service, as determined by the city council, shall be entered on the taxicab certificate card provided for in section 118-68, at the time the card is issued by the city manager. 
(Code 1981, § 37-176) 
Sec. 118-204. - Passenger's receipt. 
    It shall be the duty of the driver of a taxicab to give any passenger so requesting a receipt, in writing, signed by the driver and showing his taxicab driver's license number, the taxicab number, items for which a charge is made, the amount paid and the time and date. 
(Code 1981, § 37-177) 
Sec. 118-205. - Failure of passenger to pay. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person who engages a taxicab for hire, under any agreement, expressed or implied, to refuse or fail to pay, or attempt to avoid payment, for the use of the taxicab, the lawful charge or fare due the driver, based on rates established by the city council. Any person who violates any provision of this section shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1981, § 37-178) 
Secs. 118-206-118-230. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - BUSES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 118-231. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, the following words and terms shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
    Bus means any motor vehicle operated along defined routes for the transportation of passengers for compensation. 
    Interurban bus means a bus used in the business of transporting passengers over the streets of the city from points within the city to points without the city. 
    Intraurban bus means a bus used to transport passengers from one point to another within the city. 
(Code 1981, § 37-16) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 118-232. - Violations of article. 
    Unless otherwise specifically provided, any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall be guilty of a class 4 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1981, § 37-17) 
Secs. 118-233-118-250. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - INTRAURBAN BUSES 

Sec. 118-251. - Application of and compliance with division. 
(a)  The operation of all intraurban buses in the city shall be subject to the conditions, regulations and restrictions set forth in this division. 
(b)  All of the provisions of this division imposing obligations or requirements on any person operating hereunder shall be deemed to be mandatory, and no intraurban bus shall be operated on the streets of the city, save and except in accordance with the terms and conditions of this division. 
(Code 1981, § 37-25) 
Sec. 118-252. - Operating permit. 
    No person shall operate an intraurban bus within the city, unless he shall first obtain from the city manager a permit to do so. Such permit shall be subject to revocation upon six months' notice, in writing, given by the city manager to the operator, for any of the following grounds: 
(1)  Failure to operate the authorized buses in such a manner as to serve the public adequately. 
(2)  Failure to maintain buses in good order and repair. 
(3)  Failure to maintain insurance as required by this chapter. 
(4)  Repeated and persistent violations, by the permit holder or his drivers, of this Code or the motor vehicle laws of the state. 
(5)  Failure to report any accident as required by this Code. 
(6)  Failure to pay any fees lawfully assessed upon the ownership or operation of any vehicle covered by the permit. 
(7)  Failure to supply information required under this article. 
(Code 1981, §§ 37-26, 37-138(a)) 
Sec. 118-253. - Discontinuance of service by permit holder. 
    Any person having a permit to operate intraurban buses shall continue operations thereunder until the expiration of a period of six months from the date of a notice, in writing, given by such person to the city manager of his intention to discontinue such service. 
(Code 1981, § 37-27) 
Sec. 118-254. - Interior lights. 
    No bus operating under this division shall be operated between one-half hour after sunset and one-half hour before sunrise, except in case of emergency, unless sufficient light is provided to adequately light the whole of the interior of such bus. 
(Code 1981, § 37-28) 
Sec. 118-255. - Routes generally. 
    The city manager shall have authority to establish, change or extend intraurban bus routes in the city. 
(Code 1981, § 37-29) 
Sec. 118-256. - Temporary change of routes. 
    The director of traffic and transportation may, in all cases of fires, accidents, parades, obstructions, break ins or repairs to streets or any other emergency which requires such action, temporarily modify bus routes established by the city manager and require the use of such other streets as, in his opinion, the public convenience and safety may require, until the emergency calling for such action has terminated. 
(Code 1981, § 37-30) 
Sec. 118-257. - Deviation from routes. 
    It shall be unlawful for the driver of any bus operated under this division to operate such bus on any route or street other than the route or streets designated in the manner provided by this division. No deviation from any authorized route shall be practiced or permitted, except that, in case any authorized route is obstructed on any block, drivers may, unless the city manager shall otherwise direct, make a detour by the nearest streets around the block on which the obstruction exists, returning to the prescribed route as soon as the obstruction has been passed. 
(Code 1981, § 37-31(a)) 
Sec. 118-258. - Fares-Prescribed. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided, the fare charged passengers on buses operated on duly established routes shall be $1.50. Fare tickets, in booklets of ten, may be purchased for $12.00. Children who are pupils of any public or parochial school in the city during the regular school session and the summer school session, shall be issued 20 tickets, upon payment of $12.00, which tickets may be used by such children between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m., on school days only. 
(b)  The fare for elderly and persons with disabilities shall be one-half the normal fare prescribed by this section, and shall be applicable during all hours of operation. As used in this section, the term "elderly and persons with disabilities" means those individuals who, by reason of illness, injury, age, congenital malfunction or other permanent or temporary incapacity or disability, including those who are non-ambulatory wheelchair-bound and those with semi-ambulatory capabilities, are unable, without special facilities or special planning or design, to utilize mass transportation facilities and services as effectively as persons who are not so affected. 
(c)  The fare for persons eligible to be transported by the special elderly and persons with disabilities van service shall be $1.00. 
(Code 1981, § 37-32; Ord. No. 01-37, 6-19-2001; Ord. No. 07-01, 1-2-2007; Ord. No. 12-51, § 1, 6-5-2012) 
Sec. 118-259. - Same-Charging or receiving other than prescribed fare. 
    No person operating under this division shall permit to be charged nor shall the driver of any bus owned by such person charge, demand, collect or receive a greater or different compensation for the transportation of passengers or for any service in connection therewith than the rates and charges specified in section 118-258. 
(Code 1981, § 37-33) 
Sec. 118-260. - Same-Passengers to have exact change; posting of fares; etc. 
    Buses governed by this division shall be operated on an exact change basis. The exact fare shall be posted on each bus and drivers shall not be allowed to make change or to deposit fares. 
(Code 1981, § 37-34) 
Sec. 118-261. - Operation for excursions or special services. 
    Nothing in this division shall prevent any person operating under this division from operating buses for excursion parties or special services under charter or other contract at such charges as may be agreed upon; provided, that there shall be no interference thereby with the operation of the established schedules. 
(Code 1981, § 37-35) 
Sec. 118-262. - Smoking prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person operating any bus under this division or for any passenger in such bus to smoke or have in his possession a lighted cigar, cigarette or pipe, while such bus is in operation, and it shall be unlawful for such operator to permit any passenger so to do. 
(Code 1981, § 37-36) 
Sec. 118-263. - Disposition of property left in bus. 
    The person in charge of any bus operated under this division shall carefully preserve any money or other property left in such bus by any passenger and the money or other property shall be promptly deposited with the person owning or operating such bus, to be kept by him at some convenient point within the city, where the money or other property may be called for by the owner. When such money or property is identified and ownership established, the money or property shall be promptly delivered to such owner. Any property, whether money or otherwise, which is not called for within three months, shall be disposed of according to law. 
(Code 1981, § 37-37) 
Secs. 118-264-118-280. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - INTERURBAN BUSES 

Sec. 118-281. - Application of division. 
    The provisions of this division shall apply to the operation of interurban buses; provided, however, that this division shall not apply to persons owning, controlling or operating any bus in the business of transporting persons for compensation over the streets of the city from points within the city to points without the city within a radius of not more than ten miles. 
(Code 1981, § 37-49) 
Sec. 118-282. - Owner not to permit violations of division. 
    It shall be unlawful for any owner or other person in control of the operation of interurban buses to permit the driver of any such bus to violate any provision of this division. 
(Code 1981, § 37-50) 
Sec. 118-283. - Waiting room and terminal. 
    It shall be the duty of each interurban bus operator to provide a waiting room and terminal where buses may be loaded and unloaded on private property and off the streets of the city. Such waiting room shall be kept clean, properly lighted and ventilated and shall be equipped with necessary restroom facilities. 
(Code 1981, § 37-51) 
Sec. 118-284. - Intracity transportation prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for the driver of an interurban bus to take on any passenger in the city and discharge him within the city limits. 
(Code 1981, § 37-53) 
Sec. 118-285. - Taking on or discharging passengers on streets. 
    It shall be unlawful for the driver of any interurban bus to take on or discharge passengers on the streets of the city, within a radius of one mile from the terminal station of the bus line. The city manager is hereby authorized to designate one stop each way, other than at the terminal station, at which interurban buses may be stopped for the purpose of taking on or discharging passengers using such buses in traveling from the city to points in the County of Chesterfield, or in traveling from points in the County of Chesterfield to points in the city. 
(Code 1981, § 37-54) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 98. 
Sec. 118-286. - Taking on or discharging passengers at hotels, motels or lodginghouses. 
    It shall be unlawful for the driver of an interurban bus to stop such bus at any hotel, motel or lodginghouse in the city for the purpose of taking on or discharging passengers. 
(Code 1981, § 37-55) 
Secs. 118-287-118-310. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - EMERGENCY MEDICAL SERVICES VEHICLES[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Statewide emergency medical services system and services, Code of Virginia, § 32.1-111.1 et seq.; powers of city council as to emergency medical services, Code of Virginia, § 32.1-111.14. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 118-311. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Attendant means any person riding in attendance with a patient. 
    Call; run means the act of progressing with an emergency medical services vehicle to the scene of need and transporting a patient to his destination. 
    Certificate means a certificate of public convenience and necessity issued under this article and authorizing the operation of an emergency medical services vehicle or emergency medical services vehicles. 
    Emergency medical services vehicle means any motor vehicle that is specially designed, constructed or modified and equipped and is intended to be used for, and is maintained and operated to, provide immediate medical care to, or to transport, persons who are sick, injured, wounded or otherwise incapacitated or helpless. 
    Owner means the owner of one or more emergency medical services vehicles, or his designee. 
(Code 1981, § 4-1) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference- "Emergency medical services vehicle" defined, Code of Virginia, § 32.1-111.1. 
Sec. 118-312. - Violations of article. 
    Unless otherwise specifically provided, a violation of any provision of this article shall constitute a class 1 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1981, § 4-2) 
Sec. 118-313. - Insurance. 
(a)  Every owner operating emergency medical services vehicle under a certificate shall submit to the city council evidence of public liability and property damage insurance, in force with an insurance company licensed to conduct business in this state, in at least the following amounts: 
Bodily injury ..... $100,000.00 per person Bodily injury ..... $300,000.00 per accident Property damage ..... $50,000.00 per accident  
(b)  Such owner shall also show that the city is named as an insured on such policies. 
(Code 1981, § 4-3) 
State Law reference- Authority of city council to set minimum limits of liability insurance coverage for emergency medical services vehicles, Code of Virginia, § 32.1-111.14. 
Sec. 118-314. - Terminal. 
    Every emergency medical services vehicle operated under a certificate on the streets of the city shall have a headquarters terminal wherefrom emergency medical services vehicles are dispatched and whereto such emergency medical services vehicles shall return by the most direct route. 
(Code 1981, § 4-4) 
Sec. 118-315. - Identification. 
    Each emergency medical services vehicle operated within the city shall bear the name of the owner and a unit number. 
(Code 1981, § 4-5) 
Sec. 118-316. - Construction, equipment and maintenance. 
    All emergency medical services vehicles operated within the city shall be constructed, equipped and maintained in accord with all applicable requirements of Code of Virginia, tit. 46.2, and with the specifications, rules and regulations adopted by the state board of health pursuant to Code of Virginia, § 32.1-111.4. 
(Code 1981, § 4-6) 
Sec. 118-317. - Communications equipment; dispatcher. 
(a)  Each emergency medical services vehicle shall be equipped with a two-way radio licensed by the Federal Communications Commission and in operative condition at all times. 
(b)  Each emergency medical services vehicle owner shall maintain a dispatcher 24 hours every day, at his base of operation, for the purpose of communication with the public and with the emergency medical services vehicles. 
(c)  Each emergency medical services vehicle owner must provide direct communications with the city police dispatcher from his base of operation. 
(Code 1981, § 4-7) 
Sec. 118-318. - Inspection; correction of defects. 
(a)  Each owner must inspect each emergency medical services vehicle every morning, to ascertain cleanliness, mechanical and operational worthiness for transporting patients. Each emergency medical services vehicle shall be subject to inspection at all reasonable times by an authorized representative of the city. 
(b)  Any emergency medical services vehicle found by the owner or an authorized representative of the city, upon inspection, to be unsafe for emergency medical services vehicle operations shall have such repairs and alterations made as may be required and the owner shall not operate or cause to be operated any such emergency medical services vehicle, until all such repairs and alterations have been completed. 
(c)  Monthly records of inspections of emergency medical services vehicles and their equipment shall be kept current and made available to any governmental agency requesting such records. 
(Code 1981, § 4-8) 
Sec. 118-319. - Certified attendant. 
    No person shall operate an emergency medical services vehicle on an emergency run or call, unless an emergency medical care attendant, currently certified by the state health commissioner pursuant to Code of Virginia, § 32.1-111.5, is on duty in such emergency medical services vehicle. 
(Code 1981, § 4-9) 
Sec. 118-320. - Notice to police department of request for emergency run; procedures. 
    Upon receipt of a request for an emergency run, an emergency medical services vehicle dispatcher shall notify the police department dispatcher of the nature of the emergency and the location thereof as soon as possible and practical. Upon arrival at the scene of the emergency, the emergency medical services vehicle attendant shall immediately determine the condition of the patient and administer any necessary first-aid treatment. Thereupon, the patient shall immediately be transported to medical attention, under emergency run conditions, only if the patient's condition is such as to warrant immediate medical attention of a physician in order to conserve human life or relieve undue suffering. 
(Code 1981, § 4-10) 
Sec. 118-321. - Maximum charges. 
(a)  No person owning, operating or controlling an ambulance covered by a certificate issued under this article shall charge other than the following rates for ambulance service: 
(1)  Maximum charge of $825.00 per person within the city limits to be charged as follows: 
a.  Basic life support (BLS) ..... $500.00 
b.  Advance life support 1 (ALS-1) ..... 600.00 
c.  Advance life support 2 (ALS-2) ..... 825.00 
(2)  A charge of $12.50 per loaded mile while patient is in the vehicle. 
(b)  Any ambulance company owner or operator charging in excess of the rates prescribed in this section shall be guilty of a class 4 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1981, § 4-11; Ord. No. 96-13, § 4-11, 9-19-1995; Ord. No. 00-34, § 4-11, 6-20-2000; Ord. No. 01-72, 12-11-2001; Ord. No. 04-98, 11-9-2004; Ord. No. 08-14, 2-5-2008; Ord. No. 17-38, 9-5-2017) 
Sec. 118-322. - Obtaining or receiving service without intending to pay. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to obtain or receive emergency medical services vehicle service without intending, at the time of obtaining or receiving such service, to pay, if financially able, the necessary charges. 
(b)  Any violation of the provisions of this section shall constitute a class 2 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1981, § 4-12) 
Sec. 118-323. - Record of calls; dispatcher's daily log. 
(a)  There shall be maintained, for a period of not less than three years, a record of all calls made by an emergency medical services vehicle operated under this article. Such record shall show all of the following: 
(1)  The patient's name, age, race, sex and address. 
(2)  The time the request for service was received. 
(3)  The time the emergency medical services vehicle was dispatched. 
(4)  The time the emergency medical services vehicle arrived at the scene. 
(5)  The name of the hospital or other place of medical attention to which the patient was transported and the time the emergency medical services vehicle arrived at such hospital or place. 
(6)  Whether or not the call was an emergency. 
(7)  The condition of the patient and whether or not first-aid treatment was administered. 
(8)  Whether or not an emergency run was made. 
(9)  The names of the driver, the attendant and the dispatcher. 
(b)  The dispatcher of any emergency medical services vehicle shall maintain a daily log for the purpose of identifying persons transported in any one day. 
(Code 1981, § 4-13) 
Sec. 118-324. - Inventory of personal possessions of unconscious or deceased persons. 
    In the event that the transport of a deceased or unconscious person is made by an emergency medical services vehicle, the emergency medical services vehicle driver or attendant shall prepare a written inventory of such person's personal possessions transported, witnessed by the agency receiving the deceased or unconscious person. Such inventory shall be kept on file by the owner of the emergency medical services vehicle for a period of two years. At reasonable times, such inventory may be inspected by the next of kin of the person so transported and by any governmental agency having authority to make such inspection. A copy of such inventory shall be given to the witnessing agency. 
(Code 1981, § 4-14) 
Sec. 118-325. - Prohibited acts by drivers and attendants. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person employed or acting as an emergency medical services vehicle driver or attendant to commit or cause to be committed any of the following acts: 
(1)  To fail to comply with all reasonable and lawful requests of the patient as to first-aid treatment and destination. 
(2)  To smoke while inside or outside an emergency medical services vehicle, whether moving or standing, during the transportation of a patient. 
(3)  To transport any deceased person, except upon explicit instructions of the deceased's family, the medical examiner, or the police, after permitted by the police, to any place other than a local state recognized hospital. 
(4)  To move any deceased person except by permission of the city police or the medical examiner. 
(5)  To move any patient where there is suspicion of foul play, without notifying the city police of such suspicion. 
(6)  To recommend to anyone a particular funeral home to handle a deceased person. 
(7)  To administer, prescribe, employ or sell any drug, herb, medicine, plaster or belt or attempt the treatment of a disease. 
(8)  To make vaginal examinations for the purpose of determining pregnancy or to attempt to mechanically break the bag of waters or remove adherent placental tissue. 
(9)  In the event of miscarriage, to transport any patient without first obtaining all placenta membranes and transporting the placenta membranes with the patient if found. 
(10)  To disregard any instruction from a licensed physician of this state as concerns the welfare of patient. 
(11)  To disregard any instruction of any police officer during the administering of first-aid, transporting, standing or en route to destination. 
(12)  To permit anyone to sit in the attendant seat, other than the attendant or a doctor or registered nurse, while transporting a patient. 
(13)  To make an emergency run, without having notified the city police as soon as possible or practical. 
(Code 1981, § 4-15) 
Secs. 118-326-118-340. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CERTIFICATE OF PUBLIC CONVENIENCE AND NECESSITY 

Sec. 118-341. - Required. 
    No person shall operate or cause to be operated an emergency medical services vehicle within the city, without first having obtained a certificate of public convenience and necessity from the city council authorizing such operation. 
(Code 1981, § 4-27) 
State Law reference- Authority of city council to require permit or franchise for operation of emergency medical services vehicles, Code of Virginia, § 32.1-111.14. 
Sec. 118-342. - Application. 
    All persons applying to the city council for a certificate under this article shall file with the city council a sworn application therefor, in triplicate, on forms provided by the city council, stating as follows: 
(1)  The name and address of the owner and, in the event the owner is a corporation, a certified copy of its articles of incorporation. 
(2)  The number of emergency medical services vehicles actually owned and the number of emergency medical services vehicles actually operated by such owner on the date of such application, if any. 
(3)  The net worth of the owner or applicant over and above all debts, judgments, demands and claims whatsoever. 
(4)  Whether there are any unsatisfied judgments of record against the applicant, and if so, the title of all actions and the amount of all judgments unsatisfied. 
(5)  The make, type, year of manufacture, serial number and equipment therein for each emergency medical services vehicle owned or operated by the applicant. 
(6)  The court record, if any, of the applicant. If the applicant is a corporation, the court record, if any, of the officers, directors and supervising employees thereof, including the general manager or director, shall be included. 
(7)  Whether there are any liens, mortgages or other encumbrances on such emergency medical services vehicles and, if so, the amount and character thereof. 
(Code 1981, § 4-28(1)-(7)) 
Sec. 118-343. - Hearing; determination of public convenience and necessity. 
    Upon receipt of an application for a certificate under this article, the city council shall fix a time and place for hearing the applicant. No certificate shall be granted, unless the city council shall find, after hearing, that the public convenience and necessity require the proposed emergency medical services vehicle service. In determining whether the public convenience and necessity require the operation of an emergency medical services vehicle or emergency medical services vehicles for which application for a certificate is made, the city council will consider and investigate: 
(1)  The statements made in the application. 
(2)  The adequacy of existing emergency medical services vehicle service. 
(3)  The financial responsibility, experience and character of the applicant. 
(4)  The public need for additional service. 
(5)  The ability of existing holders of a certificate to provide any necessary additional service. 
(6)  Any other factors pertinent to such determination. 
(Code 1981, § 4-29) 
Sec. 118-344. - Issuance. 
    Upon finding that the public convenience and necessity require the emergency medical services vehicle service proposed in an application filed under this article, the city council shall grant to the applicant a certificate upon the terms and conditions prescribed by this article; provided: 
(1)  The applicant has complied with all the provisions of this article; 
(2)  The emergency medical services vehicle or emergency medical services vehicles proposed to be operated under such certificate are found, after inspection by the police department, to meet the requirements of this article; 
(3)  There are no unsatisfied judgments of record against the applicant; and 
(4)  The court record, if any, of the applicant is such as would conform to the public interest upon granting of a certificate. 
(Code 1981, § 4-30) 
Sec. 118-345. - Appeal from refusal. 
    In the event the city council shall refuse, after a hearing, to issue a certificate to the applicant therefor, upon the ground that public convenience and necessity do not require the operation of additional emergency medical services vehicles in the city, or because it has required persons then engaged in such business in the city and holding certificates, or any one or more of them, to provide such additional service, or because it is not satisfied as to suitability, character and qualifications of the applicant to conduct such business, or the financial responsibility of the applicant, or the applicant's experience or ability to conduct such business, the applicant may, within, ten days from the date of such refusal, file with the circuit court of the city a petition, in writing, to review the findings of the city council and its action with respect to such certificate. A copy of such petition, in which shall be stated the time and place at which it will be presented to the court, shall be served on the city manager. 
(Code 1981, § 4-31) 
Sec. 118-346. - Term. 
    In order that any applicant granted a certificate under this article may justify the capital investment essential to the adequate and efficient emergency medical services vehicle service required in the public interest, the term of any certificate granted shall be ten years, unless such certificate is sooner suspended or revoked. 
(Code 1981, § 4-32) 
Sec. 118-347. - Sale, transfer, etc. 
    No certificate granted under this article may be sold, assigned or transferred, nor shall such certificate in any way vest in any person other than the applicant to whom the certificate is granted any rights or privileges under such certificate. 
(Code 1981, § 4-33) 
Sec. 118-348. - Suspension or revocation. 
    Any certificate granted under this article may be suspended or revoked by the city council, after a hearing held upon 30 days notice to the certificate holder, for failure to comply with any provision of this article. If, upon such hearing, the city council shall find that the certificate holder has corrected any deficiencies and has brought himself into compliance with the provisions of this article, the certificate shall not be suspended or revoked. 
(Code 1981, § 4-34) 
Secs. 118-349-118-370. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - EMPLOYEE HAULERS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 118-371. - Definition. 
    For the purposes of this article, the term "employee hauler" shall mean any person operating a passenger vehicle, for pay or compensation to transport persons from various points within the city to their place of employment, either within or without the city. 
(Code 1981, § 37-191) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 118-372. - Application of and compliance with article. 
    The operation of passenger vehicles by employee haulers upon the streets of the city shall be subject to the conditions, regulations and restrictions set forth in this article. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate, or cause to be operated, within the city any such vehicle, unless such conditions, regulations and restrictions are complied with by the owners, operators and drivers of such vehicles. 
(Code 1981, § 37-192) 
Sec. 118-373. - Violations of article. 
    Unless otherwise specifically provided, any violation of any provision of this article shall constitute a class 2 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1981, § 37-193) 
Sec. 118-374. - Insurance. 
    No employee hauler vehicle shall be operated on the streets of the city, unless the owner and driver are protected by liability and property damage insurance issued by a company authorized to do business in this state in the sum of such amounts as are required under section 118-39 for taxicabs. 
(Code 1981, § 37-194) 
Secs. 118-375-118-390. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 118-391. - Required. 
    No person shall operate, or cause to be operated, any employee hauler vehicle upon the streets of the city, unless he has a current permit so to do issued by the city manager. 
(Code 1981, § 37-206) 
Sec. 118-392. - Application. 
    Application for a permit required by this division shall be filed with the city manager, upon forms prescribed by him. 
(Code 1981, § 37-207) 
Sec. 118-393. - Issuance. 
    The city manager shall issue a permit applied for under this division for the number of employee hauler vehicles specified in the application, without proof of public convenience and necessity. 
(Code 1981, § 37-208) 
Sec. 118-394. - Sale or transfer. 
    A permit issued under this division shall be sold or transferred only with the consent and approval of the city manager. The person making the sale or transfer shall state, under oath, if the city manager requires it, the selling price of the permit and the vehicle. If the city manager shall find that the proposed sale or transfer is other than bona fide, he shall refuse his consent to, or approval of, such sale or transfer. 
(Code 1981, § 37-209) 
Sec. 118-395. - Expiration and renewal. 
    Permits issued under this division shall expire on April 30 following the date of issue and shall be renewed annually thereafter. 
(Code 1981, § 37-210) 
Sec. 118-396. - Revocation. 
    Permits issued under this division may be revoked by the city manager, at any time, pursuant to uniform city standards. 
(Code 1981, § 37-211)
